Praefatio.	 Preface.
Postquam compleui uobis o Filii, librum hunc, qui est postremus scientiae in medicina cum complemento ipsius, et consecutus sum finem in eo, ex expositionibus eius, et ipsius declarationibus, uisum est mihi, ut compleam ipsum uobis cum hoc Tractatu qui est pars operationis, id est, chirurgiae cum manu.	 After I have completed for you, O Sons, this book which is the last in medicine with its complement, and I have reached the end of it through its explanations and declarations, it seemed to me that I should complete it for you with this Treatise which is a part of operation, that is, surgery with the hand.
Quoniam operatio cum manu prostrata est in regione nostra, et tempore nostro priuata omnino: donec fortasse periit scientia eius, et abscissum est uestigium eius: et non remanserunt ex ea, nisi descriptiones paruae in libris antiquorum, quas mutauerunt manus: et accidit eis error et haesitatio, donec clausae sunt intentiones eius, et elongata est uis ipsius: Visum est mihi, ut uiuificem eam cum ordinatione huius Tractatus in ea secundum uiam ex positionis, et declarationis, et abbreuiationis: et ut ueniam cum formis ferramentorum Cauterii, et reliquorum instrumentorum operis: cum fit ex declarationis additione, et ex properatione eius quod est necesse.	 Since operation with the hand is abandoned in our region and time altogether, so that perhaps its knowledge has perished and its trace has been cut off; and nothing remains of it except for small descriptions in the books of the ancients, which have been changed by hands; and errors and hesitations occurred to them, until their intentions were closed and their strength was weakened. It seemed to me that I should revive it with the arrangement of this Treatise on it according to the way of positioning, explanation, and abbreviation; and that I would come with figures of the cautery iron and other instruments for work: as is done by adding explanations and hastening what is necessary.
Caussa autem propter quam non inuenitur bonus artifex eius cum manu sua in hoc nostro tempore, est: quia ars medicinae est longa, et oportet auctorem eius exercitari ante illud in scientia anatomiae, quam narrauit Galenus, donec sciat iuuamenta membrorum, et ipsorum formas, et eorum coniunctionem, et separationem, et habeat cognitionem ossium, et neruorum, et lacertorum, et numerum ipsorum, et eorum egressionem, et uenarum pulsatilium, et quietarum, et locorum exitus earum.	 But the reason why a good artisan of it is not found with his hand in this our time is that the art of medicine is long, and it is necessary for its author to be trained beforehand in the science of anatomy, as Galen narrated, until he knows the supports of the members, and their forms, and their conjunction and separation, and has knowledge of the bones, and nerves, and sinews, and their number, and their exit, and of the pulsatile and quiet veins, and of the exits of these.
Et propter illud dixit Hippocrates, quod nomen cum nomine est multum, et cum opere est paucum, et praecipue in arte manus.	 And because of this, Hippocrates said that a name with a name is much, and with work it is little, especially in the art of the hand.
Nos uero iam diximus de illo in introitu huius libri.	 But we have already spoken about that at the beginning of this book.
Quoniam qui non est sciens, quod diximus de anatomia, non euacuatur, quin iam cadat in errorem, quo interficiuntur homines: sicut ego uidi multos ex illis, qui formantur de hac scientia, et iactant se de ea absque scientia, et sine experimento.	 "Since he who is not knowledgeable about what we said regarding anatomy is not purged of error, whereby men are killed: just as I have seen many of those who claim to be formed in this science and boast about it without knowledge or experience.
Quod est, quia uidi medicum stolidum secuisse apostema scrophulosum in collo mulieris, et incidit quasdam arterias in collo: quare fluxit sanguis mulieris, donec cecidit mortua inter manus eius.	 "Which is to say, I have seen a foolish physician cut out a scrofulous abscess on a woman's neck, and he sliced into some of the arteries in her neck; therefore, the woman’s blood flowed until she died in his hands.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui praesumpsit ut extraheret lapidem uiro, qui processerat in aetate, et lapis erat magnus.	 "And I have seen another physician who presumed to remove a stone from a man who had grown old, and the stone was large.
Peruenit ergo ad eum, et extraxit ipsum cum frusto uesicae.	 "He came to him and removed it along with a piece of the bladder.
Quare mortuus est uir in tertio die.	 "Wherefore the man died on the third day.
Et ego quidem iam uocatus fueram ad extrahendum ipsum: et uidi ex magnitudine lapidis, et dispositione infirmi, quod moriretur.	 "And I was called to remove it, and seeing the great size of the stone and the condition of the patient, I knew that he would die.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui accipiebat stipem apud quendam Ducum terrae nostrae propter medicinam: et accidit eunucho nigro, qui erat apud ipsum, fractura in crure eius prope calcaneum: et properauit medicus cum ignorantia sua, et strinxit fracturam super uulnus cum puluinaribus, et astellis strictura forti, et non dimisit uulneri expirationem.	 "And I have seen another physician who received payment from a certain Duke of our land for his medical service: and it happened to a black eunuch who was with him that he suffered a fracture in his leg near the ankle; and the physician, in his ignorance, hastily bound the fracture over the wound with bandages and strong clamps, allowing no air to reach the wound.
Deinde absoluit eum secundum desyderia sua.	 "Then he released him according to his wishes.
Postea dimisit eum diebus aliquot, et praecepit ei, ne solueret ligamentum: et stetit sic donec apostematum est crus eius, et ipsius pes, et peruenit ad perditionem.	 "After that, he released him after a few days and ordered him not to loosen the bandage; and so it remained until his leg became gangrenous, along with his foot, leading to its destruction.
Vocatus sum ergo ad eum: et properaui ad soluendum ligamentum: et consecuta est tranquillitas, et euasit a doloribus suis.	 "So I was called to him and hastened to loosen the bandage; and he found relief and was freed from his pains.
Verumtamen corruptio iam confirmata erat in membro: et non potui refraenare ipsam.	 "But the corruption in the limb had already taken hold, and I could not stop it.
Pon ergo cessauit corruptio perambulare in membro, donec periit.	 Therefore, the corruption ceased to walk in the limb until it died.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui perforauit apostema cancerosum: et ulceratum est post dies, donec magnificata est malicia eius cum domino ipsius.	 And I saw another physician who pierced a cancerous abscess, and it became ulcerated after several days until the evil of it was greatly increased with its lord.
Quod est, quia quando est cancer purus ex humore melancholico, tunc non oportet ut perueniatur ad eum cum ferro omnino, nisi sit in membro quod toleret, ut abscindatur totum eius.	 That is, because when the cancer is pure of black bile, then it is not necessary to approach it with iron at all unless it is in a member that can bear it, so that all of it may be cut off.
Et propter illud o Filii, necesse est uobis, ut sciatis, quod operatio cum manu diuiditur in duas diuisiones: scilicet, operationem cui associatur salus: et operationem, cum qua est periculum in pluribus dispositionibus.	 And because of this, O sons, it is necessary for you to know that the surgical operation is divided into two divisions: namely, the operation associated with health and the operation which involves danger in many dispositions.
Et ego iam excitaui in omni loco huius libri, in quo uenit operatio, in qua est terror et timor.	 And I have already pointed out in every place of this book where an operation occurs which involves fear and dread.
Quare necesse est uobis, ut caueatis illud, et dimitatis ipsum: ut non inueniant stolidi uiam ad loquendum, et dehonestandum.	 Therefore it is necessary for you to beware of that and to avoid it, so that the foolish may not find a way to speak about it and dishonor it.
Accipite ergo mensuram cum sollicitudine et protectione, et infirmos uestros cum facilitate et firmitudine, et utimini uia meliore perducente gratia Dei ad salutem et successionem laudabilem: et dimittite aegritudines terribiles difficilis sanationis: et tollite animas uestras ab eo quod facit uos timere, ut ingrediatur super uos haesitatio in fide uestra et commodo uestro.	 Receive then the measure with diligence and caution, and your sick with ease and steadfastness, and use the better way which leads by the grace of God to health and praiseworthy success: and leave behind terrible diseases of difficult cure; and lift up your spirits from that which makes you fearful, so that hesitation may not come upon you in your faith and interest.
Est enim magis remanens ad gloriam uestram, et sublimius in mundo isto, et postremo ad quantitates uestras.	 For it remains more for your glory, and is higher in this world, and finally to the degree of your abilities.
Galenus enim iam dixit in quibusdam suis admonitionibus.	 For Galen has already said in some of his advice.
Non medicetis aegritudinem malam: ne nominemini medici mali.	 Do not treat the bad disease, lest you be called a bad physician.
Iam autem diuisi hunc Tractatum secundum tria Capitula. ¶	 Now, however, I have divided this Treatise into three Chapters.
Capitulum primum.	 Chapter One.
De Cauterio cum igne, et Cauterio cum medicina acuta, capitulatum, et ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum, et ferramentis Cauterii: et omni quod necessarium est in operatione. ¶	 On Cautery with Fire, and Cautery with Sharp Medicine, this Chapter is arranged and ordered from the head to the feet, including the shapes of the instruments and tools for cautery, and everything necessary for the operation.
Capitulum secundum.	 Chapter Two.
De sectione et perforatione, phlebotomia et uentosis, et uulneribus: et extractione sagittarum, et similibus illius: et totum capitulatum, ordinatum formis instrumentorum. ¶	 About incision and perforation, bloodletting and ventoses, and wounds: about the extraction of arrows and similar things: and all this is arranged according to the forms of the instruments.
Capitulum tertium.	 Chapter Three.
De restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus illius: capitulatum, ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum.	 About restoration and dislocation, and the cure of wrenching, and similar things: arranged from head to foot, according to the forms of the instruments.
Soli Deo Gloria.	 To God alone be the glory.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis.	 The Surgical Book of Albucasis.
Pars I.	 Part One.
¶ De Iuuamento, et Nocumento Cauterii: et quibus complexionibus conueniat, et quo tempore: et si cum ferro, uel auro.	 ¶ About the help and harm of cautery: and in which temperaments it is suitable, and at what time: and whether with iron or gold. ✨
Caput I.	 Chapter One.
Sed Ante Quidem Quam rememorer operationis cum eo, oportet ut dicam qualitatem Iuuamentorum eius, et Nocumentorum ipsius: et in qua complexione exhibeatur.	 But before I remind you of the procedure with it, it is necessary for me to say about its benefits and harms, and in which temperament it should be administered.
Dico ergo, quod sermo de qualitate iuuamenti Cauterii, et nocumenti eius, est sermo prolixus, et subtilis, scientia, et secretum occultum.	 Therefore, I say that the discussion about the quality of the help and harm of cautery is a lengthy and subtle science, and an obscure secret.
Etiam locuta fuit in eo multitudo sapientum, et dissenserunt in eo: et mihi quidem sufficit parum ex sermonibus eorum, timens prolongationem.	 Many wise men have also spoken about it and disagreed about it, and for me, a little from their discussions is enough, fearing prolixity. ✨
Dico ergo, quod Cauterium confert uniuersaliter omni complexioni, quae est cum materia, et absque materia: excaeptis duabus complexionibus, quae sunt complexio calida absque materia, et complexio sicca absque materia.	 Therefore, I say that cautery benefits every temperament, whether material or immaterial, except for two temperaments: the hot temperament without matter and the dry temperament without matter.
In complexione autem calida et sicca cum materia dissenserunt.	 About the hot and dry temperament with matter, they disagreed.
Quidam enim dixerunt, quod Cauterium iuuatiuum est in ea.	 For some said that cautery is helpful in it. ✨ ✨ ✨
Et dixerunt alii contrarium illius, scilicet quod Cauterium non est conueniens in aegritudine, quae est ex caliditate et siccitate: quoniam natura ignis est caliditas: et inconueniens est, ut sanetur ex agritudine calida et sicca, cum calido et sicco.	 And others said the opposite of this, namely that cautery is not suitable in an illness caused by heat and dryness; for the nature of fire is heat, and it is inconvenient to cure a hot and dry illness with heat and dryness.
Et dixit ille qui dicit contrarium illius: quod per Cauterium fit iuuamentum in omni aegritudine calida et sicca, quae accidit in corporibus hominum: quoniam quando tu comparas corpus hominis, et humiditates eius, ad complexionem ignis, inuenis corpus hominis frigidum.	 And he who speaks against this said that cautery is beneficial in every warm and dry illness that occurs in the human body; for when you compare the human body and its moistures to the complexion of fire, you find the human body to be cold.
Et ego quidem dico per sermonem eius: quia ex perimentum iam detexit mihi illud aliquotiens.	 And I say through his speech: for experiment has already revealed this to me many times.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut ueniat super illud, nisi qui iam probatus est, et exercitatus in capitulo Cauterii exercitio ultimo, et cognouit diuersitatem complexionum hominum, et dispositionem aegritudinum in se ipsis, et caussas earum, et accidentia ipsarum, et spacium temporis earum.	 However, it is not fitting that anyone should approach this unless he has already been tested and trained in the final exercise of the chapter on cautery, and has recognized the diversity of human complexions, and the nature of illnesses in themselves, and their causes, and their accidents, and their duration.
Ex reliquis autem complexionibus non est super uos timor: et praecipue in aegritudinibus frigidis et humidis.	 As for the other complexions, there is no need to fear; especially in cold and moist illnesses.
Iam enim conuenerunt omnes medici super eas: et non dissenserunt in iuuamento cum Cauterio in eis.	 For all physicians have agreed on these matters and have not disagreed with the use of cautery in them.
Et scitote filii, quod ex secreto curationis per Cauterium cum igne, et bonitate eius super Cauterium cum medicina comburente est: quoniam ignis est simplex, cuius actio non peruenit, nisi ad membrum quod cauterisatur: et non nocet membro alio coniuncto cum eo, nisi nocumento paruo.	 And know, my sons, that the secret of cure by means of a cautery with fire and its efficacy over a cautery with combustible medicine is that fire is simple, whose action does not extend except to the member that is cauterized; and it does no harm to another member joined with it, except for a slight injury. xspace
Medicinae uero comburentis actio peruenit ad illud quod elongatur ex membris: et fortasse facit accidere in membro aegritudinem difficilis sanationis, et fortasse interficit.	 But the action of combustible medicine reaches even what is remote from the members; and perhaps it causes illness of difficult cure in a member, and perhaps it kills.  xspace  xspace
Ignis autem propter subtilitatem suam et bonitatem substantiae suae, non facit illud, nisi superfluat.	 But fire, because of its subtlety and the goodness of its substance, does not do this except in excess.
Iam uero innotuit nobis illud per experimentum, propter longitudinem seruitutis et studii cum arte, et stationem super ueritatem rerum: et propter illud excusor a longitudine sermonis.	 Now indeed this has been made known to us through experience because of the length of our service and study in the art, and our dedication to the truth; and for that reason I am excused from prolonging the discussion.
Et si non esset, quia non licet huic libro meo, afferrem uobis secretum occultum in igne, et qualitatem operationis eius in corporibus expulsionis suae, qua expellit aegritudines sermone philosophico demonstratiuo, qui acueretur a mentibus uestris.	 And if it were not allowed to this book of mine, I would bring you the secret hidden in fire and the quality of its operation in bodies for the purpose of expelling illnesses, demonstrated by a persuasive philosophical speech that would be accepted by your minds.
Et scitote filii, quod ipsi dissentiunt in tempore, in quo conuenit fieri cauterium, et ponunt melius tempus ueris.	 And know, children, that they disagree about the time when it is best to perform cautery, and they say that spring is the better time.
Et ego dico, quod cauterium conuenit in omni tempore: propterea, quod nocumentum accidens propter tempus submergitur in iuuamento, quod attrahitur cum cauterio.	 And I say that cautery is appropriate at all times because the harm that occurs due to the time is overshadowed by the benefit that is drawn from the cautery.
Et praecipue si cauterium est propter dolores ex doloribus necessariis, fortibus, festinis, qui non tolerant tarditatem: propterea quod timetur ex eis, quod accidat malicia quae est maior, quam paruum nocumentum intrans propter tempus.	 And especially if the cautery is due to severe, urgent pains that do not tolerate delay; because it is feared from them that a worse outcome will occur than the slight harm caused by timing.
Et non cadat in mentibus uestris o filii illud, quod non extimant, nisi uulgus et stolidi medici, scilicet quod illi aegritudini quae sanatur per cauterium, non est reditio semper: et ponunt illud consequens, et res non est sicut putant: propterea quod cauterium non est, nisi loco medicinae, quae alterat complexionem, et exiccat humiditates quae sunt caussae, quare accidunt dolores.	 And do not let it enter your minds, O children, that only the ignorant and foolish physicians believe that the illness treated by cautery does not always recur; and they conclude this, but it is not as they think. Because cautery is nothing other than a remedy which alters the complexion and dries up the humors which are the cause of the pains.
Verumtamen cauterium superfluit super medicinam per uelocitatem ualetudinis suae, et uirtutem suae operationis, et uehementiam dominii sui: et possibile est, ut redeat aegritudo hora aliqua temporis secundum complexionem infirmi, et locationem aegritudinis suae, et uirtutem eius: et quod praeparatur in corpore eius ex aggregatione superfluitatum in eo: et quod peruenit ad ipsum in acquisitione sua ex cibis, et similibus illis ex caussis, nisi fit aegritudo, in qua administratur cauterium.	 However, cautery is superior to medicine because of its quick effectiveness, the power of its action, and the intensity of its control. And it is possible that the illness may return at some point in time according to the constitution of the patient, the nature of his illness, its strength, what is prepared in his body from the accumulation of superfluous matter, and what reaches him through food and similar causes, unless the illness for which cautery is applied is fatal.
Aegritudo subtilis in membro paucarum superfluitatum, et humiditatum, sicut cauterium dentis, propter dolorem, et similia illi, possibile est enim, ut non redeat in eo ille dolor.	 A subtle illness of a member with few superfluities and humors, such as tooth cautery for pain and similar conditions, it is possible that the pain may not return.
Sed illud fit in paucis.	 "But that occurs rarely.
At uero sermo uulgi iterum, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, est sermo rectus: non ad illud quod ipsi intendunt in illo: quoniam ipsi credunt, quod non est curatio quae conferat cum medicina, neque cum alio post occasum cauterii.	 But the common saying again is true, that cautery is the last resort of medicine; and their intention is not as they themselves intend in it, for they believe that no treatment can be applied together with medicine after the effect of cautery.
Res autem est econtrario illius, et intentio, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, non est, nisi quod quando nos administramus modos curationis in aliqua aegritudinum, et non conferunt illae medicinae: deinde administramus in fine rei cauterium, et confert: tunc inde cadit, quod cauterium est postremum mediciuae, non secundum intentionem quam intelligunt uulgus et multistolidorum medicorum.	 But the truth is contrary to that saying, and the meaning, that cautery is the last resort of medicine, does not exist except in this sense: when we administer treatment methods for some diseases and they do not help, then at the end we apply cautery, and it helps; thus it follows that cautery is the last resort of medicine, not according to the intention that the common people and many stupid physicians understand.
Antiqui autem dixerunt, quod cauterium cum auro est melius, quam cauterium cum ferro: et non dixerunt illud, nisi propter aequalitatem auri, et sublimitatem substantiae suae: et dixerunt, quod non facit pus locus cauterii.	 The ancients said that cautery with gold is better than cautery with iron; and they did not say this except because of the balance of gold and the nobility of its substance; and they said that cautery does not cause suppuration in the place where it is applied.
Verum non est illud absolute: quoniam ego iam probaui illud, et inueni, quod ipsum non facit illud in quibusdam corporibus absque aliis.	 However, that is not absolutely true; for I have already tested it and found that cautery itself does not do this in some bodies without other factors involved.
Et cauterium cum ipso est bonum, et melius quam cum ferro, sicut dixerunt.	 And cautery with gold is good, and better than with iron, as they said.
Verumtamen quando tu ignis cauterium in igne ex auro, non declaratur tibi, quando ignitur secundum quantitatem quam uis, propter rubedinem auri: et quando properat ad ipsum frigus, et si addis super ipsum ignitionem, liquescit in igne, et uertitur in laminas.	 Nevertheless, when you cauterize with fire from gold, the fire does not show you when it is ignited to the degree that you wish, because of the redness of the gold; and when it quickly turns cold, if you add more fire upon it, it melts in the fire and turns into plates.
Quare cadit artifex ex illo in occupationem: et propter illud fit Cauterium cum ferro apud nos uelocius et propinquius, ex rectitudine ad operationem.	 Therefore, the craftsman falls short in that respect; and because of this, cautery with iron is faster and more convenient for us, in terms of correct practice.
Et ego quidem iam ordinaui hoc Capitulum in Cauterio, secundum capitula: et ordinaui ea a capite usque ad pedes: ut alleuient quaerenti illud quod uult ex eo.	 And I have indeed already arranged this chapter on cautery according to chapters, and I have arranged them from head to foot, so that those who seek it may find what they want from it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Caput in commissura coronali.	 "On the method of cauterizing the head at the coronal suture.
Caput II.	 "Chapter II.
Confert hic cauterizatio ad dominium humiditatis et frigiditatis super cerebrum: quae duae sunt caussae sodae, et multitudinis fluxus humorum ex capite ad partes oculorum et aurium, et multitudinis somni, et doloris dentium, et doloris gutturis: et uniuersaliter omnis aegritudinis, quae accidit ex frigiditate, sicut paralisis, et sodae, epilepsiae, et apoplexiae, et similia illis ex aegritudinibus.	 "This cauterization is beneficial for controlling moisture and cold on the brain: these two conditions are causes of headaches, excessive flow of humors from the head to the eyes and ears, excess sleep, toothache, throat pain, and universally all illnesses arising from coldness, such as paralysis, headaches, epilepsy, apoplexy, and similar diseases.
Modus cauterizationis est, ut praecipias infirmo: ut euacuetur in primis cum medicina solutiua mundificante caput tribus noctibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod exigit uirtus infirmi, et eius aetas, et consuetudo eius.	 "The method of cauterization is that you instruct the patient to first empty the head for three or four nights with cleansing medicine, according to the strength of the patient, age, and habit.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radi faciat caput suum cum nouacula.	 "Then instruct him to shave his head with a razor.
Deinde fac eum sedere inter manus tuas quadratum, ita quod iam posuit manus suas super pectus suum.	 "Then have him sit upright between your hands, placing his own hands on his chest.
Deinde pone radicem palmae tuae super radicem nasi sui inter oculos suos.	 "Then place the base of your palm on the base of his nose between his eyes.
Vbicumque ergo peruenerit digitus tuus medius, signa locum illum cum incausto.	 "Wherever your middle finger reaches, mark that spot with ink.
Deinde igni Cauterium Oliuare: cuius haec est forma.	 "Then heat the cautery in oil. This is its shape.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum signatum cum incausto, descensione, qua constringatur manus tua paulatim, et tu reuolues ipsum.	 "Then place it on the marked spot with ink. Gradually lower your hand to press it firmly and rotate it.
Deinde leua manum tuam uelociter, et aspicias locum.	 "Then quickly lift your hand and examine the spot.
Quod si uides iam detegi ex osse quantitatem capitis alkiel, aut quantitatem zeuherbi, tunc eleua manum tuam.	 "If you see that the area as large as a lentil or a grain of barley has been exposed from the bone, then lift your hand.
Et si non, itera manum tuam ferro ipso, aut cum alio ab ipso si infrigidatur: donec uideantur ossa, quae dixi tibi.	 "And if not, repeat the process with the same iron or another if it cools, until you see the bone as I have told you.
Deinde sume aliquid ex sale, et solue illud in aqua, et imbibe in ipso cotum, et pone super locum: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	 "Then take some salt, dissolve it in water, and soak a cloth in the solution. Place the cloth on the spot and leave it for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, et dimitte illum super locum, donec destruatur eschara ignis.	 Then place a piece of cloth soaked in butter over it and leave it there until the fire burn is destroyed.
Deinde cura illud cum unguento tetrapharmacon, usquequo sanetur.	 Then care for it with tetrapharmacon ointment until it heals.
Iam dixerunt, quod quanto uulnus plus remanet apertum, emittit pus: quare est melius et magis iuuatiuum.	 Now they say that the more a wound remains open, the more pus it sends out; therefore it is better and more beneficial.
Et dixerunt quidam eorum, ut cauterizetur cutis usque ad os: et teneatur Cauterium, donec aduratur quiddam spissitudinis ossis.	 And some of them said that the skin should be cauterized to the bone, and that the cautery should be held until a thick part of the bone is burned.
Deinde radatur post illud quod adustum est ex osse, deinde curetur.	 Then that part which has been burnt from the bone is scraped away, then it is cleaned out.
Et dicunt alii, quod oportet ut cum cauterio perueniatur ad ultimum, donec imprimat in os impressionem for tem, ita quod cadat os, quod fit sicut forma kirate: aut instrumentum quod mulieres ponunt infuso alphabeti parui: et extimant, quod exspirantur ex hoc loco uapores capitis, et dimittatur uulnus apertum tempore longo.	 And others say that it is necessary to go with the cautery to the very end, until it makes an imprint in the bone like a tem, so that the bone falls away; this happens just as if one were using a kirate or the instrument which women put into alphabet infusions. And they believe that from this place the vapors of the head are expelled and the wound is left open for a long time.
Deinde curetur, donec consolidetur.	 Then it should be cleaned out until it heals over.
Mihi autem non uidentur hae duae species Cauterii omnino nisi in quibusdam hominibus secundum uiam timoris.	 But these two types of cautery do not seem to me to be suitable except in some people according to the way of fear.
Et dimittere ipsum, apud me est melius cum salute ipsius.	 And to let it go is, in my opinion, better for the patient's health.
Debilitatur enim caput ex solutione continuitatis ipsius naturalis: sicut testificati sumus in reliquis membris: et praecipue quando caput infirmi debile est natura: et species quidem Cauterii prima est magis salua et melior apud me, et ea utor: operare ergo cum ea in salute.	 For the head is weakened by the dissolution of its natural continuity, as we have shown with other members; and especially when the head of the patient is naturally weak. The first type of cautery is safer and better in my opinion, and that is what I use. So, work with it for the sake of health.
¶ De modo cauterizandi capitis in dolore totius capitis.	 ¶ On how to cauterize the head for pain throughout the entire head.
Caput III.	 Chapter III
Quando in toto Capite accidit dolor chronicus: et prolongatur illud in infirmo, et utitur hyeris, et cochiis, et caputpurgiis, et oleis, et empleumatis.	 When chronic and persistent pain occurs throughout the entire head, and the patient uses syrups, powders, purges, oils, and fumigations.
Et praecipue si iam cauterizatum est cauterio uno, quod narrauimus, et non confert ei aliquid ex illis: tunc considera.	 And especially if it has already been cauterized with that one-pronged iron I mentioned, and nothing else helps: then consider.
Nam si caput infirmi est fortis creationis natura, et non est debile, et inuenit frigus uehemens: tunc cauteriza cum cauterio alio sub illo parum.	 For if the head of the sick person is of strong and robust nature, not weak, and he finds extreme cold: then cauterize him with a different iron under that one.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio, do nec pertranseat cutis, et discooperiatur ex osse quantitas, quam narrauimus.	 Then cauterize him over every horn of his head with the iron, so that it does not pierce the skin, and expose the amount of bone I mentioned.
Et cauteriza ipsum cauterio uno in occipitio capitis sui, in loco qui nominatur uas: et est locus in quo ponitur uentosa: et eleua matum tuam in hoc, et non discooperias os.	 And cauterize him with a single iron on the back of his head at a place called 'uas', which is the location where the windpipe is placed. Raise your hand in this manner, and you will not expose bone.
Infirmus enim inuenit propter illud dolorem uehementem, et diuersum a dolore reliquorum cauteriorum capitis omnium.	 For the sick person finds on account of this an intense pain, and different from the pain of all other head cauteries.
Et ego dicam hoc Cauterium in loco suo: et oportet quod sit cauterium, quo cauterizantur cornua capitis, et occiput eius subtilius cauterio, quo cauterizatur medium capitis.	 And I call this the Cautery in its place. And it is necessary that it be a finer iron than the one used to cauterize the horns of the head and the back of the head.
Et haec est forma eius.	 And this is its shape.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in hemicrania, tam cum medicina adustiua, quam cum ferro.	 ¶ On the method of cauterizing for headache, both with burnt medicine and with iron.
Caput IIII.	 Chapter IV.
Quando accidit in parte capitis dolor et soda, aut extenditur dolor usque ad oculum, et euacuatur cum medicinis mundificantibus caput, et administratur reliqua curatio, quam dixi in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert illud totum: tunc cauterizatio in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterizatio cum medicina acuta comburente: aut cum ferro.	 When pain and headache occur in any part of the head, or when the pain extends to the eye and is evacuated with purifying medications, and the rest of the treatment is administered as I mentioned in the divisions of illnesses, but it does not help entirely, then there are two ways to cauterize: either with a sharp burning medicine or with iron. ︎
Cauterium autem cum medicina acuta comburente, est, ut accipias dentem unum allii, et excortices ipsum, et abscindas extremitates eius ex duobus lateribus.	 Now, to cauterize with a sharp burning medicine, take one clove of garlic and peel it, then cut off its ends from both sides.
Deinde scinde locum doloris in tempore cum phlebotomo lato, donec fiat in eo locus sub cute, in quo dens capitur.	 Then divide the place of pain with a broad lancet, until there is a space under the skin where the tooth can be placed. ︎
Intromitte ergo eum in ipso sub cute, donec occultetur: deinde stringe super ipsum cum puluillo constrictione decenti, et dimitte ipsum quantitate quindecim horarum deinde solue eum, et extrahe allium, et dimitteuulnus duobus diebus, aut tribus: postea pone super ipsum cotum submersum in butyro, donec locus efficiat pus: deinde cura ipsum cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	 Insert it under the skin until it is hidden; then bind it with a suitable bandage above. Leave it for fifteen hours, then remove it and extract the garlic. Leave the wound open for two or three days; afterwards place a pledget soaked in butter over the wound until pus forms; then treat it with an ointment until it heals.
Et si uis fac illud cum quibusdam medicinis comburentibus, quas ego scripsi in tractatu duodecimo, de Medieinis adurentibus.	 And if you wish, make this preparation with some of the warming medicines that I have written about in chapter twelve on heating medicines.
Cauterizatio uero eius cum ferro, est secundum hunc modum.	 To cauterize it with iron is done as follows:
Igni Cauterium, cuius forma haec est.	 The fire brand, which looks like this.
Et nominatur Clauilis: quoniam forma capitis eius est sicut forma claui, in quo est quiddam curuitatis, et in medio eius est quaedam eminentia parua.	 And it is called a "Claw"; because the head of it resembles the shape of a nail with some curvature, and in its middle there is a small projection.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum, et retine manum tuam: et tu reuolue ferrum paulatim cum uelocitate: et sit quantitas quae aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, sicut medietas eius.	 Then place it on the wound and hold your hand firmly; and slowly rotate the iron with speed; and let the amount that is burned be half the thickness of the skin.
Et eleua manum tuam, ut non aduratur arteria, quae est inferius, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	 And raise your hand so that the vein underneath is not burned and bleeding occurs.
Deinde imbibe cotum in aqua salis, et pone super locum, et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus: deinde pone cotum cum butyro: postea cura cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	 Then soak a pledget in salt water and place it on the wound and leave it for three days; then place a pledget with butter; afterwards treat it with an ointment until it heals. ︎
Et si uis, cauteriza hanc hemicraniam cum extremitate cultellari secunda Cauterii.	 And if you wish, cauterize this half-head wound with the pointed end of a second cautery.
Et caue ab incisione arteriae in hac hemicrania, non antiqua proprie.	 And be careful not to cut an artery in this half-skull, unless it is necessary. ︎
¶ De modo cauteriezandi in hemicrania antiqua.	 ¶ On the method of cauterizing in old half-skulls.
Caput V.	 Chapter Five
Quando curas hemicraniam, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione praecedente, et quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio: et uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei quod diximus ex cauterio primo cum medicina, aut cum cauterio cum igne, tunc oportet ut ignias Cauterium cultellare, donec albificetur postquam signas super locum doloris cum linea, cuius longitudo sit medietas digiti, aut quasi illud: et depone manum tuam uice una, et stringe eam donec incidas arteriam, et peruenias usque ad os.	 When you are treating half-skull with what we have said in the preceding treatment and in the divisions of diseases, and it does not heal; and you see from the disease that what we have said about cautery with medicine or with a heated iron is not enough, then you should heat a pointed cautery until it whitens after marking the place of pain with a line whose length is half a finger or similar to that; and raise your hand once, and bind it until you cut the artery and reach the bone.
Verumtamen necesse est tibi, ut caueas a continuatione mandibulae, quae mouetur apud masticationem, ne aduratur latus, aut neruus qui mouet ipsam, unde accidat spasmus.	 But you must be careful not to burn the side or the nerve that moves the jaw during chewing, lest a spasm occur.
Et esto super custotiam, et cautelam de fluxu sanguinis arteriae, quae abscisa est.	 And be on guard against the flow of blood from the cut artery.
In abscisione enim eius est timor, et praecipue ei qui ignorat illud quod facit, et non est studiosus, nec expertus: et dimittit operationem cum eo in primis.	 For its incision is dangerous, especially for one who is ignorant of what he does, unstudious, and inexperienced; and he leaves off the operation with that in particular.
Et ego ueniam cum rememoratione regiminis fluxus sanguinis accidentis ex arteria secundum modum suum, et in loco suo huius libri.	 And I shall pardon myself by remembering to give rules for stopping the flow of blood from an artery according to its manner and in the proper place in this book.
Quod si uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei hoc Cauterium, et uides corpus infirmi tolerans cauterium in medio capitis, sicut narrauimus, cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	 But if you see from the illness that this cautery is not enough, and you see the patient's body tolerating a cautery on the middle of the head, as we have said, care for the wound until it heals.
Et si uis, administra Cauterium, quod diximus in capitulo extractionis arteriae cum Cauterio habente duos cultellos.	 And if you wish, administer the cautery that we have mentioned in the chapter on extracting an artery with a two-bladed knife.  />
Est enim cauterizatio melior hac et magis conferens.	 For this cautery is better and more beneficial than that one.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Aurium.	 ¶ On the method of cauterizing for earache.
Caput VI.	 Chapter Six
Quando accidit in Aure dolor a frigore, et curatur cum solutiuis, et reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione, et non remouetur dolor, tunc igni Cauterium: et est illud quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma est haec.	 When earache occurs from cold and is treated with solutions and other methods of treatment as we have said in the division, but the pain is not removed, then use fire for cautery; and this is what is called a "Puncture," the form of which is as follows:  />  >
Deinde puncta cum eo post eius ignitionem in circumitu auris totius, sicut reuoluitur: aut in circumitu utriusque, si simul dolor est in utrisque.	 Then, after it is heated by fire, make punctures with it around the entire ear, as shown here: or around both ears if the pain is in both at the same time.
Et elonga te cum Cauterio a radice auris parumper, postquam signaueris loca cum encaustro: et sit cauterii quantitas decem punctorum in omni aure, et quasi illa.	 And keep the cautery a short distance from the root of the ear after marking the places with the iron: and let there be ten punctures on each ear, as shown here.
Deinde cura loca, donec sanentur.	 Then care for the places until they heal.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tortura.	 In the way of cauterizing in Torture.
Caput VII.	 Chapter VII.
Tortura quae curatur cum cauterizatione, non est nisi ex speciebus, quae accidunt ex phlegmate, secundum quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum.	 The torture that is treated with cauterization is not anything other than the types which occur from phlegm, as we have said in the divisions of diseases.
Et deuita cauterizationem speciei, quae accidit ex exiccatione, et spasmo nerui.	 And avoid cauterizing the type that occurs from dryness and nerve spasm.
Quando curas hanc speciem torturae cum hyeris, et caputpurgiis, et gargarismis, et non confert curatio tua, tunc oportet ut cauterizes infirmum tribus Cauteriis: uno apud radicem auris, et secundo parum inferius a timpore suo, et tertio apud coniunctionem duorum labiorum.	 When you treat this type of torture with medicines, purgatives, gargles, and your treatment does not help, then it is necessary to cauterize the patient with three cauteries: one at the root of the ear, another a little below its tympanum, and the third at the junction of the two lips.
Et pone Cauterium tuum ex contrario partis infirmae.	 And place your cautery on the opposite side of the diseased part.
Quoniam mollificatio non accidit, nisi in parte quae apparet sana.	 Because softening does not occur except in the part that appears healthy.
Et forma cauterizationis est, ut cauterizes ipsum Cauterio in directo extremitatis auris superioris sub cornu capitis parum: et alio in timpore: cuius longitudo sit secundum longitudinem pollicis.	 And the manner of cauterization is that you cauterize it with a cautery directly at the tip of the upper ear, a little under the horn of the head: and another one on the tympanum, whose length should be according to the length of the thumb.
Et depone manum tuam cum cauterio, donec comburatur quantitas medietatis spissitudinis cutis.	 And place your hand with the cautery until the amount equivalent to half the thickness of the skin is burned.  /> Si quis non est prudens in hac arte, vide ne uelimus, ne uideantur perforationes in ea parte.
Et haec est forma Cauterii, et est species ex cultellari, cuius forma praemissa est: uerumtamen non est subtilior ea parum, sicut uides: et oportet ut sit cultellus in eo superfluae grossitudinis parum.	 And this is the form of the cautery, and it is a species made from an old knife, whose form has been mentioned above; however, it is not a little subtler than what you see: and it is necessary that there be a little excess in the thickness of the knife.
Deinde cura loca, cum eo quod praecessit: donec sanetur.	 Then treat the places with what was mentioned previously until they heal.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Apoplexia antiqua.	 ¶ On the method of cauterizing for old apoplexy.
Caput VIII.	 Chapter VIII.
QUando antiquatur Apoplexia, et curas eam cum eo quod diximus, et non confert medicatio tua, et infirmus non habet febrem, tunc cauteriza eum quatuor cauteriis super omne cornu capitis sui, et cauterio in medio capitis, sicut diximus, et cauterio in occipitio capitis, secundum quod praecessit: et modus cauterii sit secundum quod praecessit.	 When apoplexy becomes chronic and you treat it with what we have mentioned, and your treatment does not help, and the patient has no fever, then cauterize him with four cauteries on every horn of his head, and a cautery in the middle of the head as we said, and a cautery at the back of the head, as previously stated; and let the manner of the cautery be as previously mentioned.  /> Et si fuerit in infirmo fomes, nequeas curare eum: sed poteris curare eum cum cauteriis, et praedicta medicamenta, secundum quod diximus, et si non sanabitur nisi uerecundia tua in deum.
Etiam cauterizatur cum Cauterio super os stomachi: et est magis ultimum.	 And it is also cauterized with a cautery over the mouth of the stomach; and it is more ultimate.
Deinde curetur, cum eo quod praecessit.	 Then it should be scraped, along with what has preceded.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Obliuione.	 On the Method of Cauterization for Forgetfulness.
Caput IX.	 Chapter IX.
Oportet ut in potu dentur in primis infirmo hyerae magnae, et pillulae mundificantes cerebrum.	 It is necessary that in the first place large henbane seeds and purifying pills for the brain be given to the patient to drink.
Deinde rade caput infirmi totum, et pone super occipitium eius emplastrum de synapi descriptum in tractatu emplastrorum: et pone ipsum aliquotiens.	 Then shave the entire head of the patient and place on his occiput a plaster made from mustard, as described in the treatise on plasters; and apply it several times.
Ipsum namque est modus Cauterii: et fac illud secundum ordinem eundem, quem dixi illic.	 For this is the method of cautery; and do it in the same way as I have said there.
Si ergo sanatur per illud, bonum est.	 If therefore he is cured by that, it is good.
Si non: tunc fac ei cauteria tria in posteriori parte capitis sui, quae sint descendentia a superiori parte capitis usque ad inferiorem partem oculi: et pone inter omne cauterium grossitudinem digiti.	 If not, then make three cauteries on the back of his head, which should descend from the upper part of the head to the lower part of the eye; and put the width of a finger between each cautery.
Deinde cura Cauterium, cum eo quod praecessit.	 Then treat the cauteries as described above.
Si autem uis additionem, et infirmus est tolerans illud: tunc fac ei Cauterium in medio.	 If you wish to add more and the patient is able to bear it, then make a cautery in the middle.
Quod si uis additionem: tunc cauteriza ipsum super duo cornua.	 If you wish to add more, then cauterize him over both temples.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: sitque Cauterium oliuare secundum formam, quae praemissa est.	 Then treat the patient until he is cured; and let the cautery be oiled according to the shape described above.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Paralisi, et mollificatione.	 On the Method of Cauterization for Paralysis and Softening.
Caput X.	 Chapter X.
Oportet ut procedas in mundificatione capitis cum hyeeris, et cum eo quod diximus.	 It is necessary that you proceed with the purification of the head using henbane and as we have said.  /> ¶ Et sit haec modus Cauterii.
Deinde rade caput infirmi: postea cauteriza ipsum cauterio in medio capitis, et cauterio super omne cornu capitis, et cauterio super posterius ipsius, et tribus super spondiles colli.	 Then shave the patient's head. After that, cauterize him with a cautery in the middle of his head, and with a cautery over each temple, and with a cautery on the back of his head, and with three cauteries on the vertebrae of his neck.  /> Et si fuerit necesse: tunc fac ei cauteria quatuor ad uires eius, et sit illud in capite, et inter oculos, et in medio colli, et in medio thoracis.
Si autem indiges in aegritudine mollificatione corporis pluribus illis, et infirmus est tolerans, et aegritudo est fortis: tunc cauteriza ipsum quatuor cauteriis super spondiles dorsi, et ultima cum cauterio, donec comburatur ex cute plurimum eius, et eleua manum tuam.	 If however you need to soothe the body with many of those during illness, and if the patient is weak and the disease is strong: then cauterize him with four cauteries on the vertebrae of the back, and with the last cautery until most of the skin is burned off, and lift your hand.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: et sic cauterium Oliuare.	 Then care for him until he heals; and thus ends the section on cauterization.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Epilepsia.	 On the manner of cauterizing in epilepsy.
Caput XI.	 Chapter XI.
Non Cauterizatur epilepticus, nisi ille cuius epilepsia est ex phlegmate.	 An epileptic is not to be cauterized unless his epilepsy is due to phlegm.
Oportet ergo ut mundifices cerebrum eius in primis cum hyeris, et cum reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione: quando infirmus est magnus, aut est tolerans in accaeptione medicinarum.	 Therefore, it is necessary that you cleanse his brain first with cupping glasses and with the rest of the treatment which we have said in the division, when the patient is large or can tolerate the taking of medicines.
Si autem est puer, qui non tolerat medicinas, tunc administratur gargarisma, et masticationes mundificantes cerebrum, ante illud diebus multis cum bonificatione ciborum.	 But if he is a child who cannot tolerate medicines, then let him be given gargles and cleansing foods to chew for many days before that, with the improvement of his diet.
Deinde rade caput eius, postea cauteriza ipsum Cauterio uno in medio capitis, secundum quod praecessit in modo: et cauterio alio in occipitio eius, et super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio.	 Then shave his head; afterward cauterize him with one cautery in the middle of his head, according to what was said before about the manner; and with another cautery on the back of his head, and over each horn of his head with a cautery.
Quod si infirmus fuerit fortis, et fuerit tolerans, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauteriis, quae dixi in habente paralisim, et mollificationem corporis super spondiles colli, et spondiles dorsi: et sit Cauterium oliuare secundum modum qui praecessit.	 But if the patient is strong and can tolerate it, then cauterize him with the cauteries which I mentioned for those with paralysis, and to soothe the body on the vertebrae of the neck and back: and let the final cautery be according to the manner which was said before. 》
Si autem infirmus est puer, tunc pone cauterium subtile, secundum hunc modum.	 But if the patient is a child, then place a fine cautery accordingly.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Melancholia.	 On the manner of cauterizing in melancholy. 》 》
Caput XII.	 Chapter XII.
Quando caussa melancholiae sunt humiditates corruptae, et phlegma grossum, tunc cauteriza ipsum Cauteriis, quae diximus in habente paralisim.	 When the cause of melancholy is corrupted moisture and thick phlegm, then cauterize him with the cauteries which we mentioned for those with paralysis.
Et si caussa melancholiae est superfluitas decliuis ad melancholiam, et est corpus infirmi humectum, tunc da ei in potu quod mundificet cerebrum eius, secundum quod praecessit in diuisione: deinde rade caput infirmi, et fac postea tortellam decenter factam ex lino, sicut circulum.	 And if the cause of melancholy is an excess of black bile towards melancholy, and the body of the sick person is moist, then give him to drink that which cleanses his brain, according to what preceded in the division: then shave the head of the sick person, and afterwards make a neatly made tortilla from linen, like a circle.
Deinde pone ipsam in medio capitis: et infirmus sedens quadratus teneatur ab omni parte.	 Then place it in the middle of the head; and let the sick person, sitting square, be held on every side.
Deinde praesenta linimentum.	 Then present a poultice.
Et est dignius ex butyro ouium antiquo.	 And it is more suitable from old ewe's butter.
Et calefac ipsum super ignem calefactione temperata mensura, quam toleret digitus, quando intromittitur in ipsum.	 And heat it over a fire with a moderate amount of warmth, so that when the finger is inserted into it, it may bear it.
Deinde euacua ipsum in medio capitis eius in circulo, et dimitte ipsum donec infrigidetur.	 Then evacuate it onto the middle of his head in a circle, and leave it until it cools.  />  Et quando frigida facta est, tollens illud de capite infirmi, fac quod uelis.
Fac illud infirmo omni hebdomada semel, cum reliquo regimine eius bono, donec sanetur.	 Do this for the sick person once a week with the rest of his good regime until he is cured.
Aut si uis, cauteriza ipsum faciendo puncta parua plurimum eius, praeter quod teneas manum cum cauterio: imo sit odorando.	 Or if you wish, cauterize it by making many small punctures, except that you hold the hand with the cautery; rather let it be fragrant.
Haec enim species cauterii humectat cerebrum cum qualitate.	 For this kind of cautery moistens the brain with its quality.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, aut adipe gallinae.	 Then place upon it a cloth soaked in butter or chicken fat.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aqua descendente ad oculum.	 ¶ On the method of cauterizing with water dripping into the eye.
Caput XIII.	 Chapter 13.
Quando declaratur tibi principium aquae in oculo per signa, quae dixi in diuisione, tunc incipe et pota infirmum, cum eo quod mundificet caput eius.	 When the beginning of water in the eye is declared to you by the signs that I have mentioned in the division, then begin and give the sick person to drink that which cleanses his head.
Et custodi ipsum ab omnibus humiditatibus, et fac eum sedere in balneo, in ieiunio diebus aliquot.	 And keep him away from all moist things, and make him sit in a bathhouse in fasting for several days.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radat caput suum, et cauteriza ipsum in medio capitis sui.	 Then instruct him to shave his head, and cauterize it in the middle of his head.  />  Et sit hoc in diebus plurimis: et postea fac eum radere caput suum.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super duo timpora duobus cauteriis, si est incaeptio descensus aquae in duobus oculis simul: aut ex latere uno, si est incaeptio aquae in oculo uno: et abscinde cum cauterio omnes uenas et arterias quae sunt sub cute: et sint cauteria in ea longa in latitudine timporum: et caue a fluxu sanguinis.	 Then burn the patient above both temples with two irons, if the water flow is beginning simultaneously in both eyes; or from one side only, if the flow is starting in one eye. And cut off with an iron all veins and arteries that are under the skin: and let the cauteries be long in the breadth of the temples; and take care to prevent the flow of blood.
Quod si uides aliquid ex eo, tunc abscinde eum statim cum quacumque medicina est possibile: et ego ueniam cum sapientia, quae est in extractione arteriarum, et abscisione earum, et cautela a fluxu sanguinis.	 If you see anything from it, then cut it off immediately with whatever medicine is possible; and I will come with the wisdom which is in the extraction of arteries, and their cutting, and care to prevent the flow of blood.
Et quandoque cauterizatur in ceruice, sub duobus ossibus, duobus cauteriis ultime productis.	 And sometimes it should be burned on the neck under two bones with two irons fully extended.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lachrymis antiquis.	 ¶ On the method of burning away old tears.
Caput XIIII.	 Chapter XIV
Quando lachrymae oculorum sunt antiquae, assiduae: et sunt super uenas, et arterias quae sunt in manifesto capitis exterius, uerificatur quod illud est ex superfluitatibus frigidis, phlegmaticis: tunc cauteriza cauterio eodem quod narraui in incaeptione aquae descendentis, cauterio in medio capitis, et duobus cauteriis super duo timpora, et duobus cauteriis in ceruice sub duobus ossibus.	 When the tears of the eyes are old and persistent, and they are over the veins and arteries which are evident on the outer surface of the head, it is verified that this comes from cold, phlegmatic excesses; then burn with the same iron as I described in the case of water starting to flow, with one iron in the middle of the head, and two irons over both temples, and two irons on the neck under two bones.
Et si indiges additione, tunc cauteriza ipsum in omni latere caute oculi, super extremitatem supercilii cum cauterio paruo.	 And if you need to add more, then burn the patient carefully on every side of the eye, at the outer edge of the eyebrow with a small iron.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in foetore Nasi.	 ¶ On the method of burning away nasal odor.
Caput XV.	 Chapter XV
Quando tu medicaris illud, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert medicatio: tunc propera, et da in potu infirmocochias tribus noctibus: deinde rade caput eius, et cauteriza ipsum cauterio medio, cum cauterio oliuari.	 When you are treating this condition with the method we mentioned in division, and it does not benefit from treatment; then hurry up and give infirmocochias to drink for three nights: then shave his head, and burn him with a medium-sized iron and an olive oil cautery.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio clauili duobus cauteriis, super duo supercilia sub capillis parum.	 Then burn the patient with two small irons over both eyebrows under the hair.
Et custodite ab arteria, ne incidas eam.	 And be careful not to cut the artery.
Et haec est forma cauterii Clauilis.	 And this is the shape of the cupping glass.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in mollificatione Palpebrae.	 In the manner of cauterizing for the softening of the eyelid.
Caput XVI.	 Chapter 16.
Quando mollificatur Palpebra oculi ab aegritudine, aut humiditate: tunc cauteriza Palpebram cauterio uno, cum hoc cauterio lunari.	 When the eyelid of the eye is softened by illness or moisture, then cauterize the eyelid with one cautery, and this lunar cautery.
Et si uis, cauteriza ipsum supra duo supercilia parum duobus cauteriis in omni parte: et elongentur a duobus timporibus: et sit longitudo omnis cauterii, secundum longitudines supercilii: et non ultimes manum tuam cum cauterio, imo secundum quantitatem quod aduritur tertia palpebrae.	 And if you wish, cauterize [the area] above the two eyebrows a little with two cauteries on every side, and let them be distant from the two temples; and let the length of every cautery be according to the length of the eyebrow, and do not touch with your hand the cautery, but according to the amount that the third eyelid is burnt.
Et haec est forma cauterii secundum hunc modum cauterii lunaris.	 And this is the shape of the cautery in this manner of the lunar cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Palpebram cum pili inuersantur pungentes oculum.	 In the manner of cauterizing the eyelid when the hairs turn in and prick the eye. )))
Caput XVII.	 Chapter 17.
Cauterium in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum igne: aut cauterium cum medicina comburente.	 There are two ways to cauterize it: either with a hot iron, or with a burning medicine.
In cauterio autem cum igne, praecipe infirmo ante illud, ut dimittat pilos suos, si est ex illis qui mundant eos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	 But in the case of the hot iron, tell the patient beforehand to let his hairs grow, if he is one of those who plucks them out, until they lengthen and become even. ))) ))) ))) )))
Si autem pungunt eum apud ortum suum: tunc constringe oculos eius cum uitta, ut non moueantur, donec nascantur.	 But if they prick him at their origin, then bind his eyes with a bandage, so that they do not move, until they are born. )))
Cum ergo nascuntur et aequantur, tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo: deinde signa super Palpebram oculorum eius cum encaustro, signo quod sit secundum figuram folii myrti: et sit principium signi prope pilos.	 When they are born and become even, then put the patient's head in your lap; then mark on his eyelid with caustic, a mark that should be like the shape of a myrtle leaf; and let the beginning of the mark be near the hairs.
Deinde pone cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum.	 Then place a cloth soaked in egg white, or in slippery elm mucilage, over the eye.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	 Then, for the cautery iron, which looks like this.
Deinde cauteriza super figuram, quam signasti paulatim in uicibus multis, donec comburatur superficies cutis, quae est sicut figura folii myrti, totam apparentem proprie.	 Then cauterize over the figure which you have marked little by little in several places, until the surface of the skin, which is like a myrtle leaf, is entirely burned and appears properly.
Et signum sanitatis operis tui est: ut si uideas Palpebram oculi iam contrahi, et pilos eleuari apud puncturam oculi.	 And the sign of health in your work is that if you see the eyelid already contracting and the hairs rising at the point of the eye.
Eleua ergo manum tuam tunc: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	 Then raise your hand (i.e., stop treating): and leave him for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur eschara.	 Then put on him cotton with butter, until the scab is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	 Then treat him with ointment, until he heals.
Quod si redeat aliquod ex pilis post horam, et mollificetur palpebra: tunc itera Cauterium super illum locum, sicut fecisti in primis.	 If any of the hairs returns after an hour and the eyelid softens, then repeat the cautery on that spot as you did at first.
Si autem pili sunt in inferiori: tunc cauteriza ipsam, donec eleuetur ad locum suum naturalem: et aequetur ut non pungant pili oculum.	 If however the hairs are on the lower (eyelid), then cauterize it until it rises to its natural place and is even so that the hairs do not prick the eye.
¶ De modo cauterizandi cum medicina comburente in eodem casu.	 ¶ On the method of cauterizing with a burning medicine in this case.
Caput XVIII.	 Chapter XVIII.
Est ut praecipias infirmo, ut dimittat pilos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	 It is that you advise the patient to let the hairs grow until they lengthen and even out. ︎
Fac ex charta de panno formam folii myrti.	 Make from a piece of cloth the shape of a myrtle leaf.
Deinde accipe ex sapone cognito, et ex calce non imbibita ex unoquoque pondus uncia I aut quasi illud: deinde tere ea simul contritione bona, et fac illud cum festinatione, ut non infrigidetur.	 Then take from known soap and from unslaked lime one ounce each or so: then grind them together well until you make that quickly, so it does not cool down.
Deinde ex pande ex eo super chartam quam fecisti sicut formam folii myrti, et pone ipsum super palpebram oculi unius, aut duorum.	 Then spread it over the shape of the myrtle leaf that you have made on the cloth, and place it on the eyelid of one or two eyes. ︎
Et pone sub oculo cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: et caput infirmi sit in sinu tuo.	 And put under the eye cotton soaked in egg white; and let the patient's head be in your lap.
Et pone digitum tuum indicem super medicinam, et preme ipsum parumper.	 And put your index finger on the medicine, and press it slightly.
Et tu moueas ipsum quotiens sentit infirmus mordicationem medicinae: quoniam inuenit eius mordicatio sicut ignis.	 And you shall move it whenever the sick person feels the biting of the medicine, for its biting is like fire.
Dum ergo perseuerat hoc quod ipse inuenit mordicatio, tunc dimitte medicinam, et moue ipsam cum digito tuo.	 Therefore, while this biting that he has found persists, then leave off the medicine and move it with your finger.
Cum ergo quiescit mordicatio, tunc remoue medicinam, et ablue oculum cum aqua.	 When therefore the biting ceases, then remove the medicine and wash the eye with water.
Et considera tunc, si uides palpebram eleuari, sicut eleuatur apud contractionem cum igne, aut cum incisione, est bene: et si non, tunc itera super ipsam ex medicina super locum, in quo non imprimit medicina, et non denigrat, donec aequetur operatio tua, et contrahatur oculus.	 And consider then, if you see the eyelid lifted up, as it is lifted up with burning or cutting, it is well: and if not, then repeat on that same spot of medicine where it does not make an impression and does not blacken, until your operation is made equal and the eye contracts.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur cutis adustionis.	 Then place on it Kohl with butter, until the skin of the burn is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento diaphinicon, aut alio, donec sanetur.	 Then care for it with diaphoretic ointment or another, until it heals.
Et necesse est tibi apud operationem, ut custodias ultima custodia, ne in oculum cadat aliquid ex medicina.	 And it is necessary for you during the operation that you guard with the greatest care, lest anything from the medicine fall into the eye.
Quod si mollificatur palpebra post dies, et pugnat ex capillis aliquid in oculo, tunc itera medicinam super illum locum, qui mollificatur ex palpebra proprie, sicut fecisti in primis.	 But if the eyelid becomes soft after days and something struggles from the hairs into the eye, then repeat the medicine on that spot which is becoming soft from the eyelid, just as you did at first.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Then care for it until it heals.
Et haec est forma folii myrti.	 And this is the shape of a myrtle leaf.
Et scias, quod oculi hominum diuersificantur in magnitudine, et paruitate.	 And know that human eyes are varied in size and smallness.
Ergo secundum illud sit consideratio tua: et non occultatur uia rectitudinis illi, cui est studium de hac arte.	 Therefore let your consideration be according to that, and may the way of righteousness not be hidden from him who has an interest in this art. 》
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Fistula lachrymali.	 ¶ On the Method of Cauterizing the Lacrimal Duct.
Caput XIX.	 Chapter XIX.
Quando curas Fistulam, cum eo quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc, oportet ut cauterizes ipsam secundum hunc modum.	 When you are treating a fistula with what we have said regarding the divisions of diseases and your treatment is not effective, then it is necessary that you cauterize it in this manner.
Praecipe infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo, et teneat caput eius minister inter manus suas taliter, ut non moueatur, neque agitetur cum capite suo.	 Instruct the patient to place their head in your lap, and have an assistant hold their head with both hands so that it does not move or shake.
Deinde pone Cotum infusum in albugine oui, aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum eius: deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	 Then apply a cautery with the shape like this to the eye after placing a poultice of infused cotton in the membrane of an egg or in slippery elm mucilage on it.
Sit concauum, sicut forma cannae pennae uulturis ab extremitate una, cum qua fit Cauterium: et si uis sit penetrans usque ad extremitatem aliam, et si uis sit sursum sic tenta.	 Let it be concave like the shape of a vulture's feather quill from one end, with which the cautery is made; and if you wish for it to penetrate to the other end, or if you wish for it to go upward, do so in this manner.
Verumtamen hoc concauum est melius ad opus tuum.	 However, this concave shape is better suited for your task.
Deinde exprime fistulam, si est aperta, et extrahe ex ea saniem, et exicca ipsam: et si non est aperta, tunc aperi eam, et extrahe pus eius.	 Then squeeze out the pus if it is open, and extract the pus from it, and dry it; and if it is not open, then open it and extract its pus.
Deinde pone tunc super eam Cauterium, quod fit ignitum ualde.	 Then apply a very hot cautery to it.
Et tene cum eo manum tuam parumper apud Cauterium ab oculo, ad partem nasi, ut non erret manus tua, aut inquietetur infirmus: et ponas Cauterium in adipe oculi, et corrumpas ipsum.	 And hold your hand with the cautery near the eye towards the side of the nose so that your hand does not wander or disturb the patient; and place the cautery on the fat of the eye and destroy it.
Si ergo peruenis in principio Cauterii tui usque ad os, erit bene.	 If you reach with your cautery to the bone at its beginning, it will be good.
Et si non: tunc itera Cauterium semel, aut bis, si indiges illo: et dimitte illud tribus diebus.	 And if not, then repeat the cautery once or twice, if you need it; and leave it for three days.
Deinde pone Cotum cum butyro, et cura ipsum cum unguento exiccatiuo, donec sanetur.	 Then apply a cotton poultice with butter, and treat him with drying ointment until he is healed.
Quod si praeterierint ei quadraginta dies, et non sanatur: tunc pone super ipsum medicinam acutam corrosiuam, donec detegatur os: et rade ipsum secundum quod uenit in capitulo suo.	 But if forty days pass and he is not healed, then apply a sharp corrosive medicine to him until the bone is exposed; and scrape it according to its chapter.
Et est modus alius Cauterii fistulae, quem quidam primi dixerunt.	 And there is another method for cauterizing a fistula that some of the first [surgeons] have said. ">
Intende ad locum fistulae, et finde ipsum: deinde pone in ipsam fissuram camahan subtile, id est, Cannulam subtilem, cuius forma haec est.	 Find the location of the fistula and then place a fine cannula into its slit, that is, a fine tube whose shape is like this.
Et funde in ipsum quantitatem drachmae ex plumbo liquefacto, et tene manum tuam cum Canna retentione bona, et non moueatur infirmus omnino, ut non currat, uel perueniat plumbum liquefactum ad oculum eius.	 And pour into it a drachm's quantity of melted lead, and hold your hand with a good grasp on the reed, so that the patient does not move at all, lest the melted lead reach his eye.
Et oportet ut ponas super oculum infirmi cotum infusum in albumine oui, aut in aqua.	 And you should place over the sick person's eye a cloth soaked in egg white or water.
Plumbum enim comburit locum fistulae, et sanat ipsam sanatione mirabili.	 For lead burns away the site of the fistula and heals it with remarkable healing.
Quod si sanatur fistula, cum eo quod diximus ex Cauterio, et curatione, est bonum.	 If the fistula is healed along with what we have said about cautery and treatment, it is good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est administrare foramen nasi, et reducere fistulam ad cursum nasi, secundum quod ueniet in loco suo sibi proprio.	 And if not, then it is necessary to administer the nasal passage and lead the fistula into the course of the nose, so that it will come to its own proper place.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fissuris Labiorum.	 ¶ On the method of cauterizing lip fissures.
Caput XX.	 Chapter 20.
Multotiens accidunt in Labio fissurae, quae nominantur Pili, et praecipue in labiis puerorum.	 Often fissures occur on the lip, which are called hairs, and especially on the lips of children.
Cum ergo tu curas has fissuras, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio, tunc igni cauterium paruum cultellare, secundum hanc formam.	 Therefore, when you are treating these fissures with what we have said about the division of diseases, and the treatment is not effective, then use a small scalpel-shaped cautery with fire, in this manner.
Et sit concauitas eius secundum subtilitatem cultelli.	 And let its cavity be according to the fineness of the scalpel.
Deinde pone ipsum ignitum festinanter in ipsis fissuris, donec perueniat cauterium ad profundum fissurarum.	 Then place the heated cautery quickly on these fissures, until the cautery reaches the depth of the fissures.
Deinde cura ipsum cum caeroto, donec sanetur.	 Then treat it with cerate until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fistula Oris.	 ¶ On the method of cauterizing a mouth ulcer. 😊
Caput XXI.	 Chapter 21.
Quando accidit apostema in radice gingiuae, aut in palato, aut in radicibus dentium: deinde facit pus, et rumpitur: postea antiquatur, et currit pus, et fit fistula: deinde curas ipsam, et non confert in ea curatio, tunc oportet ut ignias cauterium secundum quantitatem, quod capiat in fistula.	 When an abscess occurs at the root of the gum, or on the palate, or at the roots of the teeth: then it forms pus and bursts; afterwards it heals and the pus flows out and a fistula is formed: then you treat it, and the treatment does not work in it, then you should heat a cautery according to the size that fits into the fistula. 😊
Deinde intromitte ipsum ignitum in foramine fistulae, et tene manum tuam, donec perueniat ferrum ignitum ad profundum eius, et ultimum eius: fac illud semel, aut duabus uicibus.	 Then introduce the glowing iron into the opening of the fistula, and hold your hand until the glowing iron reaches the depth and end of it; do this once or twice.
Deinde cura ipsum post illud, cum eo quod diximus de curatione usquequo curetur.	 Then care for him afterward, with what we have said about caring for him until he is cured.
Si ergo abscinditur sanies, et sanatur, erit bonum.	 If the pus is drained and healing occurs, it will be good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est detegere locum, et auferre os corrupum secundum quod ueniet in capite suo.	 And if not, then it is necessary to uncover the place and remove the rotten bone according to how it appears at its head.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Gingiuis, et Dentibus mollificatis.	 On the method of cauterizing the gums and softened teeth.
Caput XXII.	 Chapter 22.
Quando mollificatur gingiua propter humiditates, et mouentur dentes, et curas eam cum medicinis, et non confert: tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	 When the gums are softened due to dampness and the teeth become loose, and you care for them with medicines but it does not help, then place the head of the patient on your lap.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma ueniet post haec, ita ut ponas Cannulam super dentem: et intromitte in ea Cauterium ignitum festinanter: et tene manum tuam parumper, donec sentiat infirmus calorem ignis iam peruenisse ad radicem dentis.	 Then use fire to cauterize with an instrument whose form will be shown below, placing the cannula on the tooth; and introduce the glowing cautery quickly into it; and hold your hand briefly until the patient feels the heat of the fire reaching the root of the tooth. ›
Et eleua manum tuam: deinde itera Cauterium aliquotiens, secundum quod uis.	 And lift up your hand; then repeat the cautery several times according to what you wish. › ›
Deinde impleat infirmus os suum aqua salis, et teneat ipsam hora una: et exspuat ipsam.	 Then let the patient fill his mouth with salt water and hold it for one hour; then spit it out.
Dens enim motus firmatur, et gingiua mollificata stringitur, et siccatur humiditas corrupta.	 For the loose tooth is strengthened, and the softened gum is tightened, and the corrupt moisture is dried.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Dentium.	 On the method of cauterizing for toothache. › › › › › › ›
Caput XXIII.	 Chapter 23. › › › › › › ›
Quando dolor dentis est propter frigiditatem, aut in ipso est frigus, aut uermis, et non confert curatio cum medicinis: tunc Cauterium in ipso est secundum duos modos: aut Cauterium cum butyro: aut cauterium cum igne.	 When the toothache is due to cold, or there is cold or worm in it, and care with medicines does not help; then cautery in it is in two ways: either cautery with butter, or cautery with fire. › › › › › › › › › › › › › › › › › › › › ›
Cauterium autem eius cum butyro est, ut accipias butyrum uaccinum, et bullias ipsum in cochleari ferreo, aut in uenera.	 "The cautery for it with butter is as follows: take butter from a cow, and boil it in an iron ladle or in bronze.
Deinde accipe cotum, et inuolue ipsum super extremitatem tentae.	 Then take cotton and wrap it around the tip of the probe.
Deinde submerge ipsum in butyro bullito: et pone ipsum super dentem dolorosum festinanter, et tene ipsum donec infrigidet: deinde itera ipsum aliquotiens, donec perueniat uirtus ignis ad radicem dentis.	 Then dip it in the boiled butter; place it quickly on the aching tooth and hold it until it cools down. Repeat this several times until the heat of the fire reaches the root of the tooth.
Et si uis, submerge lanam, aut cotum in butyro frigido, et pone ipsum super dentem dolentem: et pone super ipsum ferrum ignitum, donec perueniat ignis ad profundum concauitatis dentis.	 And if you wish, dip wool or cotton in cold butter and place it on the aching tooth; then put a heated iron on top until the fire reaches the bottom of the tooth cavity.
Cauterizatio autem eius cum igne est, ut intendas ad cannulam aeris, aut cannulam ferri.	 The cautery for it with fire is done using a tube of brass or iron.
Et sit in corpore eius quiddam grossitudinis, ut non perueniat acuitas ignis ad os infirmi.	 And let its body have some thickness so that the sharpness of the fire does not reach the mouth of the patient.
Deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma ueniet: et pone ipsum super illum dentem: et tene manum tuam, donec infrigidetur Cauterium.	 Then heat the cautery whose shape will come; and place it on that tooth; and hold your hand until the cautery cools down.
Fac illud aliquotiens, nam dolor remouebitur, aut in illo eodem die, aut die alio.	 Do this several times, for the pain will be removed either on that same day or another day.
Et oportet in impressione illius Cauterii, ut impleat infirmus os suum buyro bono, et teneat ipsum hora una: deinde exspuat ipsum.	 And it is necessary for the patient to fill his mouth with good butter after the impression of that cautery and hold it for one hour; then he should spit it out.
Et haec est forma Cauterii.	 And this is the shape of the cautery.
Cauteriza cum quacumque extremitate uis secundum quod est possibile: et haec est forma Cannulae.	 Cauterize with whatever end you wish according to what is possible; and this is the shape of the tube. ➤
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Strophulis.	 ¶ On the method of cauterizing in tonsils.
Caput XXIIII.	 Chapter 24
Quando Strophulae sunt a phlegmate, et ab humiditatibus frigidis, et non sunt obedientes digestioni per mecicinas, et uis digestionem earum uelociter: tunc igni Cauterium concauum, cuius forma est haec.	 When the tonsils are caused by phlegm and cold humors, do not respond to medicine, and you wish to quickly speed up their digestion, then use a concave cautery like this shape.
Habens duas extremitates apertas, ut egrediatur fumus apud Cauterium ab extremitate altera: et pone ipsum ignitum super ipsum apostema semel, et secundo, si indiges illo, donec perueniat ad profundum apostematis.	 It has two open ends so that the smoke can escape from one end while the cautery is heated; and place it once on the swelling, and a second time if necessary, until it reaches the depth of the swelling. ➤ ➤ ➤
Quod si apostema est paruum: tunc pone Cauterium secundum quantitatem apostematis.	 If the abscess is small, then apply a cautery according to the size of the abscess.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super ipsum cotum infusum in butyro, donec remoueatur quod combussit ignis.	 Then leave it alone for three days, and place over it a bandage soaked in butter until what the fire has burned away is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento dentis, donec sanetur forma cannulae.	 Then care for it with tooth wax until it heals in the shape of a cannula.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in raucedine uocis, et constrictione anhelitus.	 ¶ On the method of cauterizing for hoarseness of voice and constriction of breath.
Caput XXV.	 Chapter 25.
Quando uincunt humiditates super cannale pulmonis, et praecipue quando illud est cum frigiditate complexionis, tunc oportet ut euacuetur infirmus in primis cum medicinis solutiuis.	 When the moistures prevail over the bronchial tube, especially when it is with a cold temperament, then it is necessary for the patient to be first evacuated with dissolving medicines.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum in nocrati apud radicem gutturis in loce depresso: et caue, ne peruenias cum Cauterio ad guttur, neque in cute, nisi quiddam eius.	 Then cauterize him at the crook of the neck near the root of the throat, in a low place; and be careful not to reach the throat with the cautery, nor the skin, except for some of it.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cauterio alio apud iuncturam colli in ultimo spondili eius ultimando: et sit Cauterium clauile secundum modum, qui praecessit.	 Then cauterize him with another cautery at the junction of the neck in its last vertebra, terminating there; and let the cautery be small according to the previous method.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	 Then care for him with what has been said before until he heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aegritudinibus Pulmonis, et Tussi.	 ¶ On the method of cauterizing for lung diseases and coughing.
Caput XXVI.	 Chapter 26.
