When this happens to someone, then quickly place your hand on the opening of the artery and put your index finger over it; and press hard until the blood is blocked under your finger and nothing comes out from it.
Deinde pone in ignem cauteria oliuaria parua, et magna numero plura: et suffla super ea, donec fiant ignita ualde.	 Then place a small cauterizing instrument made of iron into the fire and several large ones; blow on them until they become very hot.
Deinde accipe ex eis unum, aut paruum, aut magnum, secundum uulnus et locum, in quo disrupta est arteria, et depone cauterium super ipsam uenam, post quam tu remoues digitum tuum festinanter: et tene cauterium, donec abscindatur sanguis.	 Then take one of the instruments, either small or large, according to the wound and the place where the artery has been cut; quickly remove your finger and place the cautery on the vein itself, and hold it there until the blood is cut off.
Quod si expellatur cum eleuas digitum ab orificio arteriae, et extinguis cauterium, tunc accipe cauterium aliud festinanter, ex cauteriis quae in igne sunt praeparata.	 But if it is driven out along with the elevation of your finger from the opening of the artery, and you extinguish the cautery, then quickly take another cautery from those that are prepared in the fire.
Non ergo cesses facere illud cum uno post aliud, donec abscindatur sanguis.	 Do not therefore cease to do this with one after another until the blood is cut off.
Et caue, ne comburas neruum qui est illic, et accidat super infirmum malicia alia.	 And be careful not to burn the nerve that is there, lest something else happen to the patient.
Et scias, quod quando ex arteria fluit sanguis, tunc non est possibile abscindere ipsum: praecipue quaudo arteria est magna, nisi cum uno quatuor modorum.	 And know that when blood flows from the artery, then it is not possible to cut it off; especially when the artery is large, unless with one of four methods.
Aut cum cauterio, sicut diximus.	 Or with a cautery, as we have said.
Aut cum extractione, quando non est extracta.	 Or with extraction, when it has not been extracted.
Nam quando extrahitur, contrahuntur extremitates eius, et abscinditur sanguis.	 For when it is extracted, its ends contract, and the blood is cut off. ↑
Aut ligetur cum filo ligatione forti.	 Or it may be tied with a strong thread of binding.
Aut ponantur super ipsum medicinae de proprietate, quarum est abscindere sanguinem, et stringatur cum puluinari constrictione decenti.	 Or medicines that have the property of cutting off blood may be placed on it and tied tightly with a decent compress.
Qui autem administrat abscisionem eius cum ligamento, et strictura cum panno, aut positione rerum comburentium, et similium, non confert ei penitus, nisi raro.	 However, he who cuts it off with a ligature and constriction with a cloth or with the application of burning substances and such does not help at all, except rarely.
Si autem accidat alicui illud, et non sit ei praesens medicus, neque medicina: tunc incipiat cum positione digiti indicis super orificium uenae ipsius, sicut narrauimus, et constrictione eius ualde, donec obsessus sit sanguis a superiori parte uulneris, et super arteriam.	 But if this happens to someone and there is no physician present or medicine; then let him begin with the position of his index finger on the opening of that vein, as we have described, and with its very tight constriction, until the blood is held back from the upper part of the wound and above the artery. ↑
Et digitus non remoueatur, desuper ipsum cum aqua frigida uehementis frigoris semper, donec congeletur sanguis, et ingrossetur, et abscindatur.	 And the finger should not be moved; pour cold water of intense cold over it until the blood freezes and thickens, and is cut off.
Et interim consideret in eo, quid indiget ex cauterio, aut ex medicina.	 And during that time he should consider whether anything is needed from the cautery or medicine.
¶ Partis Primae Finis.	 End of the First Part.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars II.	 Surgical Book of Albucasis, Part II.
¶ De Incisione, Perforatione, et Phlebotomia in uulneribus, et his similibus.	 Concerning the incision, puncturing, and venesection in wounds and similar cases.
Iam Diximus in Capitulo Primo, omnem aegritudinem in qua conueniens est cum igne cauterium et medicina comburente, et occasiones eius, ipsius caussas, et instrumenta eius, et formas cauteriorum.	 As we have said in the first chapter, every illness that is suitable for the use of the cautery and burning medicine, along with its causes, instruments, and types of cautery.
Et posui illic capitula a uertice usque ad pedem.	 And I placed there chapters from the head down to the feet.
Et ego procedam in hoc capitulo illa eadem uia: ut alleuietur super quaerentem quaesitum eius.	 And I will proceed in this chapter along the same path, so that what is sought may be clear to those who seek it.  />
Et antequam incipiam illud, oportet ut addiscatis o filii, quod in hoc capitulo est ex terrore illud quod est in capitulo primo de cauterizatione.	 And before I begin that, it is necessary for you, O sons, to learn what is in this chapter from fear of what is in the first chapter about cautery.
Et propter illud oportet, ut sit cautela in eo uehementior, quoniam in operatione quae est in hoc capitulo, multotiens cadit euacuatio cum sanguine, cum quo stat uita apud apertionem uenae, aut incisionem super apostema, aut apertionem exiturae, aut curationem uulneris, aut extractionem sagittae, aut incisionem super lapidem, et illis similia: ex quibus omnibus associatur tremor, et timor, et cadit in pluribus eorum mors.	 And because of this, greater care is necessary, for in the operation that is in this chapter, there often occurs an evacuation with blood, with which life stands at the opening of a vein, or an incision over an abscess, or the opening of a fistula, or the treatment of a wound, or the extraction of an arrow, or an incision over a stone, and similar things: from all these comes trembling, fear, and in many of them death occurs.  />  />  >
Et ego moneo uos, ne cadat super uos illud in quo est haesitatio, nam quandoque cadunt ad uos in hac arte modi hominum cum modis infirmitatum.	 And I warn you that this hesitation does not fall upon you, for sometimes people with various conditions come to you in this art.
Ex eis enim est qui irascitur cum aegritudine sua, et est leuis apud eum mors: propter uehementiam eius quod inuenit ex infirmitate sua et longitudine eius maliciei.	 For among them is one who becomes angry with his illness, and death is light for him because of the severity he finds from his illness and its long-standing evil.  />  />  >  />
Et cum aegritudine est ex timore quod significat mortem.	 "And with illness from fear which signifies death.
Et ex eis est, qui dat tibicensum suum, et ditat te cum eo, sperans sanitatem, et aegritudo eius est perniciosa.	 "And among them is one who gives his flute to you and enriches you with it, hoping for health, but his illness is deadly.
Non ergo oportet ut consentiatis ei qui uenit ad uos ex eis, cuius modus est talis.	 "Therefore, you should not agree with him who comes to you from among them, whose manner is such.
Et sit cautela uestra uehementior, quam cupiditas et uestra rapacitas.	 "And let your caution be greater than your greed and your rapacity.
Et non praesumatis super aliquid ex illo, nisi post scientiam certam, quae uerificat apud uos illud ad quod peruenit successio laudabilis.	 "And do not assume anything from him unless after certain knowledge, which verifies for you the praiseworthy outcome to which he has arrived.
Et utimini in curatione omnium infirmorum uestrorum, prognosticatione et indicatione de eo ad quod conuenienter sit salus.	 "And use in the treatment of all your sick, prognosis and diagnosis for that to which health is properly suited.
In illo namque est uobis adiutorium super acquisitionem famae et gloriae, et memoriae et laudis.	 "In this indeed you have assistance in the acquisition of fame and glory, and memory and praise.
Inspiret uobis Deus o filii, intellectum suum, et non auferat uobis directionem et inspirationem: quoniam illud est in manu eius.	 "May God inspire you, O sons, with his understanding, and may he not take away your guidance and inspiration, for that is in his hand.
Et ego quidem ordinaui hoc Capitulum distinguendo per capitula, secundum quod praecessit in capitulo Cauterii, a ceruice usque ad pedes: ut alleuietur uobis quaesitum quod uultis ex eo, et quo indigetis.	 "And I myself have arranged this Chapter into sections, following the previous chapter on cautery, from the neck down to the feet, so that it may facilitate for you the search of what you wish and need from it.
¶ De curatione Aquae quae aggregatur in capitibus puerorum.	 "On the treatment of water which collects in the heads of children.
Caput I.	 Chapter I
Scias, quod haec infirmitas multotiens accidit pueris apud partum: aut quando stringit obstetrix caput pueri absque leuitate.	 "Know that this illness often happens to children at birth, or when the midwife presses the child's head without gentleness.
Et quandeque accidit etiam ex caussa occulta quae non scitur.	 "And sometimes it also happens for an unknown cause which is not known.
Et ego quidem non uidi hanc aegritudinem in aliis quam in pueris: et ad omnem quem ex eis uidi properauit mors: propter illud ergo uisum est mihi dimittere operationem in ea.	 "And I myself have not seen this illness in anyone other than children, and for every one of them that I saw death followed quickly; therefore it seemed to me to abandon the treatment of it.
Et ego quidem uidi ex eis puerum, cuius caput impletum erat aqua, et caput magnificabatur in omni die, donec non poterat sedere super seipsum, propter magnitudinem capitis sui: et humiditas augmentata fuit, donec mortuus est.	 "And I myself saw a boy from them whose head was filled with water, and his head increased in size every day until he could no longer sit on his own because of the size of his head; and the fluid accumulated until he died.
Et haec quidem humiditas, aut aggregatur inter cutem et os: aut aggregatur sub osse super sifac.	 And this moisture either gathers between the skin and bone, or it gathers beneath the bone above the sinus.
Et operatio in illo, si est humiditas inter cutem et os, et apostema est paruum, tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis fissura una in latitudine: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo nodi, donec currat humiditas.	 And if the operation is on that [area], and there is moisture between the skin and bone, and an abscess has formed, then it is necessary to cut one incision in the middle of the head, with a width equal to one fingerbreadth; and let the length of the incision be like two finger joints, until the moisture runs out.
Et haec est forma spatumilis.	 And this is the form of a trepan.
Si ergo humiditas est magis augmentata, et apostema est maius, tunc pone eas duas fissuras, secundum formam hanc.	 Therefore, if the moisture has increased more and the abscess is larger, then place those two incisions according to this form.
Et si humiditas est sub osse, et signum eius est, quod uides commissuras capitis apertas ab omni parte: et aqua deprimitur quando comprimis eam manu tua ad interiora, et non occultatur tibi illud: tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis tribus fissuris, secundum hunc modum.	 And if the moisture is beneath the bone, and its sign is that you see the sutures of the head open on every side; and when you press with your hand towards the inside, water flows out and is not hidden from you; then it is necessary to cut three incisions in the middle of the head according to this manner.
Et post incisionem extrahe humiditatem totam.	 And after making the incision, remove all the moisture.
Deinde stringe fissuras cum pannis et puluillis.	 Then bind the incisions with cloths and wool.
Deinde embroca illud desuper cum uino et oleo usque ad diem quintum.	 Then dress it on top with wine and oil until the fifth day.
Deinde solue ligamentum, et cura uulnus cum tentis, et unguentis.	 Then loosen the bandage, and care for the wound with poultices and ointments.
Et non dimittas stringere caput cum aequalitate.	 And do not neglect to bind the head securely.
Et ciba infirmum omni cibo sicco paucae humiditatis, usquequo confortetur membrum, et sanetur.	 And feed the patient with every dry food of little moisture until the part is strengthened and healed.
Et modus alius incisionis est, ut consideres ubi apparet magnitudo apostematis, et collectio aquae.	 Another method of incision is to consider where the swelling of the abscess and the collection of water appear.
Quoniam quandoque est in occipitio plus, aut in sincipite, aut in dextra, aut in sinistra.	 Because sometimes it is more on the back of the head, or in the front, or on the right side, or on the left side.  />
Ascende ergo cum incisione ubi apparet tibi apostema et impletio aquae: et scinde illud secundum quod tibi possibile est.	 Therefore, ascend with your incision to where you see the abscess and the filling of water; and cut it according to what is possible for you.
Et obserua, ne incidas arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis, et moriatur infirmus ex illo fluxu cum euacuatione humiditatis.	 And be careful not to cut an artery, and cause bleeding, and the patient may die from that bleeding with the evacuation of moisture.
¶ De incisione Arteriarum quae sunt post aures.	 On cutting arteries that are behind the ears.
Caput II.	 Chapter 2
Quando accidunt alicui catarri ad oculos, aut ad pectus, et antiquatur illud, et non confert curatio medicinarum: tunc magis ultima curatio est in illo, incisio harum duarum arteriarum.	 When someone has a cold affecting their eyes or chest, and it persists despite the treatment of medications: then the final cure for them is the cutting of these two arteries.
Oportet ergo quando uis incidere eas, ut radat infirmus caput suum.	 Therefore, when you wish to cut them, the patient must have their head shaved.
Deinde frica locum cum panno aspero, ut appareant arteriae.	 Then rub the area with a rough cloth so that the arteries become visible.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum, cum quolibet panno suo.	 Then let the patient tighten their neck with any of their own cloths.
Deinde considera, ubi pulset uena.	 Then observe where the vein pulsates.  /> Deinde incide eam superius in medio.
Et loca utriusque sunt loca quae sunt post aures depressa: et raro occultatur, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	 And the locations of both are behind the ears and slightly depressed; they are rarely hidden except in some people.
Deinde signa cum encaustro super utraque: et incide utramque cum spatumili utrimque acuro, incisione perueniente ad os: et fiat illud per latitudinem capitis.	 Then mark each with wax and cut both with a sharp scalpel on either side of the opening, and make this incision as wide as the head.
Et si uis, intromitte spatumile sub arteria, et incide eam ad superiora cum incisione.	 And if you wish, insert the scalpel under the artery, and cut it from above with this incision.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quasi duo digiti iuncti.	 And let the length of the incision be about two fingers' width.
Nam quando inciditur uena, egreditur sanguis egressione pulsatili, qui salit ad interiora saltu frequenti.	 For when the vein is cut, blood flows out in a pulsating manner, which jumps to the innermost parts with frequent leaps.
Si autem arteria non apparet sensui, tunc oportet ut mensures ab aure quantitatem spacii trium digitorum.	 But if the artery is not perceptible by touch, then measure from the ear the distance of three fingerbreadths.
Deinde signa cum encaustro, et finde usque ad os.	 Then mark with wax and find it until you reach the opening.
Et illud quod oportet emittere ex sanguine, est VI uncia et fortasse emittis ex eo plus, aut minus.	 And what should be released from the blood is six ounces, and perhaps you will release more or less than that.
Totum illud secundum quantitatem quae apparet tibi ex uirute infirmi et repletione arteriae eius.	 The entire amount according to what appears to you from the strength of the patient and the fullness of his artery.
Deinde considera ad uulnus.	 Then observe at the wound.
Tunc si remanet ad os ex sifac aliquid, tunc incide illud, ut non accidat apostema calidum: tunc stringe uulnus cum liciniis ex panno lini.	 Then if something remains at the opening from the bandage, cut it off so that a hot abscess does not form; then bind the wound with strips of linen cloth.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	 Then care for it with an ointment until it heals.
¶ De extractione arteriarum, quae sunt in timporibus.	 On the extraction of temporal arteries.
Caput III.	 Chapter 3.
Quando accidit homini hemicranea antiqua, aut catarri acuti propter humiditates acrimoniales, et caliditate in lacertis timporum, aut soda antiqua, uehemens, et similia illis: et medicatur cum modis curationis medicinae, et non confert illud: tunc experti sumus in his aegritudinibus extractionem arteriarum ex timporibus, aut cauterizationem earum, sicut narrauimus.	 When someone has an old hemicrania or acute catarrh due to sharp humors and heat in the temples, or an old, severe headache similar to these, and is treated with the methods of medical therapy but does not benefit from it; then we have found that in these illnesses extraction of the arteries from the temples, or cauterization of them, as we have narrated, is beneficial.
Et modus operationis in extractione earum, est, ut radat infirmus pilos qui sunt in timporibus, et intendat ad arteriam apparentem in timpore.	 And the method of operation for their extraction is as follows: the patient should shave the hair from his temples and direct [his attention] to the visible artery in the temple.
Ipsa namque ostenditur tibi ex pulsu suo, et raro occultatur nisi in paucis hominibus, aut uehementia frigoris.	 It is indicated to you by its pulse and rarely conceals itself except in a few people or from intense cold.
Quod si occultatur tibi, tunc stringat infirmus caput suum cum quolibet panno suo: deinde frica locum cum panno aspero.	 If it is hidden from you, then the patient should bind his head with any of his cloths; afterwards, rub the place with a rough cloth.
Aut uapora locum cum aqua calida, donec appareat tibi apparitione manifesta.	 Or steam the place with hot water until it appears clearly to you.
Deinde accipe spatumile, quod paulo ante formaui.	 Then take the spatula that I described earlier. ︎
Deinde excoria cum eo cutem cum facilitate, donec peruenias ad arteriam.	 Then use it to easily scrape away the skin until you reach the artery.
Deinde proiice in eam uncinum, et extrahe eam ad superiora, donec extrahas eam ex cute, et facias eam euadere ex tunicis quae sunt sub ea ab omni parte.	 Then insert a hook into it and pull it upwards until you have drawn it out of the skin and made it exit from all the tissues beneath it on every side.
Si autem arteria est subtilis: tunc inuolue eam cum extremitate uncini.	 If, however, the artery is thin, then wrap it around the end of the hook.
Deinde incide ex ea partem secundum quantitatem qua elongentur extremitates eius, et contrahantur, et non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	 Then cut from it a portion according to how much its ends are lengthened and contracted, so that there is no hemorrhage. ︎
Nam si non inciditur, et si non abscinditur, non ascendit sanguis penitus.	 For if it is not cut or separated, the blood does not rise up at all.
Deinde euacua ex sanguine ana VI unci, usque ad .III.	 Then evacuate from blood six ounces, up to three.
Quod si arteria est magna: tunc oportet ut liges eam in duobus locis ex filo duplo, forti, ex serico: aut ex chordis alhohod, ut non properet ad ipsam putrefactio ante consolidationem uulneris, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	 If the artery is large, then you must tie it in two places with a double, strong thread of silk or catgut, so that putrefaction does not hasten to it before the wound has healed, and blood flow occurs.
Deinde incide superfluitatem, quae est inter duo ligamenta.	 Then cut the excess between the two ligatures.
Fac illud in illa hora, aut post horam aliam.	 Do that at that hour, or after another hour.
Et si uis, cauteriza eam cauterio usque ad os, cum cauterio cultellari: donec incidantur extremitates eius, et stabit loco eiusdem operis.	 And if you wish, cauterize it with a hot iron until the ends are cut off, using a cautery knife, and it will remain in that place for the same operation.
Et est melius opus, nisi si infirmus habet febrem, autest calefactae complexionis.	 And this is a better procedure, unless the patient has a fever or a hot constitution.
Quoniam cauterium est ex eis, quae iuuant ad finiendas humiditates.	 For a cautery is among those things which help to dry up humors.  /// The translator's note: "The text here has 'quorum' instead of 'quoniam', which would change the meaning to 'because of those things...'
Ergo est melius iuuamentum.	 Therefore, it is a better remedy.
Et oportet post extractionem arteriarum, ut impleatur locus cotto antiquo: et ponantur super ipsum puluilli decenter facti.	 And after the removal of the arteries, the place should be filled with old cooked dough and well-prepared poultices placed on top.
Et post solutionem curetur cum medicinis siccis, quae faciunt nasci carnem, et cum liciniis, donec sanetur.	 And after it has dissolved, scrape with dry medicines that promote the growth of flesh, and with ointments, until it heals.
Quod si interim dum operaris accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, tunc propera ad abscindendum eum cum cauterio, aut ut impleas locum cum zegi: et stringe manum tuam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	 If during the operation there is bleeding from the artery, then hurry to cut it off with a hot iron or to fill the place with wax; and hold your hand until the blood is stopped.
Quod si nihil ex illis est tibi praesens, tunc pone super locum digitum tuum, donec congeletur sanguis.	 If none of these things are available to you, then place your finger on the spot until the blood congeals.  /// The translator's note: "The Latin text has 'donec congelentur sanguines', with a plural verb form. I have assumed that this is a scribal error and translated as if it were singular."  /// The translator's note: "In the original Arabic text, this section is numbered as chapter 270."  /// The translator's note: "The translation follows the edited Latin text of Meyerhof and Carra de Vaux (1938), with some modifications based on the reading of the manuscripts.
Et embroca locum cum aqua uehementis frigoris, donec quiescat acuitas, et stringatur secundum quod oportet.	 And pierce the place with cold water until the pain subsides, and then bandage it as needed.
Et ex eo quod est leuius et facilius extractione arteriae, est, ut cauterizes uenam cum hoc cauterio habente duos cultellos: sitque acuitas duorum cultellorum similis almagdatem.	 And to facilitate and ease the extraction of the artery, it is best to cauterize the vein with this double-bladed cautery; let the sharpness of both blades be similar to an almagdatem.
Verumtamen sunt multo minoris acuitatis, quam duo cultelli.	 However, they are much sharper than two knives.
Quoniam si sunt acutae, sicut duo cultelli, properat utrisque frigus: et non incidunt carnem cum uelocitate.	 For if they are as sharp as two knives, cold quickly overtakes both of them; and they do not cut the flesh swiftly.
Cum ergo in eis est aliquantulum grossitudinis, tenetur in eis calor ignis, et abscinditur caro uelociter: cum hoc ergo opus est melius omni opere, et leuius, et facilius.	 Therefore, since there is a little thickness in them, they hold the heat of the fire, and cut the flesh swiftly; with this, therefore, the work is better than any other work, easier, and more convenient.
Et sit spacium quod est inter duos cultellos quantitas grossitudinis digiti, postquam tu signas duo loca cum encaustro: et depone utrosque ignitos ualde, donec perueniant ad os, et incidant uenam in duobus locis: ut elongetur quod est inter extremitates eius.	 And let the space between the two blades be as thick as a finger after you mark two places with the cautery; and put both very hot until they reach the vein, cutting it in two places so that what is between its ends becomes long.
Nam non consolidantur cum hoc cauterio penitus.	 For they do not heal completely with this cautery.
Et haec est forma cauterii.	 And this is the shape of the cautery.
¶ De cura cursus lachrymarum acutarum assiduarum ab oculis.	 ¶ On the treatment of persistent, sharp eye-watering.
Caput IIII.	 Chapter IV
Quando sunt lachrymae assiduae, et est cursus earum ex uenis, quae sunt super craneum capitis exterius: et non confert in eis aliquid curationis medicinae cum medicinis, et uides faciem infirmi iam rubere, et sentit in fronte sua deambulationem, sicut est deambulatio formicarum: et oculi eius sunt extenuati, humidi, ita quod iam corrosi sunt pili eorum cum corrosione: et calefactae sunt palpebrae eius ex acuitate lachrymarum: tunc antiqui indiguerunt in curatione earum hac operatione, et denominauerunt eam curationem, cum Ense.	 When tears are persistent and their flow is from the veins outside on top of the head, and medicines with medical treatment do not help; and you see the face of the patient already turning red, and he feels a crawling sensation on his forehead as if ants were walking there; and his eyes are weakened, moist, so that their hair is now corroded away; and his eyelids are heated from the sharpness of the tears—then the ancients needed this procedure for their treatment and called it "treatment with a sword." ›
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere pilos qui sunt in fronte sua.	 And it is necessary that you advise the sick person to shave the hairs on their forehead.
Deinde incide in fronte tres fissuras aequedistantes secundum longitudinem frontis: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo digiti, et fissura una sit aequedistans longitudini nasi in medio frontis, et secunda secundum longitudinem parumper a motu lacertorum, et tertia a parte altera: et caue ab incisione arteriarum quae sunt in duobus lateribus: et elonga manum tuam a continuatione duarum mandibularum, et sit spacium omnis incisionis quantitas trium digitorum coniunctorum: et sit tibi frustum spongiae praeparatum, aut panni siccati multi, cum quibus exsicces sanguinem.	 Then make three equally distant incisions along the length of the forehead: and let the length of each incision be like two fingers, and let one incision be in the middle of the forehead, equally distant from the length of the nose; and the second should be a little further from the movement of the shoulders; and the third should be on the other side. And take care not to cut the arteries that are on both sides; and keep your hand away from the continuation of the two jaws, and let the space of all the incisions be like three connected fingers in size: and prepare a piece of sponge for yourself, or many dry cloths, with which you will dry the blood.
Deinde intromitte spatumile duarum acutarum extremitatum, cuius mox sequens est forma.	 Then insert a thread with two pointed ends, whose following form is this:
Ab incisione quae est a parte timporis, usque ad incisionem secundam: et excoria cum eo totam cutem, quae est inter duas incisiones, cum sifac, quod est super os.	 From the incision that is near the temple, to the second incision; and with it peel off all the skin between the two incisions, along with the soft tissue that is on top of it.
Deinde fac illud etiam ab incisione media usque ad incisionem secundam.	 Then do likewise from the middle incision to the second incision.
Deinde extrahe hoc spatumile, et intromitte in incisionem primam iterum instrumentum aliud, quod nominatur cultellare acutum, ab una parte lene, non acutum ab altera parte.	 Then remove that thread, and insert into the first incision again a different instrument called a sharp knife, gently from one side, not sharply from the other side.
Et haec est forma eius.	 And this is its form.
Et pone latus eius acutum uersus carnem annexam cum cute, et latus eius lene uersus os: et impelle ipsum, donec perueniat ad fissuram mediam: et abscinde cum eo omnia uasa, quae descendunt a capite ad oculos: praeter quod continuetur incisio usque ad illud quod apparet de cute.	 And place its sharp edge toward the attached flesh with the skin, and its gentle side toward the bone; and push it until it reaches the middle incision; and cut with it all the vessels that descend from the head to the eyes: except that the incision continues until what is seen of the skin.
Deinde fac illud in fissura media usque ad fissuram aliam.	 Then do this in the middle incision until the other incision.
Et postquam currit ex sanguine quantitas aequalis, exprime loca ex frustis sanguinis coagulati.	 And when an equal amount of blood has flowed out, press on the places with clots of blood to stop the bleeding.
Deinde pone in omnem fissuram licinium ex cotto ueteri, et pone super eos puluillos imbibitos in uino, et oleo, aut aceto.	 Then place a patch of old linen in every slit, and place upon them small balls soaked in wine, oil, or vinegar.
Et uide ut non accidat apostema calidum.	 And see that no hot abscess occurs.
Et in die tertia solue ligamentum, et administra infusionem multam cum aqua tepida.	 And on the third day, loosen the bandage, and administer a large infusion with warm water.
Deinde cura illud ex unguento basilicon, et reliquis quibus curantur uulnera: usquequo sanetur.	 Then treat it with an ointment of balm and other treatments for wounds until it heals.
¶ De cura lachrymarum acutarum et catarrorum ad oculos ex interioribus capitis.	 About the treatment of sharp tears and head colds affecting the eyes from within the head.
Caput V.	 Chapter 5
Quando accidunt alicui catarri acuti, acres, assidui: et uides oculos eius extenuatos, paruos, et iam debilitatus est aspectus eorum: et palpebrae ulceratae, et cadunt pili ex eis, et in profundo capitis est dolor acutus, laedens, et sternutatio consequens: tunc sume ex istis accidentibus, quod illae materiae, et catarri non ueniunt, nisi ex uenis multis.	 When someone has sharp, painful, constant colds, and you see their eyes are thin, small, and their sight is already weakened; and the eyelids are ulcerated, and hairs fall out from them, and there is a sharp pain in the depths of the head that hurts, and sneezing follows: then know that these things come to pass only from many veins.
Et melior curatio in eis est haec.	 And a better treatment for them is this.  />
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere frontem suam.	 And it is that you should advise the patient to shave their forehead.
Deinde incide in eam fissuram unam in medio frontis, aut alterius parumper per latitudinem, et incipe cum fissura a timpore sinistro ad timpus dextrum: et sit incisio usque ad os: et elonga manum tuam a lacertis timporum, qui mouentur apud masticationem: donec quando detegitur os: et exsiccabis totum sanguinem cum spongia.	 Then cut one slit in the middle of the forehead, or another somewhat in width, and begin with the slit from the left temple to the right temple; and let the incision reach the mouth; and draw your hand away from the temples that move during chewing until the mouth is exposed; and dry all the blood with a sponge.  />  ·
Tunc separa inter duo labia fissurae cum cotto ueteri, aut cum liciniis ex lino.	 Then separate between the two lips of the slit with old linen cloth, or with linens from flax.
Deinde stringe desuper cum puluillis: et imbibe puluillos cum uino et oleo, ut non accidat apostema calidum.	 Then bind on top with small balls and soak the balls in wine and oil, so that no hot abscess occurs.
Et quando soluis illud, et uides quod apostema calidum iam imminuitur: tunc oportet ut frices os, donec incipiat in eo nasci caro.	 And when you loosen it and see that the hot abscess has lessened: then it is necessary for you to scrub the mouth until flesh begins to form there.  />
Deinde cura ipsum cum regimine exiccatiuo quod facit nasci carnem: sicut si accipias ex farina tritici partes duas, et ex colophonia quatuor partes: et praepares ex eis emplastrum, et administretur ad natiuitatem carnis in istis uulneribus.	 Then take care of him with a drying regimen that causes flesh to form, such as if you take two parts of wheat flour and four parts of resin and prepare a plaster from them, and administer it at the time of flesh formation in these wounds.
¶ De cura eius quod cadit in Aurem.	 § On the care for what falls into the ear.
Caput VI.	 Chapter VI
Omne Quod in Aurem cadit, est una quatuor specierum: aut lapis mineralis, aut simile lapidi, sicut ferrum, et uitrum: aut est ex planta, sicut est cicer, et fabae: aut est res fluxibilis, sicut aqua, et acetum, et eis similia: aut aliquod animal.	 Everything that falls into the ear is one of four kinds: either a mineral stone or something similar to a stone, such as iron and glass; or it is from a plant, such as chickpeas and beans; or it is a liquid substance, such as water, vinegar, and the like; or some kind of animal.
Quando ergo cadit in aurem lapis, aut genus lapidis ex eis quae non adduntur, neque crescunt in aure, expone Aurem soli: si ergo uides lapidem, tunc distilla in Aurem aliquid ex oleo uiolato, aut sisamino.	 When, therefore, a stone or something of the kind from those which do not grow and are not added falls into the ear, expose the ear to sunlight; but if you see the stone, then drip some oil of violets or sesame oil into the ear.
Deinde administra extractionem eius, et fac sternutare cum condisi, et opila nares apud aduentum sternutationis, postquam tu ponis in circumitu auris frusta ex pannis, aut lana, et extendis aurem ad superiora.	 Then administer an extraction and cause sneezing with a condiment; and plug the nostrils at the onset of sneezing, after you have placed around the ear fragments of cloth or wool, and extend the ear upwards.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum hac cura.	 For often it comes out with this treatment.
Si autem non egreditur, tunc administra extractionem eius cum Gesti, id est, Pizigarolis subtilibus: cuius forma est haec.	 But if it does not come out, then administer the extraction with tweezers, that is, fine pincers; and their form is this.  />
Si ergo egreditur cum gesti, est bonum.	 If it comes out with the tweezers, it is good.
Et si non, tunc administra extractionem eius cum uncino caeco subtili paucae duplicationis.	 And if not, then administer the extraction with a fine, small-bladed hook.
Si ergo non egreditur per illud, tunc fac cannulam ex aere, et intromitte extremitatem cannulae in foramen auris multum, et opila quod est in circumitu cannulae cum caera mollificata cum oleo, ut non sit uento uia nisi cannulae: deinde extrahe cum uento tuo attractione forti.	 But if it does not come out through that, then make a tube from metal and insert the end of the tube deeply into the opening of the ear, and plug what is around the tube with softened wax mixed with oil, so that there be no way for air except through the tube; then draw it out with your strong attraction. 
Multotiens enim egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus.	 Often indeed it goes out with what we have narrated.
Si autem non egreditur hoc modo: tunc accipe ex helkalimbat, aut ex uisco, id est, gluten praeparato, cum quo capiuntur aues, rem modicam: et pone ipsum in extremitate radii postquam tu inuoluis super eam cotum decenter positum: deinde intromitte ipsum in foramen auris cum facilitate, postquam tu exiccas aurem ab humiditate.	 But if it does not go out in this manner: then take from helkalimbat or from glue prepared with which birds are caught, a small portion; and put it at the end of the stick after you have wound over it a neatly placed bandage. Then insert it into the ear canal easily, after you have dried the ear from moisture.
Si ergo non egreditur cum omnibus quae narrauimus, tunc propera ad scindendum, antequam accidat apostema calidum, aut spasmus.	 Therefore if it does not go out with all that we have narrated, then hasten to cut open (the ear) before a hot abscess or spasm occurs.
Et modus fissurae est, ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis in cephalica: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum mensuram uirtutis eius.	 And the manner of cutting is that the physician should first open a vein on the head; and draw blood from him according to his strength.
Deinde fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et conuerte aurem eius ad superiora, et finde fissuram paruam in radice auris apud adipem eius in loco depresso ipsi: et sit fissura lunaris figurae, donec peruenias ad lapidem: deinde aufer eum cum eo, quod est tibi possibile ex instrumentis.	 Then make the patient sit between your hands, and turn his ear upward; and find a small cut in the root of the ear at its fatty part in a depressed place itself; and let the cut be lunar shaped, until you reach the stone; then remove it with whatever instrument is possible for you. 》
Deinde sue fissuram ab hora tua cum uelocitate, et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	 Then either make the cut swiftly yourself and take care of it until it heals.
Quod si res cadens in aurem est ex uno granorum, quae crescunt, et inflantur: tunc administra extractionem eius.	 If however the thing that fell into the ear is one of the grains which grow and swell up, then administer an extraction for it.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc accipe spatumile tenue, subtile, secundum hanc formam.	 But if it does not obey you to go out, then take a thin, subtle spatula according to this shape:
Et administra cum eo abscisionem illius speciei ex granis, quae cadunt in aurem, et non facias illud, quando tu cogitas, quod illud granum iam humectatum est per uaporem auris, donec ponis ipsum frusta multa: deinde extrahe ea cum uncinis, aut cum gesti subtili, aut cum suctione, sicut diximus, nam extractio eius alleuiatur.	 And apply an incision of that kind for the grains which fall into the ear and do not do this when you think that grain is already moistened by the vapor of the ear until you place it in many pieces; then remove them with tweezers, or a fine probe, or suction, as we have said, for its extraction will be eased.
In aqua autem quae ingreditur in aurem, oportet ut utatur infirmus sternutatione cum condisi in primis: et iam impleuit aurem suam cum aliquanto cotto ueteri: et est iacens super illam aurem, in qua est aqua.	 For water which enters the ear, it is fitting for the patient to use sneezing first of all; and now he has filled his ear with some old bandage; and he lies upon that ear in which there is water.
Si ergo egreditur per illud, est bonum.	 If it exits through that part, it is good.
Et si non: tunc accipe lapides multos, secundum longitudinem digiti, tenues, lenes, et calefac eos cum igne parumper, et intromittat infirmus ex eis unum in foramen auris suae: et saliat super pedem suum unum ex illa parte, et percutiat cum lapide alio super lapidem qui est in aure.	 And if not: then take many stones, according to the length of your finger, thin and soft, and heat them slightly with fire; and let the sick person put one of them into his ear hole: and let him jump on one foot on that side, and strike it with another stone on the stone which is in the ear.
Non ergo cesset facere illud cum lapide et lapide, donec egrediatur tota aqua.	 Therefore, do not cease doing this with the stone and the stone until all the water comes out.
Et iam egreditur aqua ita, ut accipias ex parpyro, aut ex iunco unum, et intromittas extremitatem eius unam in aurem: et accendas extremitatem alteram cum igne, donec comburatur plurimum eius.	 And now the water comes out in such a way that you should take one of either rush or reed, and insert its tip into the ear; and set fire to the other end with a flame, until most of it is burnt.
Deinde itera iuncum alium, et fac illud multotiens, donec egrediatur tota aqua: et extrahe ipsam cum cannula secundum quod praemissum est in lapide.	 Then repeat this with another rush, and do it many times until all the water comes out; and remove it with a probe as previously mentioned for the stone.
In extractione autem animalis intrantis in eam, si est parui corporis, ut pulex, et ei simile, cura ipsum sicut dixi in diuisione.	 But if an animal enters it, and its body is small, like a flea, then care for it as I said in the section on division.
Sed si est corporis magni, quod appareat sensui: tunc administra extractionem eius cum gesti, et uncinis: et res eius est facilior omnibus, quae tenentur in aure.	 But if it has a large body, which is perceptible to the senses; then administer its extraction with tweezers and hooks: and this case is easier than all others that are retained in the ear.
In extractione autem uermis generati in aure, quando curas eum cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et in tractatu distilationum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut aspicias aurem in sole.	 But in the extraction of a worm born in the ear, when you care for it with what we said in division and in the treatment of distillations, and your treatment does not help; then you must examine the ear in sunlight. 》
Si ergo apparet illic aliquid ex uermibus, tunc extrahe illud cum gesti, aut cum uncinis subtilibus.	 If something from the worms is visible there, then remove it with tweezers or fine hooks.
Si autem non apparet illic aliquid, tunc accipe cannulam, cuius haec est forma, stricta inferius, ampla superius: et intromitte extremitatem subtilem in aurem secundum quantitatem quod tolerat eam infirmus: deinde suge cum ea suctione forti.	 But if nothing is visible there, then take a probe of this shape, narrow at the bottom and wide at the top; and insert its thin tip into the ear according to how much the patient can tolerate; then draw with it strongly.
Fac illud multotiens, donec egrediantur omnes uermes.	 For this, often, until all the worms come out.
Si autem non obediunt tibi ad exitum, tunc opila circumitum cannulae cum caera, sicut dixi in lapide.	 But if they do not obey you to come out, then fill the circle of the probe with wax, as I said about the stone.
Quod si non egrediuntur cum eo quod diximus: tunc administra distillationes quas iam experti sunt antiqui in interfectione uermium: et inuenies illud in tractatu distillationum.	 If they do not come out with what I said: then administer the distillations that the ancients have already experienced in the killing of worms; and you will find this in the treatise on distillations.
Et sit effusio tua qua effundis olea et medicinas in aurem cum hoc instrumento, cuius forma depicta est hic.	 And let your pouring be that with which you pour oil and medicines into the ear with this instrument, whose form is drawn here.
Sicut uides fac ipsum ex argento, aut aere, inferius strictum, in quo sit foramen paruum, amplum superius.	 As you see, make it from silver or bronze, narrow at the bottom, in which there should be a small hole, wide at the top.
Sit ergo ut impellens quod est in concauitate cannulae, sit ex aere decenter factum.	 Let, therefore, the plunger that is inside the cavity of the probe be made from bronze, well-crafted.
Et si uis, accipe radium, et inuolue in extremitate eius cottum inuolutione decenti: deinde proiice oleum, aut succum, aut quod uis ex istis medicinis in cannulam: et ipsa sit in aure: deinde intromitte radium cum cotto desuper, et exprime ipsum manu tua compressione temperata, donec impellatur oleum in concauitate auditus, et sentiat ipsum infirmus interius: et illud quod infunditur in aurem, sit iam calefactum cum igne parumper: et caue ne sit res quae distillatur in eam frigida ualde: medicinae enim non tolerant illud.	 And if you wish, take a reed and wrap the tip of it neatly with cotton; then pour oil or juice or whatever medicine you want into the probe; and let the probe be in the ear; then insert the reed with the cotton on top and press it gently with your hand until the oil is pushed into the cavity of the ear, and the patient feels it inside; and what is poured into the ear should already be warmed a little by fire; and be careful that it is not very cold, for medicines do not tolerate that. ()}
¶ De cura opilationis accidentis Auri.	 ¶ On the treatment of gold impaction.
Caput VII.	 Chapter 7.
Quandoque egrediuntur quidam infantes ex uentribus matrum suarum non perforati.	 Sometimes some infants come out of their mothers' wombs unperforated.
Et iam accidit etiam quibusdam hominibus opilatio in meatu Auris a uulnere, aut carne nata in ea.	 And it has also happened to some people that an impaction occurs in the ear canal from a wound or flesh born there.
Et haec opilatio quandoque fit in profundo foraminis Auris, quam non consequitur uisus: et quandoque accidit ad exteriora foraminis parum, et consequitur eam uisus.	 And this impaction sometimes occurs deep within the ear canal, which sight cannot follow; and sometimes it happens near the outer part of the canal, and sight follows it.
Illa ergo quae accidit in profundo Auris, et quam non comprehendit aspectus, est in pluribus dispositionibus difficilis sanationis.	 That which occurs in the deep part of the ear and is not seen by the eyesight is difficult to heal in many cases.
Et in illa quam consequitur uisus, oportet ut ponas Aurem infirmi in sole, et aspicias in ea: tunc si uides opilationem apparentem, aperi eam cum spatumili subtili, cuius forma est haec quae sequitur, sit extremitas eius in qua sit quaedam latitudo parua, cuius quaedam pars sit acuta: et reliquum spatumile sit duarum laterum lenium: ut non laedat aurem.	 And in that which follows sight, you should place the ear of the patient in the sun and look at it; then if you see a visible obstruction, open it with a fine probe, the shape of which is as follows: its tip should have a small width, part of which is sharp, and the rest of the probe should be smooth on two sides so that it does not harm the ear.
Si ergo opilatio est a carne nata in meatu auris: tunc tene eam cum uncino subtili, et incide eam cum facilitate uehementi, donec auferatur tota caro.	 If therefore the obstruction is formed of flesh within the ear, then hold it with a fine hook and cut it with great ease until all the flesh is removed.
Quod si opilatio est in profundo auris: tunc accipe radium subtilem, lenem, et calefac ipsum cum igne parumper: deinde mitte ipsum in meatum auris.	 But if the obstruction is deep within the ear, then take a thin, smooth probe and heat it with fire for a short while; then insert it into the opening of the ear.
Si ergo senseris opilationem cum eo, quod inuenit infirmus cum grauitate auditus, conare apertionem eius cum facilitate: et caue, ne uulneres neruos auris.	 If therefore you feel the obstruction along with what the patient finds with a heavy hearing, endeavor to open it with ease; and beware lest you wound the nerves of the ear.  ///
Deinde pone in aurem licinium secundum quantitatem amplitudinis foraminis, quod inuoluisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud aliquot diebus, donec sis securus de consolidatione uulneris.	 Then place a linen bandage over the ear according to the size of the opening, rolled up in Egyptian ointment; do this for several days until you are sure about the healing of the wound.
Aut accipe licinium, et infunde ipsum in aqua rosata, et pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, et utere ipso.	 Or take a linen cloth and soak it in rose water; then sprinkle ground alum over it and use that.
Quod si uides aurem iam apostemari: tunc oportet ut extrahas licinium, et permittas ipsum cum licinio alio, quod inuolues in caeroto quod sit factum cum oleo rosato, donec sedetur apostema calidum: deinde cura ipsum usquequo sanetur.	 But if you see the ear swelling already, then it is necessary to remove the linen cloth and leave it with another linen cloth that you will roll up in a plaster made with rose oil until the hot swelling subsides; then treat it until it heals.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis: tunc submerge spongiam, aut pannos in aqua frigida, et pone super eam aurem: et utere reliqua curatione, quae abscindit fluxum sanguinis praedicta in tractatu distillationum.	 But if bleeding occurs, then submerge a sponge or cloths in cold water and place the ear on it; and use the rest of the treatment which cuts off the aforementioned bleeding in the section on distillations.
¶ De cura Altheli palpebrarum.	 In the care of ptosis of the eyelids.
Caput VIII.	 Chapter Eight.
Isti Althelil qui accidunt in Palpebris oculi, quandoque sunt humidi, et sunt sicci.	 These ptoses that occur in the eyelids of the eye are sometimes moist and sometimes dry.
Oportet ergo ut teneas eos cum tenaliis: aut cum uncino, et incidas eos cum spatumili a radicibus suis.	 Therefore, you should hold them with tweezers or with a hook and cut them from their roots with a scraper.
Deinde pone super loca zegi tritum.	 Then place ground cinnabar on the places.
Si autem ex eis fluat sanguis, tunc cauteriza eos cum cauterio lenticulari subtili.	 But if blood flows from them, then cauterize them with a fine lenticular cautery.
Et cauterizare eos, est melius post incisionem.	 And it is better to cauterize them after the incision.
Multotiens enim redeunt quando remanet ex radicibus suis aliquid.	 For often they return when something remains of their roots.
Et quando cauterizantur cum igne, comburuntur illae radices, et non redeunt.	 And when they are cauterized with fire, those roots are burned and do not return.
¶ De cura Grandinum palpebrarum oculi.	 ¶ On the care of chalazion in the eyelids of the eye.
Caput IX.	 Chapter Nine.
Multotiens accidit in palpebris aliquid quod assimilatur Crandini in fortitudine sua, et sua duricie, et propter illud nominatur Grando: et est aggregatio humiditatis grossae in palpebra superiore, et palpebra inferiore.	 It often happens that something appears in the eyelids similar to a chalazion in its strength and hardness, and because of this it is named 'grain'; it is an accumulation of thick moisture in the upper eyelid and the lower eyelid.
Operatio ergo in eis est, ut consideres tunc, si est Grando procedens in eo, quod apparet de palpebra, et mouentur ad omnem partem, et res eius est facilis.	 Therefore, the operation for them is that you should then consider if there is a 'grain' emerging from what appears on the eyelid and it moves in all directions, and its nature is easy.  ?>
Finde ergo super eam fissura per latitudinem.	 Therefore find above it a slit of suitable width.
Deinde excoria eam ab omni parte cum facilitate, donec euadat.	 Then excise it from all sides easily until it comes out.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncino, et abscinde ipsam.	 Then hang it with a hook and cut it off.
Si autem non praeparatur tibi abscisio eius, nisi postquam tu penetras palpebram cum incisione parumper, tunc nocet infirmo illud in aliquo.	 But if its removal is not prepared for you unless after you penetrate the eyelid with a slight incision, then it may harm the patient somewhat.
Quod si fissura est magna: tunc aggrega ipsam cum sutura: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	 If the slit is large, then close it with stitches and treat it until it heals.
Et si est parua, non superueniet tibi malum ex ea.	 And if it is small, no harm will come to you from it.
Vnguentum enim restaurat ipsam, et incarnat eam.	 The ointment restores it and fleshes it out.
Et si grando est decliuis ad interiora auris uersus superficiem intrinsecam, tunc inuersa palpebram, et suspende grandinem cum uncino: praeter quod indigeas incisione, et preme eam ab omni parte.	 And if the gravel has slipped into the interior of the ear towards the inner surface, then turn back the eyelid and hook out the gravel with a hook; besides this you will need to make an incision and press it from all sides.
Quod si elongatur palpebra per incisionem, non nocet illud in aliquo.	 And if the eyelid is stretched by the incision, this does no harm.
Deinde ablue oculum post incisionem grandinis, cum aqua salsa: et cura locum cum eo quod incarnat, donec sanetur infirmus.	 Then after the incision of the gravel, wash the eye with salt water; and treat the place with what makes it fleshy until the patient is healed.
¶ De cura Axirnath palpebrarum.	 ¶ Concerning the treatment for inflammation of the eyelids.
Caput X.	 Chapter 10
Axirnath est adeps qui generatur in tunicis palpebrae superioris: et plurimum quidem accidit illud pueris: et ipsum grauat oculos eorum, et accidunt eis catarri in matutinis, et non possunt intueri lumen solis, propterea, quod lachrymae properant ad eos, et propter illud uides eos discumbere super facies suas semper, et super eas dormiunt, et sunt palpebrae eorum sub superciliis humidae, quas iam cooperuit inflatio: et eminentia quidem Axirnath apparens est oculo, et quando tu premis locum cum digitis tuis, sentis Axirnath inter eos.	 Chapter 10: Concerning the treatment for inflammation of the eyelids. Trachoma is a fat that is generated in the tissues of the upper eyelid; and it occurs most often in children. It weighs down their eyes, and they are afflicted with catarrh in the mornings, and cannot look at the sun because tears rush to them, and on account of this you see them always lying face up, and sleeping that way, and their eyelids are moist under the eyebrows, which are already covered by swelling. And indeed, the prominent Axirnath is visible in the eye, and when you press the place with your fingers, you feel the Axirnath between them.
Et modus operationis eius est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	 And the method of operation is for the patient to place their head in your lap.
Deinde accipe pannum lini, et praepara in eo licinia, et fac ex illo licinio circulum secundum quantitatem quod continet Axirnath ab omni parte.	 Then take a linen cloth and prepare strips from it, and make a circle from those strips according to the size that contains the Axirnath on all sides.
Deinde pone eum super eam, et preme cum digitis tuis ab omni parte, ut aggregetur Axirnath in medio circuli.	 Then place it [the circle] over it [the eyelid], and press with your fingers from all sides, so that the Axirnath gathers in the middle of the circle. ⟩
Deinde finde in medio illius humiditatis cum spatumili incidente fissuras per latitudinem, et non sit fissura maior illa quae fit in phlebotomia in profundo.	 Then find in the middle of that moistness with a small blade making incisions through its width, and let the incision not be deeper than that made for bloodletting. ⟩
Aut oportet ut findas cutem totam, donec peruenias ad Axirnath in pluribus enim dispositionibus procedit Axirnath ex fissura secundum formam frusti pinguedinis albae.	 Or it is necessary to excise the entire skin until you reach the achilles tendon, for in many cases the Achilles tendon protrudes from the opening in the shape of a piece of white fat.
Extrahe ergo eam cum panno, quem infiltrasti inter digitos tuos ad exteriora: et tu reuoluis manum tuam ad dextram et sinistram, donec dispergatur: et caue, ne addas in fissura, ut non peruenias cum spatumili ad oculum, et laedas eum.	 Therefore, extract it with a cloth which you have inserted between your fingers towards the outside: and turn your hand to the right and left until it is dispersed; and be careful not to add [anything] into the opening, so that you do not reach the eye with the spoon and injure it.
Si autem non appareat tibi Axirnath in principio fissurae, tu addas in fissura parum cum facilitate, donec procedat Axirnath.	 However, if the Achilles tendon does not appear to you at the beginning of the opening, you should introduce a little [instrument] into the opening with ease until the Achilles tendon protrudes.
Deinde extrahe eam, sicut diximus.	 Then extract it as we have said.
Deinde submerge pannos in aceto et aqua, et pone eos super locum, et stringe eum cum puluillis.	 Then soak the cloths in vinegar and water, and place them on the wound, and bind it with little pieces of wool.
Et ex hominibus sunt qui terunt salem, et ponunt ipsum in concauitate fissurae, ut liquefiat quod remansit ex illa humiditate.	 And there are some people who grind salt and place it in the cavity of the opening, so that it melts whatever remains of that moisture.
Deinde cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	 Then care for [the wound] until it heals.
Si autem accidat in loco apostema calidum, tune cura ipsum cum emplastris sedatiuis, donec sanetur.	 However, if a hot abscess occurs at the site, then care for [the wound] with soothing plasters until it heals.
¶ De modis Ataxmir oculi, id est, cum palpebra mollificatur oculi, unde fit ut rugetur sicut non debet.	 ¶ Concerning the types of ataxia of the eye, that is, when the eyelid of the eye becomes lax, so that it blinks as it should not.
Caput XI.	 Chapter XI.
Quando nascuntur in palpebris oculi pili additi praeter cursum sub pilis naturalibus, et antiquantur: tunc ipsi nocent oculo, et faciunt accidere modos aegritudinum, sicut lachrymas assiduas, et mollificationem palpebrarum, et albuginem, donec fit illud caussa destructionis oculi.	 When hairs are born in the eyelids of the eye beyond their natural course among the natural hairs and they grow old; then these [hairs] harm the eye and cause various diseases to occur, such as constant tearing, laxity of the eyelids, and opacities, until it leads to the destruction of the eye.
Et Ataxmir quidem oculi curatur secundum quatuor modos.	 And ataxia of the eye is treated according to four methods. ¶ The first method: ¶ Take a needle and dip it in water and sulfur, and pass it along the edge of the eyelid, and burn [the hairs] with fire; and this is done only once. ¶ The second method: ¶ Take a red-hot needle and burn the entire length of the hair from its root to the tip, while it is still attached; but be careful not to touch the skin, so that you do not cause an inflammation or other harm. ¶ The third method: ¶ Take a very fine and sharp lancet, and make two incisions in each eyelid, one on each side of the [hair], while it is still attached; and then pluck out the hair, along with its root; but be careful not to cut into any vessel. ¶ The fourth method: ¶ When a person feels that the hairs are growing or when he sees them with his eyes; then take a needle and dip it in water and sulfur, and pass it along the edge of the eyelid; but be careful not to touch the skin, so that you do not cause an inflammation or other harm.
Aut per cauterium cum igne.	 By cautery with fire.
Aut cum medicina acuta, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo cauterii.	 With a sharp medicine, as was stated in the chapter on cautery.
Aut curatur Ataxmir per incisionem et suturam.	 Ataxia is cured by incision and suture.
Aut per cannas, secundum quod ego dicam.	 By tubes, as I will explain.
Oportet ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	 It is necessary that you place the patient's head on your lap.
Deinde conuerte palpebram oculi manu tua sinistra.	 Then, turn back the eyelid of the eye with your left hand.
Si ergo conuertitur, bonum est.	 If it turns, that is good.
Et si non: intromitte acum in eam, in qua sit filum ab inferiori parte palpebrae, et fac penetrare acum cum filo desuper, et sit illud prope pilos ipsos, id est, prope marginem palpebrae, in quo nascuntur pili: et trahe filum ad superiora cum palpebra, et conuerte eam cum radio.	 If it does not, insert a needle into the eyelid from below, so that the thread runs over the needle and is close to the eyelashes themselves, that is, near the edge of the eyelid where the lashes are born; then draw the thread upwards with the eyelid, and turn it with a stick.
Deinde finde in interiori parte palpebrae sub pilis additis cum spatumili incidente a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus.	 Then find within the edge of the eyelid under the lashes, by means of a spatula introduced from the greater lacrimal duct to the lesser.
Deinde extrahe filum, et pone sub palpebra puluillum paruum ex cotto, aut panno: deinde signa super palpebram cum encaustro, quod sit sicut figura folii myrti.	 Then remove the thread and place a small piece of cotton or cloth under the eyelid; then mark on the eyelid with wax in the shape of a myrtle leaf.
Verumtamen oportet, ut fit figura secundum quantitatem et eleuationem palpebrae: quoniam iam diuersificatur illud in hominibus.	 However, it is necessary that the figure be made according to the size and elevation of the eyelid, because this varies greatly among people.
Ex eis enim est, qui indiget ut incidatur ex palpebra quantitas magna, secundum quantitatem quae mollificatur a palpebra.	 Among these is one who needs a large amount of the eyelid to be cut off, according to the size that is softened by the eyelid.
Deinde cum spatumili finde super duas lineas quas signasti, et incipe a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus, et sit fissura una prope pilos naturales, sicut est grossitudo radii.	 Then with the spatula find on the two lines that you have marked, and begin from the greater lacrimal duct to the lesser; let there be one slit near the natural lashes, as thick as a stick.
Deinde intromitte uncinum in uno duorum angulorum cutis.	 Then insert a hook into one of the two corners of the skin.  Bible
Deinde excoria ipsam totam.	 Then peel it all off.  Bible
Deinde aggrega cum sutura duo labia, cum acu et filo lana subtili: et absterge sanguinem, et fac adhaerere quod superfluit ex filis super duo supercilia, cum quibusdam rebus inuiscantibus, si uis facere illud: et si non, non cures.	 Then sew together the two lips with a needle and fine wool thread; then clean away the blood, and make the superfluous threads stick together over the two eyebrows with some adhesive substance, if you wish to do that; but if not, it is of no importance.  Bible  Bible
Deinde dimitte suturam et fila usque ad tres dies, aut quatuor: postea cura illud.	 Then leave the stitching and threads for three days, or four; afterwards care for it.
Et si uis, dimitte uulnus absque sutura, et cura ipsum cum eo, quod exsiccat et constringit.	 And if you wish, leave the wound without stitching and treat it with what dries and tightens.
Nam palpebra eleuatur apud sigillationem uulneris et aggregationem eius: sed futura est melior.	 For the eyelid is raised at the sealing of the wound and its healing; but it will be better in the future.
Hunc modum curandi Ataxmir docuerunt antiqui.	 This method of treatment ancient people taught Ataxmir.
Verumtamen in eo est sollicitudo super infirmum, et est ex bona operatione, et non est in eo timor.	 Nevertheless, there is concern for the patient in this [method], and it comes from good practice, and there is no fear [of complications] in it.
Et modus alius est in Ataxmir etiam: et est, ut signes super palpebram figuram, quae sit sicut figura folii myrti, sicut narrauimus.	 And there is another method in Ataxmir as well: and it is to make a mark on the eyelid in the shape of a myrtle leaf, as we have said.
Deinde eleua palpebram cum tribus uncinis separatis, aut aggregatis, secundum formam hanc quae sequitur, deinde incide quod superfluit cum forficibus paruis, secundum hanc formam, cum aequalitate incisionis.	 Then raise the eyelid with three separate hooks or connected together in this following shape, then cut off what is superfluous with small scissors according to this shape, maintaining equality in the cutting.  />
Si autem non est tibi possibile tenere uncinum, et non aequatur illud: tunc accipe acum in qua sit filum, et intromitte ipsum in medio figurae: et intromitte filum aliud prope lachrymale maius, et filum secundum prope lachrymale minus: et aggrega inter digitos tuos fila cum aequalitate.	 If it is not possible for you to hold the hook and make it equal, then take a needle with a thread in it and insert it into the middle of the shape; and insert another thread near the larger lacrimal [point] and a third thread near the smaller lacrimal [point]; and hold the threads together between your fingers with equality.
Deinde eleua manum tuam eleuatione aequali: et eleua cutem super quam est signatum cotum, sicut narrauimus.	 Then lift your hand with equal elevation; and lift the skin over the marked point, as we have said.  />  />  />  />
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Then join together the two lips of the wound with stitching; and treat it until it heals.
Si uero accidat apostema apud incisionem tuam, aut fissuram tuam: seda illud apostema cum caeroto, et his similibus, ex unguentis sedantibus.	 If an abscess occurs at your incision or cut; cauterize it with a hot iron and similar [substances] from the soothing ointments.
Et quandoque accidit palpebrae etiam, ut conuertantur pili eius.	 And sometimes it happens that the eyelashes of the eyelid also turn inwards.
Oportet ergo ut utaris in ea quod diximus in incisione: sed sutura utrisque magis est artificialis.	 Therefore, you should use what we have said about the incision [in this case]; but the stitching is more skillful for both [eyelids].
¶ De cura Ataxmir cum cannis.	 "On treating Ataxmîr with dogs.
ET Est, ut conuertas palpebram, et scindas fissuram quae est deintus, secundum quod narraui.	 "And you should turn the eyelid and cut the slit that is inside, as I have told you.
Deinde arte fac duas cannas, aut duo ligna subtilia: quarum longitudo sit secundum longitudinem palpebrae, et latitudo earum sit minor latitudine spatumilis: et tu iam incidisti in extremitatibus utriusque ab utrisque partibus ubi tenes fila.	 "Then skillfully make two reeds or two thin sticks: the length of which should be according to the length of the eyelid, and their width should be less than the width of the spatula; and you have already cut at the ends of each from both sides where you hold the threads.
Deinde aggrega utramque cum subtilitate super illud quod superfluit ex palpebra oculi, et stringe duas cannas ab utrisque partibus strictura forti, et dimitte eam diebus aliquot.	 "Then place each one with delicacy on the excess from the eyelid of the eye, and tie the two reeds from both sides with a strong binding, and leave it for several days.
Cutis enim stricta morietur, et denigrabitur, et putrefiet, donec cadet per se.	 "For the skin that is bound will die, blacken, and rot until it falls off by itself.
Si ergo tardatur, tunc incide eam cum forficibus.	 "If it is delayed, then cut it with scissors.
Deinde cura eam, donec sanetur.	 "Then treat it until it heals.
Cum ergo consolidatur, eleuatur palpebra: et non pungunt pili.	 "When it is healed, the eyelid will rise; and the hairs will not prick.
Et haec est forma duarum cannarum, quas facies secundum hanc figuram, et quantitatem in longitudinem et latitudinem.	 "And this is the shape of the two reeds that you make according to this figure and quantity in length and width.
¶ De eleuatione pilorum pungentium in oculo cum acu.	 "On raising the pricking hairs in the eye with a needle.
Caput XII.	 Chapter XII
Operatio in illo est, ut accipias acum subtilem, et intromittas in eam filum ex serico subtile, lene.	 "The operation in this case is to take a fine needle and insert into it a thread of fine, soft silk." ờ
Deinde aggreges extremitates eius, et nodes utramque nodo subtili ualde: et sit longitudo filorum palmus unus.	 "Then gather the ends together and tie each one with a very fine knot; and let the length of the thread be about four inches.
Deinde compone in Alinxotati filum aliud subtile sub eo in breui, et noda extremitates eius si uis.	 "Then place another fine thread under it briefly, and tie its ends if you wish.
Deinde ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo, et sit prope solem ut declaretur operatio: quoniam est operatio subtilis, uel minuta.	 "Then let the patient place his head in your lap, and let it be near sunlight to illuminate the work; for this is a delicate or fine operation.
Deinde intromitte acum cum alinxotati in radicem palpebrae, et fac eam penetrare in palpebram festinanter, donec extrahas eam desuper pilum naturalem.	 "Then insert the needle with the thread into the root of the eyelid and make it penetrate quickly into the eyelid until you extract it above the natural hair.
Deinde trahe pilum usque supra alinxotati: et intromitte in alinxotati illum pilum: si est unus, aut duo, aut tres, non plures.	 Then pull the thread up over the stitches; and introduce that thread into the stitches, if it is one, or two, or three, no more.
Deinde trahe manum tuam cum eo, donec egrediatur pilus cum alinxotati in palpebra cum pilo naturali.	 Then pull your hand with it, until the thread comes out with the stitches on the eyelid with the natural hair.
Si autem trahatur alinxotati, et non egrediatur pilus cum ea: trahes alinxotati ad inferiora, cum filo quod tu composuisti in ea, donec egrediatur alinxotati ex foramine superiori, et uideas eam uisione oculi: tunc enim trahes alinxotati, et filum: et extrahe utraque, et claude oculum: et dimitte ipsum clausum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec adhaereat pilus loco suo, et nascatur super ipsum caro.	 But if the stitches are pulled out and the thread does not come out with them, pull the stitches downwards along with the thread that you sewed into them, until the stitches come out of the upper hole, and you see it by the eye's sight; then indeed pull the stitches and the thread, and remove both, and close the eye, and leave it closed for two days or three, until the hair adheres to its place, and flesh grows over it.
Quod si pilus est breuis, tunc aut associa ei pilum longum ex pilis naturalibus, et eleuatur cum eo: aut dimitte ipsum, donec elongetur post spacium, et tunc eleua ipsum.	 But if the hair is short, then either join to it a long hair from the natural hairs and raise it with that; or leave it alone until it lengthens after some time, and then raise it up.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae accidit in palpebra superiori.	 About the care of the entropion which occurs in the upper eyelid.
Caput XIII.	 Chapter 13.
Quando accidit oculo haec Alxatrati, nominatur Leporina.	 When this entropion happens to the eye, it is called leporine.
Et haec Alxatrati est aut naturalis, aut accidentalis.	 And this entropion is either natural or accidental.
Accidentalis ergo fit ex consolidatione uulneris, aut sectionis, aut cauterii, et similium illis.	 The accidental one occurs from the healing of a wound, or a cut, or a cautery, and similar things.
Et modus operationis in ea est, ut tu findas illam consolidationem, et ut separes labia eius, et ponas in eo quod est inter ea licinium ex lino, et liges eam, donec sanetur.	 And the method of operating on it is that you cut open that healed area and separate its lips, and place between them a wick of linen, and bind it until it heals.
Et non oportet, ut utaris in curatione eius rebus quae exiccant et constringunt: nam si tu facis illud, redit Alxatrati deterior quam fuit: imo utere in ea rebus quae mollificant, sicut foenumgraecum: et embroca cum aqua, in qua cocta sit althea, semen lini: et unguento dyaquilon, quod liquefactum sit cum aliquo ex oleis: et inuolue cum eo licinium, et cura cum eo.	 And you should not use in its cure things that dry and constrict, for if you do this, the entropion returns worse than before. Indeed, use on it things that soften, such as fenugreek; and a poultice with water in which mallow, flax seed, and dyaquilon ointment melted with some of the oils have been cooked; and wrap with it a wick, and treat with it. ›
Et thesaurus curationis tuae est, ut coneris omni ingenio, ut non consolidetur, secundum formam quae fuit in primis.	 And the treasure of your treatment is that you strive with all skill, lest it consolidate according to the form which was in the first place.
Et haec quidem operatio quam diximus, non est nisi quaedam rectificatio Alxatrati, ut non redeat forma loci secundum quod fuit omnino.	 And this operation that I have mentioned is nothing but a correction of the alcatrat, so that the form of the place does not return completely to what it was before.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae fit in palpebra inferiori, et est rugatio uel contractio sursum ad dextrum et sinistrum.	 About the care for alcatrat that occurs on the lower eyelid, which is a wrinkle or contraction upward to the right and left.
Caput XIIII.	 Chapter XIV
Haec Alxatrati quae fit inferius, est quae uere nominatur Alxatrati.	 This alcatrat that occurs below is what is truly called alcatrat.
Et est naturalis, et est accidentalis.	 And it is natural and it is accidental.
Et accidentalis fit ex uulnere, aut fissura, aut cauterio, et illis similibus.	 And the accidental one occurs from a wound, or tear, or branding, and similar things.
Et uia operationis in ea est, ut accipias acum, in qua sit filum duplum, et tingas eam in carnem, et facias eam penetrare a lachrymali sinistro usque ad lachrymale dextrum, donec perueniat filum in duabus extremitatibus carnis.	 And the way to operate on it is that you take a needle in which there is a double thread, and dip it into the flesh, and make it penetrate from the left tear duct to the right tear duct, until the thread reaches both ends of the flesh.
Deinde extende carnem ad superiora cum acu, et incide eam cum spatumili lato.	 Then stretch the skin upward with a needle and cut it with a broad scalpel.  />
Si ergo redit figura palpebrae secundum quod oportet, est bonum.	 Therefore, if the shape of the eyelid returns as it should, that is good.  />
Et si non, accipe radium, et pone ipsum in fissuram, et conuerte cum eo palpebram: et finde duas fissuras in latere interiore palpebrae, et sint extremitates duarum fissurarum ex duobus angulis incisionis, donec concurrant et fiat ex eis angulus: donec quando aggregantur fiat figura earum haec figura, et est litera lauda graeca.	 And if not, take a thread and place it in the tear, and turn the eyelid with it; and find two tears on the inner side of the eyelid, and let the ends of the two tears be from the two corners of the incision until they meet and form a corner: until when they are gathered together this shape is formed, which is in the form of the Greek letter lambda.
Deinde aufer illam carnem per quantitatem, quod est latus eius acutum inferius, ab eo quod sequitur palpebram.	 Then remove that skin to the extent that its lower sharp side extends from where the eyelid follows.
Deinde aggrega partes separatas: sue eam cum filo lanae.	 Then bring together the separated parts, or sew it with a wool thread.
Deinde cura eas cum eo quod diximus, de medicinis mollificantibus, et liciniis, donec sanentur.	 Then treat them with what we have said about softening ointments and compresses until they heal.
Et si Alxatrati accidat ex fissura, et sutura, aut cauterio: tunc oportet ut findas fissura plana sub pilis palpebrarum, etiam secundum quod praecessit.	 And if it happens to the Xatrati due to a tear or stitching, or cauterization, then you should split the tear smoothly under the eyelashes, just as was mentioned before.
Deinde separa inter duo labia cum licinio, secundum quod diximus.	 Then separate between the two lips with a probe, as we have said.
Et summa sermonis de cura Alxatrati, quando est desuper, aut inferius, est, ut currat in ea operatio, secundum quod praeparatur ex forma Alxatrati.	 And the main point about caring for the Xatrati, whether it is above or below, is that the operation should proceed according to the form of the Xatrati.
Ipsa namque est multarum diuersitatum in forma: et artifex prudens praeparat ingenium cum quocunque modo est possibile ei, donec redire faciat figuram ad formam naturalem, aut prope eam, et ipsemet infirmus, secundum quod conuenit ei ex operatione et instrumentis in plurimis dispositionibus.	 For it is of many different forms: and a skilled craftsman prepares his ingenuity in whatever way is possible for him, until he makes the figure return to its natural form or very close to it, and the patient himself, according to what suits him from the operation and instruments in numerous arrangements.
¶ De adhaerentia palpebrae oculi cum coniunctiua, aut cornea.	 About the adherence of the eyelid to the conjunctiva or cornea.
Caput XV.	 Chapter 15.
Quandoque accidit haec consolidatio multis hominibus, ita ut consolidetur palpebra superior cum albedine oculi, et prohibeat ipsum ab operationibus suis naturalibus.	 It sometimes happens to many people that the upper eyelid adheres to the white of the eye and prevents it from performing its natural functions.
Oportet ergo quod intromittas extremitatem radii sub palpebra, et eleues eam sursum: aut extendas eam cum uncino: deinde incide adhaerentiam cum spatumili subtili, quod non sit cum acuitate incisionis spatumilium, imo sit obtusum parumper: ut non inquietetur infirmus apud operationem, et remoueatur spatumile, et laedat oculum cum acuitate sua: et sit incisio tua quasi tu excories illam adhaerentiam cum facilitate, donec quando redit palpebra secundum formam suam naturalem, et sanetur adhaerentia tota.	 Therefore, you should insert the tip of a probe under the eyelid and lift it up, or extend it with a hook; then cut the adhesion with a fine spatula that is not sharp like other spatulas, but rather blunt slightly, so that the patient is not disturbed during the operation, and the spatula is removed and does not harm the eye with its sharpness. And your incision should be as if you were easily excising that adhesion until, when the eyelid returns to its natural form, the entire adhesion heals.
Funde tunc in oculum aquam salsam, cum aqua ablue ipsum: aut distilla in ipsum ex sief facto, ex ziniar dissoluto cum aqua.	 Then irrigate the eye with salty water and wash it with plain water, or distill into it from a sieve made of crushed juniper berries mixed with water.
Deinde separa inter palpebram et oculum cum licinio lini: et pone super oculum lanam infusam cum albugine oui: et post diem tertium utere sief, et cum solidatiuis, donec sanetur.	 Then separate the eyelid from the eye with a linen probe. And place over the eye a wool compress soaked in egg white. And on the third day use a sieve and patches until it heals.
¶ De incisione ungulae et eminentiae carnis lachrymarum.	 Of the incision of the nail and prominence of the tear-duct flesh.
Caput XVI.	 Chapter XVI.
Scias, quod ungula est secundum duos modos.	 Know that the nail is according to two modes.
Aut est neruosa: et est similis sifac duro, subtili.	 Or it is sinew-like, and it is similar to silica, hard and fine. 》
Aut est non neruosa, similis humiditati congelatae albae: quae quando tangit cam ferrum, aut conaris capere eam cum uncino, abscinditur, et non figitur in ea uncinus.	 Or it is not sinew-like, similar to frozen white moisture; when you touch it with iron or try to grasp it with a hook, it breaks off and the hook does not stick into it.
Et utraeque species non incipiunt, nisi a lachrymali maiore, usquequo uadit paulatim, donec cooperit uisum, et prohibet lumen, et motum oculi.	 And both types do not grow except from the larger tear-duct, until it gradually reaches the eye and covers the sight, blocking light and the movement of the eye.
Et modus operandi in incisione eius est: ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	 And the way to operate in its incision is that the patient places his head in your bosom. 》 》 》 》 》 》 》 》 》 》 》 》 》
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et eleua palpebram manu tua.	 Then open the patient's eyes and lift the eyelid with your hand.
Deinde collige ungulam cum uncino paucae duplationis, et extende eam ad superiora.	 Then collect the nail with a small hook and extend it upwards.
