Si uero corruptio est in continuatione duarum iuncturarum, tunc non est in ea ingenium nisi abrasio.	 However, if corruption is between two joints, then there is no skill in that except to scrape it off.
Quod si corruptio est in pectine manus, aut in pectine pedis: tunc res in eo est difficilis ualde.	 But if corruption is in the comb of the hand or the comb of the foot, then the matter is very difficult.
Verum oportet, ut inquiras corruptionem qualiter appareat tibi.	 Indeed, you must examine how the corruption appears to you.
Et abradas eam, et mundes ipsam secundum quamcunque dispositionem tibi possibile est, et cum quocunque ingenio rectificatur tibi: quando non facit tibi contrarietatem Vena, aut Neruus.	 And scrape it off, and clean it as best you can with whatever skill is available to you: when the vein or nerve does not work against you.
Et scias quod incisoria, et Serrae ad incidendum ista ossa sunt multa, secundum situm ossium, et praparationem eorum, et ipsorum grossitudinem, et subtilitatem eorum, et magnitudinem, et paruitatem ipsorum, et duriciem ipsorum, et eorum raritatem.	 And know that there are many different cutting tools and saws for cutting these bones, depending on the position of the bones, their preparation, their thickness or thinness, size, smallness, hardness, and softness.
Quapropter oportet, ut praepares omni speciei operationis instrumentum conueniens ad illam operationem.	 Therefore, it is necessary to prepare a suitable tool for each type of operation.
Et scias, quod operationes istae significant tibi super speciem instrumenti quo indiges, quando tecum est studium longum.	 And know that these operations indicate to you the kind of tool you need when your study is prolonged.  />
Et cognitio modorum huius artis, testimonium modorum aegritudinum: tunc enim iam inuenies per teipsum illud quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis ad omnem infirmitatem.	 And the knowledge of the methods of this art is a witness to the methods of diseases, then indeed you will find through yourself what suits it from the instruments for every ailment.
Et ego sum firmans tibi in ultimo huius capituli numerum instrumentorum, quae pones exempla super quae incides, et probationem qua experiaris super alia.	 And I assure you at the end of this chapter the number of instruments that you will use as examples for what you cut, and a test by which you try others.
Forma Serrae.	 The shape of the saw.
Forma alterius Serrae.	 The shape of another saw.
Forma Serrae alterius.	 The shape of yet another saw.
Forma Serrae alterius.	 The shape of another saw.
Haec forma Serrae depicta, sit decenter facta.	 This form of the saw is depicted, let it be done neatly.
Fiat arcus eius superior, acuitas eius ex ferro: et manubrium eius ex buxo, et sit pyramidale decenter factum.	 Let its upper part be a bow made of iron and its handle made of boxwood, let it be neatly shaped into a pyramid.
Forma Rasorii iuncturarum.	 The form of the knife for joints.
Sit caput huius Rasorii, secundum formam capitis claui stellati: et puncta eius sint secundum formam punctorum elischetfegi.	 Let the head of this knife be in the shape of a star-headed nail: and its points should be in the shape of the points of the elischetfegi.
Et non conuenit, nisi ut fricentur cum eo capita iuncturarum, quando corrumpuntur, aut os amplum, et magnum est.	 And it is not suitable except to smooth the heads of joints when they are injured, whether a large or great bone is present.
Forma maioris Rasorii.	 The form of the larger knife.
Forma medii Rasorii.	 The form of the medium-sized knife.
Forma Rasorii lati.	 The form of the broad knife.
Forma Rasorii in quo est concauitas.	 The form of the knife which has a concavity.
Forma Rasorii alterius subtilis.	 The form of another fine knife.
Forma Rasorii alterius curuatae extremitatis.	 The form of another knife with a curved tip.
Forma Rasorii parui, subtilis tentae.	 The form of the small and delicate needle-like knife.
Forma Rasorii cum quo inciduntur ossa.	 The form of the knife with which bones are cut.
Forma etiam Rasorii magni.	 Also, the form of the large knife.
Hoc similatur Radio, et extremitas est sicut Serra: exhibetur in locis multis ex rasione ossium.	 This resembles a file, and its tip is like a saw; it is used in many places for the sake of cutting bones. xspace
Forma Rasorii quod conuenit ad rasionem eius quod perforatum est ex ossibus.	 The form of the knife suitable for removing that which has been perforated from the bone.
Extremitas eius triangula, acutarum est extremitatum.	 Its tip is triangular and its points are sharp.
Fit ex Indi.	 It is made of iron.
Et similiter oportet, ut fiant omnia quae diximus ex Rasoriis, et Incisoriis, et Serris.	 And similarly, all that we have mentioned should be made from knives and saws.
¶ De incisione extremitatum, et Serratura ossium.	 ¶ On the cutting of tips and sawing of bones.
Caput LXXXIX.	 Chapter 89.
Putrefiunt extremitates, aut ex caussa extrinseca, aut intrinseca.	 The tips become putrid either from an external cause or from an internal one.  /> Caput XC.
Cum ergo medicatus fueris illam corruptionem curatione medicinarum, et non confert curatio: et uides corruptionem incidere in membrum, quam non repercutit aliquid: tunc oportet ut incidas illud membrum usque ubi consequitu corruptio, ut euadat infirmus per illud a morte, aut a malicia quae est maior defectu membri.	 Therefore, when you have treated that putrefaction with medicines and the treatment does not help, and you see the putrefaction spread into a limb which is not affected by anything else: then it is necessary for you to cut off that limb up to where the putrefaction has reached, so that the patient may escape from death or from the greater evil of loss of the limb.
Et signum cui accidit illud est, quod denigratur membrum, donec putetur: quod ignis combussit ipsum, aut putrefit post nigredinem: donec inciditur illa putredo usque ad illud quod sequitur illud membrum, et serpit in totum corpus.	 And the sign of that which occurs is that the member darkens until it appears to be burnt by fire or decayed after blackening; until that decay spreads to the point where it follows that member and creeps throughout the whole body.
Propera ergo cum incisione eius, et similiter si caussa corruptionis est a percussione quorundam uenenosorum: sicut scorpionis marini, et uiperae, et rutellae, et similium.	 Therefore, hasten with its incision, and similarly if the cause of decay is from the bite of certain venomous creatures, such as the marine scorpion, viper, or asp, and similar ones.
Si ergo corruptio, aut percussio est in extremitate digiti, tunc incide digitum, et non des spacium corruptioni, ut incedat usque ad reliquam manum.	 If therefore the decay or bite is on the tip of a finger, then cut off the finger, and do not leave space for the decay to advance to the rest of the hand.
Et similiter si accidit in manu, tunc incide eam ex radice focilis, et non des spacium corruptioni, donec capiat in focili brachii.	 And similarly, if it occurs on the hand, then cut it off at the root of the wrist, and do not leave space for the decay to reach the forearm.
Et si inuadit in eo, tunc incide brachium apud cubitum in iunctura sua.	 And if it invades that [forearm], then cut off the arm at the elbow joint.
Si autem pertransit corruptio, et uides eum circiter cubitum: tunc in illo est mors infirmi.	 If, however, the decay passes through and you see it around the elbow, then death is certain for the patient.
Et administrare praeter illud ex curatione, est quantitas uirtus.	 And beyond that, administering from the treatment is a matter of skill.
Et similiter fac de pede, quando inuadit corruptio in digito, tunc incide ipsum apud unum nodorum: et si capit in pectine pedis, tunc incide pedem totum.	 And similarly, do the same with the foot when decay invades a toe; then cut it off at one of the joints. If it reaches the sole of the foot, then cut off the entire foot.
Si autem ascendit ad genu, tunc incide crus apud iuncturam genu.	 If it however advances to the knee, then cut off the leg at the knee joint.
Quod si corruptio iam peruenit supra genu, tunc non est in ea ingenium, nisi dimissio, et relinquere infirmum morti.	 When decay has already reached above the knee, then there is no skill [to save him], except to abandon and leave the patient to death.
Et modus incidendi membrum, aut serrandi ipsum est, ut stringas ligamentum in inferiori, quem uis incidere: et stringe ligamentum aliud supra locum.	 And the method of cutting or sawing a member is to tie a ligature below the place you wish to cut and tie another ligature above that place.
Et extendat minister ligamentum unum ad inferiora: et extendat minister aliud ligamentum superius ad sursum.	 And let one assistant pull the lower ligature downward, and let another assistant pull the upper ligature upward.
Et tu separa carnem quae est inter duo ligamenta, cum Spatumili lato, donec detegatur caro tota.	 And you separate the flesh that is between the two ligatures with a broad scalpel until all the flesh is laid bare.
Deinde incidatur, aut serretur.	 Then it should be cut or sewn.
Et oportet, ut ponas ab omnibus partibus pannum lini, et non tangat Serra locum sanum: et accidat infirmo laesio addita, et apostema calidum.	 And you should place a cloth of linen over all parts, so that the saw does not touch the healthy area; and it may happen that an additional injury is inflicted on the sick person, and a hot abscess forms.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis interius dum operaris, tunc cauteriza locum uelociter: aut pone super ipsum quosdam pulueres abscindentes sanguinem.	 But if bleeding occurs internally while you are operating, then quickly cauterize the area, or place some powders that absorb blood on it.
Deinde redi ad medicationem tuam, donec compleatur.	 Then return to your treatment until it is completed.
Deinde liga membrum uulneratum cum ligamento conueniente ei, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Then bind the wounded limb with a suitable bandage and care for it until it heals.
Et ego narro tibi quod accidit uiro in pede suo, hoc idem accidens quod narro tibi.	 And I tell you that this happened to a man on his foot, the same event as I am telling you.
Quod est, quia accidit in pede suo nigredo, cum adustione quae assimilatur combustioni ignis: et corruptio illa in primis accidit in digito suo, donec coepit pedem totum.	 Which is to say that a blackening occurred on his foot, similar to the burning of fire; and this corruption first began in his toe until it spread to his entire foot.
Properauit ergo uir ex seipso, postquam uidit corruptionem incidere in membro cum uehementia eius, quod inuenit ex dolore, et adustione eius: et incidit ipsum apud iuncturam, et sanatus est.	 Therefore the man hastened to cut himself off, after he saw that the corruption was advancing into his limb with great intensity, which he found from the pain and burning of it; and he cut himself at the joint, and he was healed.
Et postquam praeteriit ei tempus longum, accidit ei illa eadem corruptio in digito manus suae indice.	 And after a long time had passed, that same corruption occurred in his index finger of his hand.
Venit ergo ad me, et conatus sum recuperare illam superfluitatem cum eo quod posui super manum ex medicinis post mundificationem corporis eius: et non repercussa est superfluitas, et coepit incedere in digitum alium: donec coepit coruptio in manum.	 So he came to me, and I tried to draw out that excess with the ointment I placed on his hand after cleansing his body; but the swelling did not subside, and began spreading to another finger until the corruption spread to the whole hand.
Vocauit ergo me, ad incidendum manum eius: et nolui illud, sperans ex me super repercussionem illius superfluitatis: et timui etiam super ipsum apud incisionem manus eius mortem.	 So he called upon me to cut off his hand; and I refused, hoping for the subsiding of that swelling from me; and I also feared death at cutting off his hand. ➤
Quoniam uirtus uiri erat super casum.	 Because the man's strength was greater than the condition.
Postquam ergo desperauit de me, reuersus est ad terram suam: et peruenit ad me de eo, quia properauit, et incidit manum suam totam: et sanatus est.	 So after he despaired of me, he returned to his own land; and news came to me about him that he had hastened and cut off his whole hand; and he was healed.
Et non attuli hanc narrationem, nisi ut sit adiutorium super illud quod cadit de genere huius aegritudinis: et ut sit significatio qua significetur, et secundum quam agatur.	 And I did not bring forward this narrative except to be of assistance concerning that which falls under the category of this illness: and so that it may serve as a signifier by which is indicated, and according to which one should act.
¶ De cura Sinuum, et qualitate clisterizationis cum medicinis.	 About caring for the sinuses, and the quality of enema administration with medications.
Caput XC.	 Chapter 90
Quando accidit apostema in quibusdam membris carnosis, et prolongatur spacium apostematis, donec collectionem facit saniei: deinde rumpitur, aut perforatur, et egreditur quod in eo est ex sanie, et remanet locus uacuus quasi sit uas: et cutis quae est super ipsum sicut pannus qui iam subtiliatus est: et non peruenit ad ultimum in corruptione sua, neque imprimit in os, neque in neruum, neque in ligamentum: meretur ut nominetur Sinus: et non nominatur Fistula: uerumtamen si prolongatur spacium eius, donec imprimat corruptio in aliquid horum membrorum, tunc nominatur Fistula, aut zuken.	 When an abscess occurs in some fleshy members and the space of the abscess is prolonged until it forms a collection of pus: then it bursts or perforates, and what is within it comes out as pus, and the place remains empty like a vessel: and the skin that is above it is like a cloth that has already been made thin: and it does not reach to the end in its corruption, neither imprinting on a bone, nor on a nerve, nor on a ligament: it deserves to be called a Sinus; and it is not called a Fistula. However, if its space is prolonged until the corruption imprints on any of these members, then it is called a Fistula or fistula.
Et cura eius est, ut incidas illam cutem totam sicut reuoluitur: et praecipue quando subtiliata est, et facta sicut pannus: et confidis quia non aaehaeret cum loco, propter corruptionem suam.	 And its treatment is that you should cut off all that skin as if you were rolling it up: and especially when it has been made thin, like a cloth: and you trust that it does not adhere to the place because of its corruption.
Si autem speras quod adhaereat cutis, et non consequitur ex eo corruptio illa ultima consecutione: et si in cute est spissitudo ex carne, tunc cura ipsum cum Clisteri: et est, ut consideres ad Sinum.	 But if you hope that the skin adheres, and it does not follow from this final corruption; and if there is thickness in the skin of flesh, then treat it with an enema: and it is as if for a sinus.
Tunc si est magnus, et pus quod emittitur ex eo est foetidi odoris: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum medicamine aegyptio, quod est aceti, et olei, et ziniar, partes recipiens aequales, aggregentur in uase: et decoquantur super ignem, donec rubeat medicamen: et ueniat in spissitudinem mellis.	 Then if it is large, and the pus that comes out of it has a foul odor: then enema it with Egyptian medication, which is vinegar, oil, and sumac, receiving equal parts, gathered together in a vessel; and boil them over fire until the medication becomes red: and reaches the consistency of honey.
Deinde accipe ex eo quod tibi necesse est: et dissolue ipsum cum aqua et melle, et clisteriza cum eo Sinum: et stringe orificium eius, et dimitte medicinam in eo ad quantitatem duarum horarum.	 Then take what you need from it, dissolve it with water and honey, and use this mixture as an enema for the bladder; then tie off its opening and leave the medicine inside for two hours.
Deinde extrahe ipsum cum expressione: fac illud diebus tot, donec mundificetur Sinus, et remoueatur foetor.	 Then draw it out with a suppository. Do this for as many days as are necessary until the bladder is cleansed and the stench removed.
Et quandoque clisterizatur cum aqua cineris, quando non est tibi praesens hoc medicamen: et est, ut accipias cinerem lignorum uitis, aut cinerem ex lignis ilicis: et proiicias super eam aquam.	 And sometimes it should be irrigated with ashes water when this medicine is not available to you. Take the ashes of vine wood or holm oak wood and pour them over the water.
Deinde cola eam, et clisteriza cum ea, donec confidas quod Sinus iam ablutus est.	 Then strain it and use it for an enema until you are confident that the bladder is now clean.
Quod si infirmo non est tolerantia super medicamen aegyptium, neque aquam cineris, tunc clisteriza ipsum cum aqua et melle, cui iam permixtum est aliquid ex ziniar contrito.	 But if the patient cannot bear the Egyptian medicine or ashes water, then use an enema of water and honey into which some powdered ginger has already been mixed.
Aut clisteriza ipsum cum melle et uino permixtis, quoniam de proprietate mellis est, ut mundificet, et abluat: et uinum facit adhaerere Sinum, praecipue quando in uino est superfluitas stipticitatis et siccitatis.	 Or irrigate it with a mixture of honey and wine, because it is the nature of honey to cleanse and wash, and wine causes the bladder to adhere, especially when the wine is somewhat astringent and dry.
Cum facis illud aliquotiens, et confidis quod Sinus corruptio iam remota est: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum eo quod facit nasci carnem in eo.	 When you have done this several times and are confident that the corruption of the bladder has been removed, then irrigate it with what causes flesh to grow there.
Et est, ut accipias ex emplastro dyafinicon: et dissoluas ipsum cum oleo rosato, et uino stiptico: aut clisteriza ipsum cum quibusdam medicinis, et unguentis aliis, quorum proprietates scripsi in tractatu unguentorum.	 And this is done by taking some diachylon plaster and dissolving it with rose oil and astringent wine; or you can irrigate it with certain other medicines and ointments whose properties I have written about in the treatise on ointments.
Quod si orificium Sinus est strictum, in quo non capit cannula clisteris: tunc amplifica ipsum cum ferro parumper: aut pone in ipso licinium inuolutum in unguento aegyptio, aut in unguento basilicon, donec amplificetur.	 But if the opening of the bladder is too narrow to accept an enema cannula, then dilate it briefly with an iron instrument; or insert into it a tampon wrapped in Egyptian ointment or basilicum ointment until it is sufficiently dilated.
Et similiter si est orificium etiam amplum, tunc aggrega labia eius cum sutura: et dimitte ex eo quantitatem in quam ingrediatur clistere sine additione.	 And similarly, if the opening is also large, then gather its lips with a stitch; and leave from it the amount into which a clyster may enter without addition.
Et similiter si orificium eius ex quo currit pus, est eleuatum ad superiora: tunc seca ipsum in depressiori loco qui est in ipso, ut currat ex eo pus usque inferius: quoniam pus quando coartatur in profunditate Sinus, prohibet carnem generari in eo.	 And similarly, if the opening from which the pus flows is elevated upwards; then cut into it in the deeper part that is within it, so that the pus may flow downwards: for when pus is constricted in the depth of the Sinus, it prevents flesh from growing there.
Quod si non est tibi possibile secare Sinum circiter inferius eius secundum quod uis: tunc conare, ut praepares membrum praeparatione qua currat ex eo pus cum facilitate secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	 If it is not possible for you to cut the Sinus lower as you wish; then strive to prepare the membrane with a preparation that allows the pus to flow easily according to how it is prepared for you.
Conare, ut non retineatur in eo aliquid ex pus omnino: et accipe medicinas consolidatiuas quae ponuntur super signum, conuenientes ad illud quod uis.	 Strive that nothing at all of the pus be retained within it; and take healing ointments which are applied to the wound, suitable for what you wish.
Et extende eas super pannum lini.	 And spread them on a linen cloth.
Et sit pannus tantae quantitatis, qua fiat communicatio totius Sinus.	 And let the cloth be of such size that it may cover the entire Sinus.
Deinde incide cum forficibus in directo orificii Sinus foramen, amplius orificio Sinus parumper.	 Then cut with scissors a hole directly in the orifice of the Sinus, a little wider than the orifice of the Sinus.
Deinde extende ex unguentis lenibus super pannum alium, secundum quantitatem foraminis: et pone eum super ipsum positione longinqua ab orificio Sinus, ut alleuietur exitus pus ex eo: et non auferas pannum magnum, nisi post dies aliquos uice una.	 Then spread gentle ointments on another cloth according to the size of the hole; and place it over the Sinus, distant from its orifice, so that the exit of the pus from it may be relieved; and do not remove the large cloth, except after a few days once.
Ille autem qui est super orificium Sinus, est ille quem remoues in omni hora, ut egrediatur quod aggregatur in eo ex pus: et ut scias, an illud quod currit ex eo uirus, est multum, aut parum: aut digestum, aut indigestum.	 But the one that is over the orifice of the Sinus; it is this one which you remove in every hour, so that what accumulates within it from pus may exit; and so that you may know whether that which flows out of it is much or little; or digested or undigested.
Et cum hoc iterum considera locum Sinus ipsius, an in ipso sentiat dominus eius dolorem, aut non sit in eo dolor, et an sit in eo apostema, aut non sit in eo apostema.	 And with this again consider the place of the Sinus itself; whether the master of it feels pain within it, or if there is no pain in it, and whether there is a swelling within it, or if there is no swelling in it.
Cum ergo protenditur medicatio tua taliter, et uides materiam quae egreditur super orificium Sinus, tunc scias, quod Sinus iam adhaeret, aut approximat adhaerentiae: tunc ergo solue ipsum in mane, aut in tertio die: et quando soluis uulnus, tunc permuta pannum alium, et renoua unguentum.	 When your treatment is extended in this manner and you see the material exiting from the opening of the sinus, then know that the sinus has adhered or is approaching adhesion; therefore, dissolve it in the morning or on the third day. And when you dissolve the wound, then change the cloth for another one and renew the ointment.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post spacium longum uirus subtile, tunc non desperes de adhaerentia eius, nam sanatio eius appropinquat, quoniam ex hominibus sunt qui tardant generationem carnis in uulneribus suis, et ex eis sunt qui agunt econtrario illius.	 But if a thin pus exits from the sinus after a long period, then do not despair of its adhesion, for its healing is approaching, since there are people who slow down the growth of flesh in their wounds, and there are those who act contrary to that.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post dies multos pus indigestum, tunc scias quod sinus non adhaeret.	 But if after many days an undigested pus exits from the sinus, then know that the sinus has not adhered.
Si ergo tardatur adhaerentia Sinus, et prolongatur res eius: tunc adde in exiccatione medicinarum, uerum faciant medici, ut sint medicinae in substantia sua humidae, et in uirtute sua siccae: sicut unguentum dyafinicon, quando additur in eo superfluitas additionis ex zegi.	 If therefore the adhesion of the sinus is delayed and its course prolonged, then add to the drying of medicines; but let the physicians make sure that the medicines are humid in their substance and dry in their power, like the ointment called dyafinicon when a superfluous amount of egg is added.
Et ex magis ultimo quo curatur, est, ut accipias unguentum dyafinicon, et soluatur cum oleo rosato, et roretur super ipsum uinum antiquum aequale in substantia sua.	 And from the above-mentioned treatment, it is that you should take the ointment called dyafinicon and dissolve it with rose oil, and pour over it an equal amount of old wine in its substance.
Deinde confice ipsum cum eo, et utere ipso.	 Then prepare it with this, and use it.
Et iam facit simile huic actioni, quando non est tibi praesens unguentum dyafinicon, mel, quando decoquis ipsum, donec ingrossetur, et uteris eo.	 And now perform a similar action when you do not have the ointment called dyafinicon present; for honey, when you boil it until it thickens, and use it.
Aut accipe myrrham, et aloen, et olibanum: tere totum, et pulueriza illud super mel dum est super ignem.	 Or take myrrh, aloe, and frankincense; grind all of them together and powder it over the honey while it is on the fire.
Deinde line super ipsum pannum, et stringe ipsum super Sinum: et line cum melle quod decoquisti, donec ingrossatum est: et pulueriza super ipsum species, et pone super ipsum pannum, et stringe eum.	 Then line it with a cloth and tie it over the sinus; and line it with the honey you have boiled until it thickens, and powder over it spices, and place a cloth over it, and tie it.  ///
Et quandoque administratur in illo aristolochia longa, et radices lilii coelestis, et est lilium: et farina herbi, et centaurea.	 And sometimes it is given with long birthwort, and root of the heavenly lily, and lily: and flour of the herb, and centaurie.
Utere eis simplicibus, aut aggregatis, tere ea, et cribella ipsa: et pulueriza super mel quod narraui, et utere eo.	 Use them either as simples or mixed together; pound them and sift them; then powderize over the honey I mentioned, and use it.
Quod si prolongatur res Sinus, et non sanatur hac curatione: tunc scias, quod in profundo eius est corruptio: aut iam facit impressionem in ossibus, aut in reliquis membris duris, aut ligamentis: tunc cura ipsum curatione Fistularum, secundum quod praemissum est.	 But if the abscess is prolonged and does not heal with this treatment, then know that there is a corruption in its depth; either it is already making an impression on the bones, or on the other hard members, or on the ligaments; then treat it with the treatment of fistulas, as has been mentioned before.  /> 133
¶ De cura Panaritii et unguis attritae, et incisione digiti additi, et sectione.	 On the care of a whitlow and crushed nail, and the cutting of the finger, and its sectioning.
Caput XCI.	 Chapter 90
Panaritium est apostema quod nascitur sub ungue pollicis manus, aut pedis: et fortasse nascitur in reliquis digitis.	 A whitlow is an abscess that arises under the thumbnail of the hand or foot; and perhaps it can arise in the other fingers as well.
Cum ergo prolongatur res eius, et negligitur curato eius, et apostematur apostemate calido: aut corrumpitur, et emittit pus, donec corrodit radicem unguis: et fortasse corrumpit eam totam, et fortasse peruenit corruptio ad os, donec est ei odor foetidus: et fit extremitas digiti lata, et fit color eius fuscus.	 But when the abscess is prolonged and its treatment is neglected and it becomes a hot abscess; or it is corrupted and emits pus until it gnaws at the root of the nail; and perhaps it corrupts it entirely, and perhaps the corruption reaches the bone, so that there is a foul odor; and the tip of the finger becomes swollen, and its color becomes dark.
Quando ergo tu curas ipsum, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut incidas cum ferro totam superfluitatem quae remansit ex ungue.	 Therefore, when you treat it with what we said in the section on division, and your treatment is not effective; then you must cut off with a knife all the remaining excess from the nail.
Deinde cauteriza uulnus post illud.	 Then cauterize the wound after that.
Cauterium enim iuuatiuum est ualde.	 For cautery is very beneficial.  /> 135 
Si uero os est sanum, et est unguis etiam sana, et additiones uacuae unguis iam comprimunt carnem ad interiora, et incipiunt pungere ipsam, et laedunt eam: tunc oportet ut ponas Radium subtilem sub angulo unguis quae pungit carnem, et impelle eam sursum: et incide eam carnem cum facilitate, et pone super illud quod remanet de carne ex medicinis comburentibus, corrosiuis, donec remoueatur totum eius.	 But if the bone is healthy and the nail is also healthy, and the additions of the nail now press the flesh inward and begin to prick it and hurt it; then you must place a fine wire under the corner of the nail that pricks the flesh, and push it upwards; and cut off that part of the flesh with ease, and put on what remains of the medicinal substances that burn and corrode until all of it is removed.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	 Then care for it with ointments until it heals.
Si autem corruptio iam imprimit in os, tunc oportet ut incidas illud os, et extrahas ipsum: non enim sanatur unquam dum permanet in eo os corruptum.	 But if the corruption has already begun in the ulcer, then it is necessary that you cut into that ulcer and remove it; for it will never heal as long as there remains a corrupted ulcer within it.
Quod si uides corrosionem et corruptionem incedere in digitum, tunc incide eum in uno nodorum, secundum quod praemissa est eius rememoratio.	 If you see the gangrene and corruption advancing into the finger, then cut it at one of its joints, as was mentioned earlier in its description.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Then care for it until it heals.
Si autem accidat ungui attritio, aut percussio: et contingit in ea dolor uehemens, tunc oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	 But if it happens that the nail is worn down or struck: and there arises a severe pain from it, then it is necessary to bleed the patient first.
Deinde seca unguem cum Spatumili acuto sectione transuersa de sursum ad uisum.	 Then cut the nail with an acutely pointed spatula, making a transverse section from top to bottom as you see fit.
Et custodi, ne sectio perueniat ad carnem quae est sub ungue, nam tu facies accidere per illud super infirmum dolorem uehementem, et erit caussa ad natiuitatem carnis additae in loco.	 And take care that the section does not reach the flesh beneath the nail, for you will cause a very severe pain to occur through this over the patient, and there will be an additional cause of scarring in that place.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod sedat dolores.	 Then care for the place with something that soothes the pains.
Digitus uero additus qui nascitur in quibusdam manibus hominum, fortasse est carnosus totus: et fortasse sunt in quibusdam eorum ossa, et fortasse est in eo unguis: et quidam eorum nascitur in radice iuncturae, aut est natiuitas eius in quibusdam nodis digiti.	 But the extra finger that is born in some people's hands is perhaps entirely fleshy; and perhaps there are bones in some of them, and perhaps there is a nail on it; and sometimes it is born at the root of the joint, or its birth is in some of the finger's joints.
Ille ergo qui nascitur in quibusdam nodis digiti, non mouetur: et ille qui nascitur apud iuncturam digiti, fortasse mouetur.	 Therefore, that which is born in some of the finger's joints does not move; and that which is born at the finger's joint, perhaps moves.
Eius ergo qui ex eis est carnosus, sectio eius facilis est.	 The section of those which are fleshy is easy.
Quod est, ut incidas ipsum apud radicem suam cum Spatumili lato.	 Which is to say: cut it at its root with a broad spatula.  /> Et sic de iuncturae addita: et similiter quae sunt in manibus aliorum, et est eisdem remediis curanda, et idem est modus curandi eorum.
Eius autem cuius natiuitas est in radice iuncturae curatio, est difficilis.	 However, the cure for that whose birth is at the root of the joint is difficult.
Abstine ergo ab incisione eius.	 Avoid cutting it.
In illo uero qui nascitur in digito apud ultimum nodorum, tunc oportet ut incidas in primis carnem eius incisione rotunda usque ad os.	 But if it is born on a finger at the last joint, then you should cut its flesh with a round incision right up to the bone.
Deinde serra os cum una illarum Serrarum conuenientium ad illud.	 Then saw the bone with one of those suitable saws for it.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Then care for it until it heals.
Consolidatio autem quae accidit digitis adinuicem, multotiens accidit aut ex natiuitate hominis, id est, nascitur cum eo, aut a consolidatione uulneris, aut combustione ignis, et similibus.	 A contraction that occurs between fingers can often happen due to a birth defect, that is, it is born with it, or from the healing of a wound, or a burn from fire, and similar causes.  />
Oportet ergo ut seces illam consolidationem, donec redeant digiti secundum formam suam naturalem.	 Therefore, you must cut away that contraction until the fingers return to their natural shape.
Deinde pone inter eos licinia, aut pannos infusos in oleo rosato: ut non consolidentur uelociter, et separa inter eos: aut pone inter eos laminam plumbi subtilem, donec consolidetur locus secundum quod oportet.	 Then place between them bandages or cloths soaked in rose oil, so that they do not quickly heal together, and separate them; or place between them a thin sheet of lead until the place heals as it should.
Et similiter si accidat consolidatio quibusdam digitis cum palma, tunc seca illam consolidationem, secundum quod praeparatur et conuenit figurae membri.	 And similarly, if a contraction occurs between some fingers and the palm, then cut away that contraction according to what is prepared and suitable for the shape of the limb.
¶ De incisione Vitium.	 ¶ On the incision of a tumor.
Caput XCII.	 Chapter 92.
Uites sunt Venae inuolutae, grossae, plenae superfluitatibus melancholicis quae accidunt in pluribus membris corporis: et plurimum euentus earum est in cruribus, praecipue in cruribus iter agentium et laborantium, et portantium.	 Veins are swollen, thick, full of melancholic excesses that occur in many parts of the body; and most of their occurrences are in the legs, especially in the legs of travelers and workers and bearers.
Oportet ergo ut administres excussionem corporis ex cholera nigra aliquotiens excussione forti.	 Therefore, you must administer a purgative made from black bile several times with a strong laxative.
Deinde phlebotoma patientis eas basilicam.	 Then bleed the patient from those veins.
Curatio uero earum cum ferro, est secundum duos modos.	 Their treatment with iron is in two ways.  /> ● If it is on a small part of the body or not very swollen: then incise it gently, and extract what is inside it, and cauterize it so that it does not swell again.  /> ● But if it is large or very swollen: then cut away its skin, and take out what is in it, and stitch up the wound with silk thread until the swelling goes down. 》
Vnus eorum est, ut secentur, et extrahatur sanguis niger.	 One of these methods is to cut them open and extract the black blood.
Et modus alter est, ut eleuetur Vena, et extrahatur tota.	 And another method is to lift the vein and remove it entirely.
Sectio uero eius est secundum hunc modum.	 Its section is according to this manner.
Embroca crus in primis cum aqua calida multum, donec resoluatur sanguis grossus faeculentus.	 First, soak the leg with very hot water until the thick and feculent blood dissolves.
Deinde stringe crus infirmi a superiori parte coxae eius, usque ad inferiorem partem genu cum uitta.	 Then tie off the patient's leg from the top of the thigh to below the knee with a bandage.
Deinde seca uenam in loco uno, aut duobus, aut tribus sectione ampla.	 Then cut the vein in one place, or two, or three, with a wide incision.
Deinde eleua, id est, extrahe sanguinem in manu tua ab inferiori parte cruris, usque ad sursum, et a superiori oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	 Then lift, that is, draw out the blood into your hand from the lower part of the leg up to the top, and first of all, let the phlebotomist bleed the patient.
Deinde seca unguem cum usque inferius: donec egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uides sufficere, et quam tolerat uirtus infirmi.	 Then cut the nail along with it below: until enough blood comes out as you see fit and which the patient's strength can bear.
Postea liga eam: et praecipe ei, ut abstineat a cibis generantibus choleram nigram: et itera euacuationem et phlebotomiam, quando implentur Venae, et nocet illud infirmo.	 Afterwards, tie it off and instruct the patient to abstain from foods that generate black bile. Repeat the evacuation and bloodletting whenever the veins are full and it harms the patient.
Eleuatio autem eius est secundum hunc modum.	 Its lifting is according to this manner.
Rade crus infirmi, si in ea sunt pili multi.	 Shave the leg of the patient if it has many hairs.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in balneum: aut embroca ipsum in crure eius cum aqua calida, donec rubeat, et exuberentur Venae: aut exercitetur exercitio forti, si non est ei praesens balneum, donec calefiat membrum.	 Then put the patient into a bath or soak his leg in hot water until it becomes red and the veins swell, or if there is no bath available, exercise strongly until the limb warms up.
Deinde seca cutem in directo uenae sectione per longitudinem: aut in ultimo eius apud genu, aut in inferiori parte eius apud calcaneum.	 Then cut the skin along the length of the vein's path: either at its end near the knee or at its lower part near the heel.
Deinde aperi cutem cum uncinis, et excoria uenam ab omni parte, donec appareat sensui: et est apud apparitionem eius, quod uides eam rubeam ad nigredinem decliuem.	 Then open the skin with hooks and strip the vein from all sides until it is visible to the touch, and at its appearance you will see it redden towards blackness.
Cum ergo uadit ex cute, uides eam albam quasi sit chorda.	 When it emerges from the skin, you will see it white like a string.
Deinde intromitte sub ea Radium, donec quando eleuatur et egreditur de cute: suspende eam cum uncino caeco, leni.	 Then insert under it a reed until when lifted and emerges from the skin; hang it with a blind hook, soft.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam prope illam sectionem tribus digitis.	 Then cut another incision near that incision three fingers wide.
Deinde excoria cutem a superiori parte uenae, donec appareat.	 Then scrape away the skin from above the vein until it appears.
Deinde eleua eam cum Radiis sicut fecisti, et suspende eam cum uncino alio, sicut fecisti in primis.	 Then lift it with tongs as you did before, and hang it with another hook as you did at first.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam, aut sectiones plures, si indiges illo.	 Then cut another incision or several more if you need to.
Deinde eleua, et incide ipsam ultima sectione apud calcaneum.	 Then lift it and cut it off at the last incision near the heel.
Deinde extrahe eam ad sectionem quae est supra eam.	 Then draw it out to the incision above it.
Et fac illud, donec extrahas eam ex sectione quae est superior, uel altior sectionibus omnibus, donec quando egreditur tota: tunc incide eam.	 And do this until you draw it out from the uppermost or all of the incisions, when it comes out entirely; then cut it off.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad extrahendum, et eleuandum: tunc intromitte acum cum filo forti duplo, et liga eam, et extrahe ipsam: aut intromitte sub ea Radium: et reuolue manum tuam ad omnem partem, donec egrediatur.	 But if it does not obey you by being drawn out and lifted up, then insert a needle with a strong double thread and tie it off, and draw it out; or insert under it a hook: and turn your hand to every side until it comes out.
Et caue, ne incidatur.	 And be careful that it is not cut.  />
Nam si incidatur, fit difficile tibi eleuare eam ualde, et ingreditur super infirmum ex ea nocumentum.	 For if it is cut, it will be very difficult for you to lift it up, and harm may come to the patient from that.
Cum ergo extraxeris eam totam: tunc pone super locum uulnerum lanam submersam in uino et oleo rosato, aut oleo: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 When you have drawn it out entirely, then place over the wound a woolen cloth soaked in wine and rose oil or oil, and care for him until he is healed.
Quod si Vitis est contracta, habens tortuositatem cui sit inuolutio ad partes, et non est sicut diximus secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut findas super eam ad omnem partem tortuositatis eius, et loca inuolutionis ipsius.	 But if the vein is constricted and has a tortuous course which it follows to its parts, and is not straight as we have said, then you must slit over it along every part of its tortuous course and places of its twisting.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncinis, donec eleues eam totam: et caue apud sectionem tuam super eam ne incidas uenam, aut uulneres: nam difficile fiet super te eleuare, uel extrahere eam.	 Then hang it with hooks until you lift it all out; and be careful at your incision above it that you do not cut the vein or injure it, for it will become very difficult for you to lift or draw it out.
Conserua ergo prudentiam tuam.	 Therefore keep your discretion.
Forma Incidentis quo sanatur Vitis.	 The Shape of a Wound that is Healed by a Wine-based Remedy.
Forma Vncini caeci.	 The shape of a blind tumor.
Non est ei curuitas sicut reliquis Vncinis, neque est acutae extremitatis, ut non uulneret uenam: et est grossae flectuositatis, lenis: quoniam si esset subtilis, incideret uenam subtilitate sua: imo sit ei superflua grossitudo, sicut diximus.	 It does not have the convexity of other tumors, nor the sharp extremities so as not to wound a vein; and it is large and twisted, soft: because if it were thin, it would pierce the vein with its thinness; but it must have excessive thickness, as we said.
De extractione Venae cruris.	 On the Extraction of the Vein of the Leg.
Caput XCIII.	 Chapter XCIII.
Haec Vena generatur in cruribus in terris calidis, sicut Alizegi, et terra Arabum, et in terris aridis, calidis, paucae teneritatis, id est, in quibus non nascitur herba, neque arbor.	 This vein is generated in the legs in hot lands, such as Alizegi and the Arabian land, and in dry, hot lands where there is little tenderness, that is, where neither grass nor trees grow.
Et fortasse generatur in locis aliis corporis praeter crura.	 And perhaps it is generated in other parts of the body besides the legs. xspace
Et generatio quidem eius est a putrefactione quae accidit sub cute, sicut accidunt intra corpora serpentes et uermes ascarides, et uermes generati inter cutem et carnem.	 And its generation is due to putrefaction occurring under the skin, just as happens within bodies with serpents and worms called ascarids, and the worms generated between the skin and flesh.
Et signum incaeptionis euentus huius Venae est, quod accidit in crure inflammatio uehemens.	 And the sign of the beginning of this vein's appearance is that a severe inflammation occurs in the leg.
Deinde uesicatur locus.	 Then the spot becomes blistered. 
Deinde incipit Vena exire ex loco illius uesicationis, quasi sit radix plantae, aut animal.	 Then the vein begins to emerge from that blistered spot, as if it were a root of a plant or an animal.
Cum ergo apparet ex ea extremitas eius, tunc oportet ut inuoluas super ipsam frustum plumbi, cuius pondus sit ex drachma keil, usque ad drachmas II et noda ipsam: et dimitte plumbum suspensum ex crure.	 Therefore, when its extremity becomes visible from that, then you should wrap around it a piece of lead weighing one drachm and two nqbats, and leave the suspended lead hanging from the leg.
Quotiens ergo egreditur ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, inuolue illud in plumbo, et noda illud.	 So whenever something emerges out of it to the outside, wrap that in lead and tie it up.
Quod si prolongatur multum, tunc incide partem eius, et inuolue residuum.	 If it becomes very long, then cut off a piece of it and wrap the rest.
Et non incidas eam radicitus antequam egrediatur tota.	 And do not cut it off at its root before all of it has emerged.  ?>
Quoniam si incidis, contrahitur, et ingreditur in carnem: et facit accidere apostema, et putredinem in loco, et ulcus malum.	 If you cut, it contracts and enters into the flesh, causing an abscess and putrefaction in the place, and a bad sore.
Quapropter oportet, ut suauiter tractetur, et extrahatur paulatim, donec egrediatur ex ultimo sui, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid in corpore: et ex hac quidem Vena egreditur in quibusdam hominibus quod est in longitudine sua quinque palmorum et decem.	 Therefore, it should be treated gently and extracted gradually until it comes out from its last part, so that nothing remains of it in the body; and this vein, in certain people, extends to a length of five palms and ten.
Et iam peruenit ad me, quia exiuit uiro ex XX palmis.	 And now it has come to me because it came out of a man from twenty palms.
Si autem inciditur tibi in hora medicationis tuae: tunc intromitte radium in foramine eius, et perfora eam foramine longo, cum corpore, donec euacuetur totum quod est in ea ex materia: et administra putrefactionem loci cum medicinis diebus aliquot.	 But if it is cut during your treatment time, then insert a reed into its opening and perforate it with a long hole along with the body until everything that is in it from matter is evacuated; and administer treatments for putrefaction of the place for several days.
Deinde cura ipsum curatione apostematum.	 Then treat him according to the method for treating abscesses.
Et haec quidem Vena quandoque habet ramos multos, praecipue quando apparet in iunctura pedis, aut in pede ipso: et accidunt ei orificia multa, et egreditur ex omni orificio ramus.	 And this vein sometimes has many branches, especially when it appears at the ankle or in the foot itself; and there are many openings for it, and from each opening a branch comes out.
Cura ergo ipsam, sicut diximus in diuisione, et cum eo quod praemissum est.	 Therefore treat it as we have said in the division, along with what was stated beforehand.
¶ De sectione super Vermes generatos sub cute, et dicitur Aegritudo bouina.	 ¶ On cutting above worms generated under the skin, which is called bovine disease.
Caput XCIIII.	 Chapter 94.
Haec Aegritudo nominatur in quadam terra apud nos Aegritudo bouina: propterea, quia multotiens accidit bouibus, et est uermis paruus unus, qui nascitur inter cutem et carnem.	 This disease is called in a certain land among us bovine disease because it often happens to cows and it is a small worm that is born between the skin and flesh.
Et uadit in corpore toto, ascendendo et descendendo: et ostenditur sensui apud ambulationem eius de membro ad membrum, donec disrumpit ubicumque disrumpit in cute locum, et egreditur.	 And it goes through the entire body, ascending and descending; and it is felt when walking from member to member until it breaks through wherever it breaks through the skin and comes out.
Et generatio eius est ex putredine quorundam humorum.	 And its generation is from the putrefaction of certain humors.
Sicut accidunt uermes et serpentes, id est, lumbrici, et ascarides in uentre.	 Just as worms and snakes, that is, earthworms and roundworms, occur in the belly.  />
Et timetur ex malicia eius.	 And fear is caused by its malignancy.
Quia quando ipse uadit in corpore, et eleuatur ad caput, et peruenit ad locum: tunc fortasse aperit in eo, et egreditur, et destruit oculum: et accidit illud multotiens.	 Because when it goes into the body and is raised to the head and reaches that place, then perhaps it opens up there and exits, and destroys the eye, and this often happens.
Cum ergo uis curare eum, et extrahere ipsum, tunc non fit illud nisi apud ambulationem eius, et apparitionem ipsius sensui.	 Therefore, when you want to cure it and extract it, this is only done during its movement and appearance to the senses.
Oportet ergo, ut stringas quod est supra eum, et quod est sub eo cum ligamento constrictione forti.	 You must therefore tie strongly with a ligature what is above it and what is below it.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	 Then cut above it and extract it.
Quod si profundatur in carne, et non inuenis ipsum: tunc pone super locum cauterium cum igne, donec moriatur.	 But if it goes deep into the flesh and you cannot find it, then put a cautery with fire on that place until it dies.
Et maius quod timetur, est corruptio eius, qua corrumpit oculum, sicut diximus.	 And what is even more feared is its corruption, by which it corrupts the eye, as we have said.
Si autem uides eum iam peruenisse in capite prope oculum, tunc stringe sub eo supercilium strictura bona.	 But if you see that it has already reached near the eye at the head, then tie a good ligature under it on the eyebrow.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	 Then cut above it and extract it. abei
Et oportet ut utatur infirmus mundificatione sui corporis, cum medicinis soluentibus humores putridos malos.	 And the patient must use bodily cleansing with medicines that dissolve bad putrid humors.
Et caueat sibi a cibis generantibus putrefactionem.	 And he should avoid foods that cause putrefaction.
¶ De sectione super aegritudinem Nakir.	 ¶ On the incision for Nakir's disease.
Caput XCV.	 Chapter XCV.
Haec aegritudo nominatur in terra nostra Nakir: et est dolor qui accidit in quibusdam membris: deinde permutatur de membro ad membrum.	 This disease is called Nakir in our land, and it is a pain that occurs in certain limbs, then changes from one limb to another.
Et ego quidem iam uidi ipsum, secundum quod narro tibi.	 And I myself have already seen this, as I am telling you.
Vocatus sum ad mulierem infirmam in quibusdam uillis.	 I was called to a sick woman in certain villages. beyi beyi
Et detexit brachium suum, et uidi inflationem paruam in uena funis brachii.	 And she uncovered her arm, and I saw a small swelling on the tendon of the arm vein.
Et postquam remansi hora una, uidi unam inflationem incedere cum focili, sicut incedit uermis, ascendendo ad humerum eius uelocius quam esse potest: ut sit sicut argentum uiuum, quando currit de loco ad locum.	 And after I remained for one hour, I saw a swelling go forth like a caterpillar, moving quickly up her arm to the shoulder faster than is possible, just as silver moves when it runs from place to place.
Recessit ergo dolor ex illo loco, et fixus est in humero.	 The pain then retreated from that place and fixed itself in the shoulder.
Deinde sedi hora una, et cucurrit in reliquum corpus, donec perueniret in brachium aliud.	 Then I sat for an hour, and it ran through the rest of the body until it reached the other arm.
Deinde narrauit mihi, quia reuoluebatur in toto corpore suo, secundum quod uidi.	 Then he told me that it was turning throughout his whole body, as I saw.
Miratus sum ergo de uelocitate permutationis eius de membro ad membrum.	 So I marveled at the speed with which it changed from member to member.
Et ego quidem ante illud non uideram hanc aegritudinem oculis meis taliter secundum hunc modum.	 And truly, before that, I had never seen this illness in my eyes acting in such a way.
Verumtamen uidi multos, qui inueniunt dolorem permutari de membro ad membrum: et non uidi ipsum oculis, sicut uidi eum in muliere.	 However, I have seen many people in whom pain was transferred from member to member; but I had never seen it with my own eyes as I saw it in the woman.
Et ego non cogito illud esse, nisi quod est propterea, quod mulier fuit ex illis qui sunt ex uillis sicci corporis detectarum uenarum: hinc ergo apparet sensui illa uentositas permutata.	 And I do not think that this happened except because she was one of those women with dry bodies and visible veins; from which it seems to the senses that the wind was transferred.
Et est necesse, ut non appareant secundum hanc rationem in illis qui sunt deliciosi, et corporibus humidis, occultarum uenarum.	 And it is necessary that these do not appear according to this reasoning in those who are delicate and have moist bodies with hidden veins.  />
Cum ergo uis curationem eius, et sentit patiens illud dolorem: tunc si est apparens tibi oculo, sicut diximus, tunc stringe supra ipsum, et sub ipso uelociter: et seca supra ipsum, donec egrediatur illa uentositas coartata: et cauteriza locum.	 Therefore, when you want to treat it and the patient feels that pain, then if it is visible to your eye as we have said, quickly tie above it and below it; and cut above it until that wind comes out constricted; and cauterize the place.
Si autem non uides ipsum oculis tuis: tunc cura ipsum cum excussione corporis, et cum eo quod expellit uentositates, et carminat eas cum pillulis foetidis, et pillulis de serapino, et similibus.	 But if you do not see it with your own eyes, then treat it with bodily evacuation and with what expels winds and binds them with fetid pills, and pills of serpentaria, and similar things.
¶ De extractione Sagittarum.	 § On the Extraction of Arrows.  />
Caput XCVI.	 Chapter 96
Sagittae diuersificantur secundum species suas, et secundum loca in quibus cadunt ex corpore.	 Arrows are distinguished by their kinds and by the places where they fall from the body.
Earum uero diuersitas est: quoniam ex eis sunt quae habent cuspides magnos, et paruos: et concauae, et surdae.	 Their diversity is such that some have large heads and others small; some are hollow and others solid.
Et ex eis sunt quae habent tres angulos.	 And among them are those which have three angles.
Et ex eis quibus sunt linguae.	 And among these are tongues.
Et ex eis quibus sunt astellae.	 And among these are stars.
Illae uero quae sunt secundum membra in quibus cadunt, est secundum duos modos.	 However, those which fall according to the members are of two kinds.
Aut enim membra sunt ex membris principalibus concauis, sicut cerebrum, et cor, et epar, et pulmo, et renes, et intestina, et uesica, et eis similia.	 For the members are either from the principal hollow organs, such as the brain, heart, liver, lung, kidney, intestine, bladder, and similar things.
Quando ergo cadit in aliquo horum membrorum, et apparent tibi signa mortis, quae ego narro tibi post, tunc oportet ut deuites extractionem illius sagittae ex eis, nam mors consequitur illum in quo est, in pluribus dispositionibus.	 Therefore, when it falls into one of these members and the signs of death, which I will tell you later, appear to you, then you must avoid extracting that arrow from them, because death follows him in whom it is, in many cases.
Et quando non apparent tibi ista signa mala, et sagitta non est absconsa in profunditate membri, tunc extrahe ipsam, et cura uulnus.	 And when these bad signs do not appear to you and the arrow is not hidden deep within the member, then extract it and treat the wound.
Ex signis enim cerebri quando cadit in eo sagitta, et penetrat os, et egreditur siphac quod est super cerebrum, est: quoniam accidunt ex illo soda uehemens, et scotomia, et uertigo, et rubedo in oculis, et inflatio, et rubedo linguae, et spasmus, et permixtio intellectus, et uomitus cholerae.	 For the signs of the brain when an arrow falls into it and penetrates the bone and exits through the fontanel on top of the brain are: because there occurs from it a severe headache, blindness in one eye, dizziness, redness of the eyes, swelling, redness of the tongue, spasms, confusion, and vomiting of bile.
Et fortasse egreditur sanguis ex naribus, aut auribus.	 And perhaps blood will come out of the nose or ears.
Et fortasse abscinditur sermo, et destruitur uox.	 And perhaps speech is cut off and the voice destroyed.
Et egreditur ex loco uulneris humiditas alba similis pulti.	 And a white fluid like dough comes out of the place of the wound.
Et exit ex eo simile aquositati carnis.	 And from it comes something resembling the wateriness of meat.  />
Si ergo apparent tibi ista signa, tunc abstine a curatione, et extrahe sagittam si non egreditur.	 If therefore these signs appear to you, then refrain from treating it, and extract the arrow if it has not exited.
Signa autem sagittae quando cadit in corde, sunt: quod ipsa est prope mammillam sinistram: et sentit cum ea quasi ipsa sit fixa in re dura, non in re uacua.	 The signs of the arrow when it falls into the heart are that it is near the left nipple and feels as if it is stuck in a hard thing, not an empty one.
Et fortasse sagittae est motus similis motui pulsus: et currit ex uulnere sanguis niger.	 And perhaps there is a movement in the arrow similar to the pulse and black blood runs from the wound.  /> 89463217
Et sequitur illud frigus extremitatum, et sudor frigidus, et syncopis.	 And it is followed by coldness in the extremities, cold sweat, and fainting.
Scias ergo, quod mors descendit procul dubio.	 You should know that death has certainly come.
Et signum sagittae quando uulnerat pulmonem, est exitus sanguinis spumosi ex uulnere: et uasa quae sequuntur collum, apostematur, et mutatur color infirmi.	 And the sign of an arrow wound to the lung is that blood-froth comes out of the wound; and the veins that follow the neck become inflamed, and the color of the sick person changes.
Et expirat spiritum magnum, altum: et quaerit attractionem aeris frigidi.	 And he exhales a great deal of air with great force; and seeks to inhale cold air.
Quod si cadat sagitta in uelamen, quod est in pectore: tunc est prope costas paruas: et fit anhelitus magnus cum dolore uehementi, cum suspirio: et mouentur omnia membra humerorum.	 If the arrow falls on the diaphragm which is in the chest, then it is close to the small ribs; and there is a great gasping with severe pain and sighing; and all the limbs of the shoulders tremble.
Et si cadat sagitta in stomachum, tunc fortasse egreditur ex uulnere ex cibo aliquid indigestum.	 And if the arrow falls on the stomach, then perhaps something undigested comes out of the wound from food.
Et si cadit sagitta in Ventrem, et figitur in eo: egreditur aliquid stercoris ex uulnere, aut zirbum, aut intestinum quod iam disruptum est.	 And if the arrow falls on the belly and pierces it, then something of fecal matter comes out of the wound, or an intestine that has already been torn.
Non est ergo spes in curatione eius, neque in extractione sagittae.	 There is therefore no hope for his cure, nor in extracting the arrow.
Quod si sagitta cadat in Vesicam, et egrediatur urina: et procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, et fortior sit dolor super infirmum: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	 If the arrow falls on the bladder and urine comes out; and something comes out of it to the outside, and the pain is greater on the sick person; then you should know that it is fatal.
Reliqua autem membra, sicut facies, et collum, et guttur, et spatula, et adiutorium, et spondiles dorsi, et furcula, et coxa, et crus, et eis similia ex membris saluantur secundum plures dispositiones: quando non inuenit sagitta arteriam, aut neruum: et non est sagitta uenenosa.	 The remaining limbs, such as the face, and neck, and throat, and shoulder blade, and shoulder joint, and back of the loins, and collarbone, and hip, and leg, and others like them from the limbs are healed according to various dispositions; when the arrow does not find a main artery or nerve; and is not a poisoned arrow. 》 》
Et ego narro tibi quod uidi de esse harum sagittarum, ut significes per illud super curationem tuam.	 And I tell you that I have seen of these arrows, in order for you to know through this concerning your cure.
Quod est, quia cuidam uiro cecidit sagitta in lachrymali oculi eius, in radice nasi.	 That is, because a certain man had an arrow fall on his tear duct at the root of his nose.
Extraxi ergo eam ipsi ex parte altera, sub adipe auris eius: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei in oculo eius nocumentum.	 I removed it from her other side, under the fat of her ear; and she was healed, and no harm came to her eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam Iudaeo, quae cecidit ei in adipe oculi sui sub palpebra inferiori: et sagitta iam occultata erat, et non consecutus sum ex ea nisi extremitatem paruam eius, cum qua adhaeret in ligno suo: et erat sagitta magna ex sagittis arcuum Turcorum, cum ferro leni, in qua non sunt aures.	 I also removed an arrow from a Jew that had fallen into his eyelid fat under the lower eyelid; and the arrow was already hidden, and I could not get anything but its small end, which was attached to its shaft: and it was a large arrow of the Turkish bows, with a soft iron tip, in which there are no barbs.
Sanatus est ergo Iudaeus, et non accidit in oculo eius accidens malum.	 Therefore, the Jew was healed, and no evil befell his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam ex gutture Christiani.	 And I removed another arrow from a Christian's throat.
Et erat sagitta arabica, et est illa cui sunt aures.	 And it was an Arab arrow, and that is the type with barbs.
Secui ergo super ipsam inter duas guidegi: et iam submersa erat in gutture eius.	 I cut, therefore, above it between the two rings: and it was already sunk into his throat.
Subtiliatus sum ergo cum ea, donec extraxi eam: et sanatus est Christianus.	 Therefore, I became skilled with it, until I removed it; and the Christian was healed. />
Et extraxi sagittam aliam uiro quae ceciderat in uentre eius: et cogitauimus, quia moreretur ex ea.	 And I removed another arrow from a man that had fallen into his belly; and we thought that he would die from it.
Postquam ergo praeterierunt ei triginta dies, et non mutatum est super eum aliquid ex dispositionibus eius, secui super sagittam: et ingeniaui super eam, et extraxi eam: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei accidens malum.	 Therefore, after thirty days had passed and nothing changed in his condition, I cut above the arrow; and I sharpened it, and removed it; and he was healed, and no evil befell him.
Et uidi uirum cui cecidit sagitta in dorso eius, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam.	 And I saw a man on whom an arrow had fallen into his back, and the wound over it had become healed.
Postquam ergo fuit post septem annos, exiuit sagitta in radice coxae eius.	 Therefore, after seven years had passed, the arrow came out at the base of his thigh.
Et uidi mulierem cui cecidit in uentre suo sagitta, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam, et remansit sagitta intra ipsam: et non mutata est ex dispositionibus eius aliqua, et mulier non inuenit ei nocumentum in aliqua ex operationibus suis naturalibus.	 And I saw a woman on whom an arrow had fallen into her belly, and the wound over it had become healed, and the arrow remained inside her; and nothing changed in her condition, and the woman did not find any harm in any of her natural functions.
Et uidi uirum alium, cui cecidit sagitta in facie sua: et consolidatum est uulnus, et remansit, non inueniens ei multum dolorem: et similia istis multa.	 And I saw another man who was struck by an arrow in his face; the wound hardened and remained, causing him little pain. There were many similar cases like this.
Et extraxi sagittam uiro ex principibus Regis, quae ceciderat ei in medio nasi sui, et iam declinauerat ad partem dextram parumper: et occultata erat sagitta tota.	 And I removed an arrow from a man who was one of the king's nobles; it had struck him in the middle of his nose and slightly deviated to the right side, and the entire arrow was hidden.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius post casum sagittae usque ad tres dies.	 I was therefore called to treat him three days after the incident with the arrow.
Inueni ergo uulnus sagittae strictum ualde.	 I found that the arrow wound was very tight.
Inquisiui ergo eam cum tenta subtili, et non sensi eam: et ipse quidem inueniebat punctionem et dolorem sub aure sua ex parte dextra.	 So I examined it with a fine probe and did not feel it; the man himself found pain and discomfort under his right ear.
Speraui ergo, quod erat illa punctio ex extremitate sagittae.	 Therefore, I hoped that this was a point of exit from the tip of the arrow. 
Emplastraui ergo locum cum emplastro in quo erat uirtus attractiua, et digestiua, confidens apud me, quod apostemaretur locus, et appareret mihi signum sagittae, ut secarem super eam: et non accidit in loco accidens significans quod sagitta consecuta sit locum.	 I then applied a plaster with attracting and digesting powers to the area, hoping that the wound would suppurate and reveal to me the sign of the arrow so that I could cut over it; but this did not happen, indicating that the arrow had not reached that location.
Assiduaui ergo cum emplastro super eum diebus multis: et non accidit accidens, et consolidatum est uulnus interim: et remansit infirmus de extractione eius spacio dierum, donec sensit sagittam die quodam intra nasum suum.	 I continued to apply the plaster for many days, and no discharge occurred; the wound healed, but the man remained weak from the arrow's removal for some time until one day he felt the arrow inside his nose.
Et narrauit mihi illud.	 And he told me about it.
Posui ergo super illud uulnus medicinam acutam, corrosiuam diebus multis, donec apertum est: et cum tenta tentaui ipsum, et sensi extremitatem sagittae subtilem quae adhaeret in ligno.	 So I placed a sharp, corrosive medicine on the wound for many days until it opened up; and when I probed it with a probe, I felt the tip of the arrow attached to the wood.
Deinde addidi in apertione uulneris per illam medicinam acutam, donec apparuit nobis uisibiliter extremitas sagittae: et praeteriit mihi cum eo spacium temporis circiter quatuor menses.	 Then I continued to widen the wound with that sharp medicine until we could see the tip of the arrow visibly; and this process took about four months. 
Deinde postquam amplificatum est uulnus, et possible fuit mihi intromittere forcipes in ipsam, et mouere ipsam, et non obediuit ad exitum: tunc non cessaui subtiliare, et ingeniare super eam cum modis ingeniorum, donec coepi super eam die quodam cum forcipibus decenter factis, secundum quod ueniet forma eorum in fine capituli, donec extraxi eam.	 Then after the wound had been widened enough to allow me to insert forceps into it and move the arrow, but it did not exit; I did not stop refining and inventing methods for removing it until one day I began with well-made forceps, as will be shown in their form at the end of this chapter, until I removed it.
Deinde restauraui uulnus.	 Then I repaired the wound.
Et medici quidem iudicant, quod cartilago nasi non restauratur.	 And indeed, doctors judge that the cartilage of the nose cannot be restored.
Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	 Therefore I repaired it (the cartilage of the nose), and the wound was healed, and the patient was restored to full health; nothing whatever harmed him.
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	 And I tell you about the method of extracting certain arrows: so that you may use this as a rule and understanding for what I did not say.
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	 Since the parts of this art and their distinctions are not comprehended by mere narrative; nor does the book comprehend them, but a skillful craftsman compares a little to much, and what is present to what is absent; and he finds a new operation and a new instrument in dealing with external things of this art when they occur.  />
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	 I say therefore that arrows do not exit from the members to which they are fixed except in two ways.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	 Either by retracing their path back out of the place where they entered.
Aut contrario partis alterius.	 Or through the opposite side (of the body).
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	 And those that exit where they entered are either arrows passing through fleshy parts, which can be drawn out and exit.  />
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	 But if it does not yield to exit at the time it fell, then you must leave it for some days until the flesh around it putrefies, and its extraction will be facilitated, along with its exit.
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	 Similarly, if it is embedded in bone and does not yield to you for extraction, then leave it also for some days; and every day try to extract it with traction and motion, until it comes out.
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	 But if after several days it does not yield to you for extraction, then you must bore around the arrow in the bone itself from all sides with a fine awl, until the arrow becomes enlarged.
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	 Then draw it out and extract it.
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	 If however the arrow is fixed in the bone of the head and has already entered one of the ventricles of the brain, and some of those effects which I have mentioned appear from the patient, then refrain from extracting the arrow and leave it there until its condition becomes equal after several days.
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	 For if an arrow reaches the pituitary gland, then death will not be delayed for him.
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	 And if the arrow is not fixed except in the bone alone and does not penetrate as far as the pituitary gland, and the patient remains for several days and nothing of those effects happens to him, then one should proceed with extracting the arrow and removing it.
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	 But if it is very fixed and does not yield to you for extraction, then apply trepanning around the arrow, as I have told you; then care for the place until it heals.
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	 But if the arrow is already hidden in some part of the body and is concealed and hidden from sense, then seek it out with a probe.
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	 But if you feel it, then extract it with certain instruments that are suitable for its extraction.
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	 But if you cannot reach it because of the narrowness of the wound and the length of the arrow deep inside, and there is no bone, nerve, or vein there, then cut open above it until the wound is widened and it becomes possible to extract the arrow.
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	 But if there are ears (i.e., pieces of flesh) by which it is held, then free the attached flesh from every side and in every way you can manage to do that, and if it cannot be extracted because of the breaking of the ears and their twisting, then persist until it comes out. )))
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	 And when you administer the extraction of an arrow in whatever place it is, then use the twisting of your hand with forceps on all parts until you make it come out; and be subtle with the utmost subtlety so that the arrow does not break and its attraction and extraction become difficult for you.
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	 If you cannot cut it in one hour, then leave it for some days until what surrounds it decays.
Deinde itera eam: alleuietur enim tuncia Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra quod diximus ex curatione in capitulo suo: et custodi uirtutem tuam ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, aut chordae.	 Then repeat the process; the swelling will be relieved. However, if the flow of blood is causing difficulty for you, then administer what we said in its own chapter on treatment: and guard your virtue from cutting a vein or nerve or sinew.
Et administra ingenium omni modo quo tibi possibile est euasionis Sagittae: et sit illud cum facilitate, et tranquillitate, uel tarditate, et firmitate, sicut narraui tibi.	 And administer the medicine in every way that is possible for you to evade the arrow: and let it be with ease, calmness, slowness, and firmness, as I have told you.
Et oportet, ut facias cum trahis Sagittam, ut infirmus sit secundum figuram, secundum quam fuit apud casum Sagittae in ipso.	 And it is necessary that when you draw the arrow, it should be weakened according to the figure as it was at the time of the arrow wound itself.
Quoniam est magis iuuatiuum.	 Because it is more beneficial.
Si autem non est tibi possibile illud, tunc administra quod tibi est possibile ex figuris.	 If this is not possible for you, then administer what is possible from the figures.
Sagitta autem quae egreditur ex contrario partis alterius, aut iam procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora: aut facit gibbositatem extremitas Sagittae per sensum ex superiore parte cutis propinquae, et uides eam eminentem: seca ergo super eam, et sit sectio secundum quantitatem quod capiant in ea forcipes.	 If the arrow comes out of the opposite part, or something is already protruding to the outside, or if it forms a swelling at the tip of the arrow that you can feel under the skin and see it protruding, cut above it; let the incision be according to the size that the forceps can grasp in it.  ()
Deinde attrahe eam: ipsa namque fit facilis ad exitum.	 Then draw it out, for it becomes easy to remove.
Si uero retinetur in osse, tunc torque manum tuam secundum rotunditatem, donec imprimat Sagitta in osse, et amplificet sibiipsi: deinde trahe ipsam.	 But if it is lodged in the bone, then twist your hand according to its roundness until the arrow presses into the bone and enlarges its own opening; then draw it out.
Et si non: dimitte eam diebus aliquot: deinde itera eam, donec egrediatur.	 And if not, leave it for some days; then repeat the process until it comes out.
Quod si lignum Sagittae est in ea, tunc impelle ipsam cum eo.	 If the arrow has a wooden shaft, then push it out with its shaft.  ()
Si autem cecidit lignum, et uis administrare impulsionem: tunc intromitte ad eam instrumentum concauum, ut ingrediatur concauitas eius in caudam Sagittae: deinde impelle eam cum ipso.	 But if the wooden shaft has broken off and you wish to administer a push, then insert into it a concave instrument so that its concavity enters into the tail of the arrow; then push it out with it.  ()  ()  ()  ()
Si autem Sagita est concaua, tunc impelle eam cum instrumento intrante in ipsam.	 If however the arrow is barbed, then push it through with an entering instrument.
Sagitta enim alleuiatur per illud.	 For the arrow should be removed by that means.
Quod si Sagitta est toxicata, tunc oportet, ut concaues carnem totam, in qua est uenenum: si est tibi possibile illud.	 If the arrow is poisoned, then it is necessary to cut out all the flesh in which the poison is located, if it is possible for you.
Deinde cura eam cum eo quod conuenit ad illud.	 Then treat it with what is suitable for that.
Quod si Sagitta est cadens in pectore, aut in uentre, aut in uesica, aut in latere: et est propinqua ex eo quod tangis cum tenta, et possibile est tibi secare super eam: tunc seca, et caue ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, et extrahe eam.	 If the arrow falls into the chest or belly or bladder or side and is close to the surface so that you can feel it with your finger, and it is possible for you to cut above it, then cut, and be careful not to cut a vein or nerve, and extract it.
Deinde sue uulnus, si uides, et cura illud, donec sanetur.	 Then treat the wound, if you see it, until it heals.
Et haec est forma Forcipum, quibus extrahuntur Sagittae.	 And this is the form of the forceps with which arrows are extracted.
Sint extremitates similes rostro auis, quae factae sunt sicut ferra: quando capiunt super Sagittam, non dimittunt eam.	 The ends should be like the beak of a bird and made in such a way that when they grasp the arrow, they do not let it go.
Et fiunt ex eis species multae, magnae, et paruae, et mediae, secundum quantitatem magnitudinis Sagittae, et paruitatis eius, et amplitudinis uulneris, et constrictionis eius.	 And many forms are made from them, large and small and medium, according to the size of the arrow and its narrowness, and the width of the wound and its narrowness.
Forma Impellentis concaui.	 The form of the pushing instrument for barbed arrows.
Et forma Impellentis surdi.	 And the form of the pushing instrument for blunt arrows.
Hoc est surdae extremitatis sicut Radius, ut alleuietur introitus eius in sagittam concauam, et impellatur cum eo.	 This is the end of the blunt arrow like a radius, so that its entry into a barbed arrow may be facilitated and it may be pushed with it.  />
Huius extremitas impellentis concauae est concaua sicut penna auis: ut alleuietur introitus sagittae in ipsam et impulsio eius.	 The end of the pushing instrument for barbed arrows is like a bird's feather, so that the entry of the arrow into it and its pushing may be facilitated.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum.	 ¶ On the bleeding of veins.  />
Caput XCVII.	 Chapter 97.
Uenae phlebotomandae, quarum cucurrit consuetudo in corpore, sunt triginta.	 There are thirty veins that run in the body and into which it is customary to bleed.
Ex quibus in capite sunt sexdecim: duae Venae pulsatiles, quae sunt post aures, dictae duae Herbae: et duae Arteriae, quae sunt in duobus timporibus apparentes: et duae Venae quae sunt in duobus lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, quae dicuntur Aspicientes: et Vena praeparata in medio frontis: et uena quae est in extremitate nasi.
