Et haec Ventosa quanto plus est magna, ut capiat aquam multam, est melior.	 And the larger this ventose is, so that it can hold much water, the better it is.
¶ De suspensione Sanguisugarum.	 ¶ About the Suspension of Bloodletters.
Caput XCIX.	 Chapter 99.
Sanguisugae non administrantur in pluribus, nisi in quibus membris non est possibilis positio uentosarum, propter paruitatem eorum, sicut labium, et gingiua, et eis similia.	 Bloodletters are not used on many [parts of the body], except for those limbs where the application of ventoses is impossible due to their smallness, such as the lip and gum, and similar parts.
Aut in membro denudato a carne, sicut digitus, et nasus, et eis similia.	 Or on limbs that are bare of flesh, like the fingers, nose, and similar parts.
Et qualitas utendi eis est: ut ueneris ex Sanguisugis quae sunt in aquis dulcibus, mundis a putredinibus.	 And the quality of using them is: that you come from bloodletters which are in sweet and clean waters, free from decay. ›
Deinde dimittantur die et nocte in aqua dulci, donec famelicae sint, et non remaneat in uentre earum aliquid.	 Then they are released day and night into fresh water until they are hungry, and there is nothing left in their stomachs.
Deinde euacuetur corpus in primis cum phlebotomia, et cum uentosis.	 Then the body should be first evacuated with phlebotomy and with enema.
Deinde absterge membrum infirmi, donec rubeat.	 Then cleanse the member of the patient until it reddens.
Postea ponantur super ipsum.	 Then they are placed upon it.
Cum ergo implentur, et cadunt, et est possibilis suctio loci cum uentosa, tunc est magis ultimum in iuuamento: et si non, tunc ablue locum cum aceto.	 When they are filled and fall off, and if it is possible to suck the place with an enema, then it is more useful; and if not, then wash the place with vinegar.
Deinde cum aqua multa, et fricetur, et exprimatur.	 Then with much water, let it be washed and squeezed out.
Quod si prolongatur cursus sanguinis post casum Sanguisugarum, et est illud resudando: tunc infunde pannum lini in aqua frigida, et pone ipsum desuper, donec abscindatur resudatio.	 If the flow of blood continues after the fall of leeches, and if this is due to perspiration, then pour a flax cloth into cold water and place it on top until the sweating stops.
Quod si multiplicatur sanguis, tunc pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, aut gallas, et similia eis ex stipticis: donec abscindatur sanguis.	 If the blood increases, then sprinkle on it powdered alum or oak galls and similar astringents until the bleeding stops.
Aut ponantur super locum medietates fabarum excorticatarum: et dimittantur, donec adhaereant fabae in loco, nam sanguis abscinditur.	 Or place half-peeled beans on the spot and let them stay until they stick to the spot, for the blood will stop.  \\
Et oportet si necessaria est iteratio Sanguisugarum, quando est possibile, mutare eas.	 And if it is necessary to repeat the use of leeches, when possible, change them.
Si autem prohibentur Sanguisugae a suspensione, tunc abstergatur locus cum sanguine recenti.	 But if leeches are prevented from biting, then cleanse the spot with fresh blood.
Aut fige acum in locis, donec egrediatur aliquid ex sanguine.	 Or prick with a needle until some blood comes out.
Deinde ponantur, nam ipsae quando sentiunt aliquid ex sanguine, adhaerent statim.	 Then place them on, for they will stick immediately when they sense something from the blood.
Quando ergo uis ut cadant, pulueriza super eas aliquid ex aloe trito, aut salem, aut cinerem: et cadent statim.	 When you want them to fall off, sprinkle some powdered aloe or salt or ash on them, and they will immediately fall off.
¶ Partis Secundae Finis.	 The end of the second part.
¶ Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars III.	 Book of Surgery by Albucasis Part III.
¶ Sermo uniuersalis de restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus.	 General discussion about restoration, dislocation, the treatment of torsion, and similar topics.
Caput I.	 Chapter 1
Hoc Capitulum etiam multotiens est necessarium in arte Medicinae, et est restauratio fracturae, et dislocationis accidentium in ossibus.	 This chapter is also often necessary in the art of Medicine, and it concerns the restoration of bone fractures and dislocations.
Scitote o Filii, quia iactant se de hoc Capitulo stolidi medicorum et uulgi, et qui non inspexerunt unquam antiquorum librum, neque legerunt ex eo literam.	 Know, O Sons, that fools and the common people boast about this chapter, even though they have never looked into an ancient book nor read a single letter from it.
Et propter hanc caussam fit, quod iste modus ex scientiis in terra nostra est priuatus.	 And for this reason, this method has been privately concealed among the sciences in our land.
Et ego non obuiaui in eo unquam bono omnino, et non adeptus sum ex eo illud, quod sum adeptus nisi propter longitudinem lectionis librorum antiquorum, et studium super intellectum eorum, donec extraxi scientiam illius ex eis.	 And I have never found anything good in it at all, and I would not have attained what I have attained except through the lengthy study of ancient books and diligence in understanding them, until I extracted that knowledge from them.
Deinde adhaesi experimento et studio longitudine uitae meae.	 Then I devoted my life to experiments and long study.
Et iam descripsi uobis ex illo in hoc Capitulo totum quod continet scientia mea: et super quod praeteriit experimentum meum, postquam abbreuiaui illud uobis, et liberaui illud ex occupatione elongationis, et abbreuiaui illud fine abbreuiationis, et ostendi illud fine declinationis: et formaui in eo formas multas ex formis instrumentorum quae administrantur in eo, cum sit ex additione declinationis, sicut feci in duobus Capitulis praecedentibus.	 And now I have described to you in this chapter all that my science contains: and concerning the experiment which I passed over after I shortened it for you, and released it from prolongation, and shortened it with the end of shortening, and showed it with the end of variation: and I formed many forms from the forms of instruments used in it, when they are added to variation, as I did in the two preceding chapters. ︎
¶ Summae, et collectiones ex esse fracturae ossium, ex eis quarum praemissio necessaria est, antequam incipiamus rememorationem membrorum fractorum, et diuersorum, si uniuscuiusque.	 Summary and collection of the essence of bone fractures, from which it is necessary to begin before we start remembering the broken members, and their various types.
Caput II.	 Chapter 2
Oportet, ut dicamus in prologo huius Capituli, summas sermonis, et capitula, ad quarum intellectum cogitur in primis artifex ad stationem super earum ueritatem: scilicet ut uos, et qui sunt prompti, sciant, uel addiscant hanc artem nobilem, et alii a uobis.	 In the prologue of this chapter, it is fitting to summarize the key points and topics that are necessary for understanding them first: so that you, and those who are quick to learn, may know or learn this noble art, and teach others from you.
Dico, ergo, quod quando accidit alicui fractura, aut dislocatio, aut torsio, aut casus: tunc oportet, ut properes in primis ad phlebotomandum eum, et soluendum ipsum, aut utraque simul: si non prohibeat aliquid, sicut debilitas uirtutis: aut est ille cui accidit aliquid ex illis puer, aut senex decrepitus: aut est tempus uehementis caloris, aut uehementis frigoris ualde.	 I say, therefore, that when someone has a fracture, dislocation, twist, or fall, you should hasten first to bleed them and loosen them, or both together, unless something prevents it, such as weakness of strength: or the one who experienced something of these things is a child, or an old man withered by age: or it is a time of very hot weather, or very cold. ︎
Deinde sit contentus in cibo suo, oleribus frigidis, et carnibus auium, et haedorum: et prohibe uinum, et carnes grossas, et repleri ex cibis et omni cibo qui replet uenas sanguine.	 Then let him be content with his food, cold vegetables, and birds or goat meat; and avoid wine, heavy meats, and overeating of all foods that fill the veins with blood.
Donec quando securus sis ex apostemate calido, et non times effusionem materiei ad membrum: tunc redeat infirmus ad regimen suum primum cum quo cucurrit consuetudo eius.	 Until you are sure of the healing of the warm swelling, and you do not fear the outpouring of matter to the member; then let the sick man return to his first regime with which he was accustomed.
Cum ergo incipit os fractum restaurari, tunc oportet, ut cibetur infirmus cibis nutrientibus nutrimento multo, grosso, graui, in quibus sit uiscositas: sicut cibaria facta ex tritico cocto cum aqua, et rizum, et capita, et pedes, et uentres uaccarum, et oua, et pisces recentes: et uinum grossum, et similia illis.	 When the fracture of the mouth begins to heal, then it is necessary for the sick person to be fed with nourishing foods that are abundant in nutrients and thick; such as foods made from boiled wheat with water, rice, fish heads, fish tails, cow intestines, eggs, fresh fish, and heavy wine, and similar things.
Cum hoc enim regimine fit coagulatio fracturae uelocius, et melius.	 With this diet, the healing of the fracture is faster and better.
Et scias, quod ossa fracta, quando sunt in uiris qui sunt in prima senectute, et decrepitis, non est possibile, ut continuentur et consolidentur secundum naturam suam semper, propter exiccationem membrorum eorum: et consolidantur et continuantur quae ex eis sunt in fine lenitatis, sicut ossa puerornm paruorum.	 And know that broken bones, when they are in men who are in the first stage of old age and decrepit, it is not possible for them to be joined and healed according to their nature always, because of the dryness of their members; and they heal and join together those which are in the end of softness, just like the bones of little children.
Verumtamen natura annectit super os fractum ex omni parte aliquid simile glutino, in quo est grossitudo, quo adhaeret et stringit ipsum, donec conglutinantur adinuicem, et ligantur adinuicem, donec uenit in fine fortitudinis et firmitudinis, sicut fuit in primis, donec non prohibet ipsum aliquid ab operationibus suis: et propter hanc caussam est necesse, ut ponas nutrimentum infirmi cibaria, in quibus sunt grauitas, et uiscositas, et grossitudo, sicut diximus.	 However, nature attaches to the broken bone from every side something similar to glue, which has thickness, by which it adheres and binds together until they are joined together and bound together until it reaches the end of strength and firmness as it was at first, so that nothing prevents it from performing its functions; and because of this cause, it is necessary to provide for the sick person foods in which there is heaviness, thickness, and abundance, as we have said.
Et scias, quod fracturae species sunt diuersae, secundum diuersitatem membrorum: quoniam fractura cruris, est diuersa a fractura ossis capitis: et fractura ossis pectoris, est diuersa a fractura ossis dorsi: et similiter reliqua membra omnia diuersa existunt adinuicem: et ego ueni cum rememoratione omnis speciei fracturae expositae in Capitulo suo distinctae ab alia.	 And know that the types of fractures are diverse according to the diversity of the members; for a fracture of the leg is different from a fracture of the head bone, and a fracture of the chest bone is different from a fracture of the back bone; and similarly all other members are diverse from one another. And I have come with the recall of every type of fracture described in its own chapter, distinguished from others.
Et diuersificantur species fracturae ossis etiam in seipsa.	 And the types of bone fractures are also diverse among themselves.
Quoniam fit fractura eius arcuata, praeter quod accidant in ea astellae.	 Since a fracture can be curved, besides which splinters may occur in it.
Et quandoque fit fractura eius secundum longitudinem ossis: et sunt fracturae eius satagiae, id est, astellae, et additiones procedentes, sicut sunt in calamo, cum aptatur cultello ad scribendum.	 And sometimes the fracture occurs along the length of the bone: and these fractures are fragmented, that is, splinters, and protruding pieces, like those in a reed when it is trimmed with a knife for writing.
Et non procedentes: et est fractura cum uulnere et disruptione in capite: et est fractura fissura parua.	 And they do not protrude: and there is a fracture accompanied by a wound and tearing at the end: and there is a small fissure fracture.
Et omni speciei est ingenium, uel instrumentum proprium in restauratione eius, secundum quod ueniet rememoratio eius, distincta in locis suis.	 And every type has its own skill or tool for its repair, as will be mentioned later, arranged by topic.
Et ex eo quo cognoscitur fractura ossis, est tortuositas eius, et ipsius eminentia: et apparitio eius sensui, et sonitus eius quando comprimis ipsum manu tua.	 And from that which is recognized as a bone fracture is its twist and prominence, and its appearance to the touch, and its sound when you press it with your hand.  />
Quando ergo non est in loco tortuositas apparens, neque sonitus apud tactum tuum cum tangis os cum agitatione, neque inuenit infirmus magnum dolorem: tunc non est illic fractura, imo possibile est, ut sit tortuositas, aut fissura parua: non ergo oportet, ut moueas ipsum cum manu et compressione omnino, imo pone super ipsum ex medicinis, quarum uenit rememoratio, post momentum illud quod conuenit loco: deinde stringatur strictura subtili.	 When there is no apparent twist or sound to the touch when you move the bone, and the patient does not feel great pain, then it is not a fracture. Rather, it may be a twist or a small fissure. Therefore, do not disturb it with your hand or pressure. Instead, place on it some of the medicines whose use will be mentioned after, when the time is right for that: then bind it tightly with fine bandages.
Et scias, quod locus quando arcuatur, et scinditur in duo, praeter quod accidant in eo satagiae, uerumtamen remouetur omnis pars a compari sua: tunc oportet tibi, ut incipias ab hora tua ad rectificationem eius, aequando ipsum antequam accidat ei apostema calidum.	 And know that when a place is curved and split into two, besides which splinters occur in it, however, every part is removed from its pair: then you should begin to straighten it immediately, evening it out before an inflammation occurs.
Si autem accidat ei apostema calidum, tunc dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec quiescat apoestema.	 But if an inflammation occurs in it, then leave it for some days until the inflammation subsides.  />  />
Deinde aequa ipsum secundum quemcunque modum potest ex lenitate et ingenio.	 Then straighten it according to whatever method is possible with gentleness and skill.
Et scias, quod restauratio eius, et ipsius aequatio, est facilior quam ossis, in quo accidunt satagiae.	 And know that its restoration and equalization are easier than that of bone, where fractures occur.
Deinde stringe ipsum, secundum quod ueniet tibi rememoratio eius.	 Then tie it according to how you remember it.
Si uero in osse sunt satagiae, tunc necessaria est extensio huius membri fracti ex duabus partibus, si manus sit, aut pes: aut cum manu tua, si membrum est paruum: aut cum duobus funibus, aut cum fune et manu.	 But if there are fractures in the bone, then it is necessary to extend this broken limb from two sides, whether it be hand or foot; either with your hand, if the limb is small; or with two ropes, or with a rope and your hand.
Et sit positio tua qua ponis membrum super locum aequalem, secundum figuram suam naturalem, donec quando extenduntur partes membri fracti: tunc conare, ut redire facias illas additiones omni ingenio, et secundum quemcunque modum potes in locis suis: et caue secundum fortitudinem tuam, ne accidat super infirmum per operationem tuam dolor, neque laesio: et conare secundum fortitudinem tuam, ut applices unum duorum ossium cum socio suo, secundum meliores formas.	 And let your position be such that you place the limb on an equal spot, according to its natural shape, until when the parts of the broken limb are extended; then strive with all your skill and in whatever manner you can to return those additions to their places: and beware lest by your operation any pain or injury occur to the weak spot. And strive with all your skill that you join one of the two bones with its mate, according to the best forms.
Et oportet in illa hora, ut tentes et tangas ipsum manu tua.	 And it is necessary at that time that you feel and touch it with your hand.
Si ergo uides illic aliquid diuersum, rectifica ipsum, et aequa illud per quantitatem tuae uirtutis.	 Therefore, if you see something different there, correct it and make it equal according to the extent of your skill.
Et caue extensionem uehementem, et compressionem fortem, sicut faciunt multi stolidorum.	 And beware of making a violent extension or a strong compression, as many foolish ones do.  />
Multotiens enim faciunt accidere per operationem illam suam apostema calidum, aut contractionem in membro: sicut iam uidimus illud ex operationibus eorum multotiens.	 For often they cause a hot abscess or contraction in the limb through their operation; as we have already seen this from their operations many times.
Deinde annecte post aequationem, et decentem operationem, et stricturam illius membri, et quietem, et tranquillitatem: et mone infirmum super ipsum.	 Then bind it after equalization and proper operation, stricture, rest, and tranquility; and admonish the patient about this.
Et fac ipsum cauere, ne moueat ipsum in hora suarum uigiliarum, et somni sui apud reuolutionem suam, et agitationem suam, et apud egestionem suam, et omnes motus suos ultima uirtute sua.	 And instruct him to be careful not to move it during his vigils or sleep, and during his turning, moving about, and all his movements with all his might.  />  />
Et ut caueat, ne sit positio membri positio cum qua sequatur dolor.	 And so that he may avoid the position of the limb which causes pain to follow.
Quod est, quia quando sentit in dispositione positionis membri dolorem, aut laesionem: tunc oportet, ut permutes ipsum ad dispositionem aliam ab illa cum qua non sentiat dolorem.	 "When he feels pain or injury in the position of a limb, then it is necessary to change its position to one that causes no pain.
Et caue cum illo, ut sit positio eius illa aequalis, recta: ut non accidat in membro tortuositas, quando restauratur.	 "And be careful with him so that his position is equal and straight, so that the limb does not become twisted when it is restored.
Et qualitas stricturae membri fracti est, secundum quod narro.	 "And the condition of a broken limb's constriction is as I describe.
Scias, quod membra fracta diuersificantur in paruitate sua, et eorum magnitudine, et ipsorum forma.	 "Know that broken limbs are varied by their smallness, and their size, and their shape.
Quae ergo ex eis sunt parua, sicut brachium, et digitus, et focile, et similia eis, tunc oportet, ut sit inuolutio panni mollis, subtilis.	 "Therefore, those that are small, such as the arm, finger, and thigh, then it is necessary for there to be a wrapping of soft, fine cloth.
Quae autem ex eis sunt grossa, sicut coxa, et crus, oportet ut sit in eis inuolutio lata, dura.	 "But those that are thick, such as the thigh and leg, there should be a broad, hard wrapping.
Quoniam ligamentum latum, connectit membrum magnum, et stringit ipsum ab omni parte strictura aequali, ita quod non ingreditur ipsum macula.	 "Because the wide bandage binds the large limb and constrains it from all sides equally with even tightness, so that no blemish enters it.
Deinde incipe post euacuationem tuam ab aequatione ponere linimentum conueniens ad illud, in stuppa leni super locum fracturae ipsius.	 "Then begin after your evacuation from the equal position to place on top of the broken area an appropriate ointment on soft tow.
Deinde incipe inuoluere ligamentum super locum fracturae ipsius tribus inuolutionibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod meretur membrum: et stringe manum tuam parumper cum ligamento.	 "Then begin to wrap the bandage over the broken area with three or four wraps, according to what the limb deserves, and tighten your hand a little with the bandage.
Deinde uade cum eo ad partem superiorem a loco fracturae, et stringe minus quam fuit strictura tua, qua strinxisti locum fractum.	 "Then go with it to the upper part from the broken place, and tighten less than you tightened the broken place.
Deinde elonga te cum inuolutione a loco fracturae parumper, et mollifica stricturam paulatim, donec capias ex loco sano rem magnam.	 "Then extend yourself with the wrapping from the broken place slightly, and gradually ease the tightness until you reach a large healthy part.
Deinde accipe uittam aliam, et inuolue eam iterum super locum fractum inuolutionibus.	 "Then take another bandage and wrap it again over the broken place with wraps.
Postea uade cum inuolutione ad partem inferiorem a fractura.	 "After that, go with the wrapping to the lower part from the break.
Et sit operatio tua in strictura inuolutionis, et mollificatione eius, secundum quod diximus in inuolutione prima superiore.	 "And let your work be in the tightening of the wrapping and its easing, according to what we said in the first upper wrapping.
Deinde pone inter inuolutiones ex stuppa leni, aut panno, cum quo aequetur tortuositas fracturae, si est in ea tortuositas: et si non, non ponas in ea aliquid.	 Then place between the layers of soft tow or cloth, with which the twisting of the fracture is made even, if there is any twisting in it; and if not, do not put anything in it.
Deinde inuolue super ipsam uittam aliam.	 Then wrap another layer over it.
Postea aequa super has inuolutiones astellas decenter factas statim, si non est in loco inflatio, neque apostema calidum.	 Afterwards, place on these layers evenly made and well-shaped splints immediately, if there is no swelling or hot abscess in the place.
Si autem in ea est inflatio, aut apostema: tunc pone super eam quod sedet illud apostema, et auferat inflationem: et dimitte eam aliquot diebus.	 But if there is swelling or abscess in it, then place on it something that will relieve the abscess and remove the swelling; and leave it for some days.
Deinde stringe super ipsam tunc astellas.	 Then tie the splints over it.
Et sint Astellae ex medietatibus cannae latae, rasae, formatae sapienter: aut sint ex ligno unde fiunt cribra, quae fiunt ex pino, aut geraid, id est, ramis palmae, aut calingi: et sit amplitudo omnis Astellae, secundum hanc formam, et hanc eandem figuram.	 And let the splints be made from half-round canes, planed and wisely shaped; or they may be made of wood used for sieves, which are made from pine or geraid, that is, branches of the palm tree, or calingi: and let the width of each splint be according to this form and figure.
Verumtamen oportet, ut Astella quae ponitur super ipsam tracturam, sit grossior et latior parumper, quam reliquae Astellae: et longitudo Astellae sit secundum quod licet membro ex magnitudine et paruitate.	 However, it is necessary that the splint placed on the tracture be somewhat thicker and wider than the other splints; and the length of the splint should be according to what is allowed by the member in terms of size and narrowness.
Deinde stringe super Astellas cum uitta alia, secundum stricturam primam eandem.	 Then tie another bandage over the splints, similarly to the first binding.
Deinde liga desuper cum filis decenter, secundum quod diximus de strictura: et est, ut sit strictura tua super locum fracturae plus: et quanto plus elongatur a fractura sit, strictura minor.	 Then tie it securely with threads, as we have said about the binding; and know that your binding over the site of the fracture should be more, and the farther it extends from the fracture, the less the binding.
Et oportet, ut sint fila media in grossitudine et subtilitate, et sint ex lino molli.	 And know that the threads should be of medium thickness and fineness, and they should be of soft linen.
Quoniam si fila sunt grossa, sicut uidi ex operatione stolidorum ponentium fila sua ex chordis lini tortis, est error magnus: quoniam cadit strictura cum eis extra qualitatem.	 For if the threads are thick, as I have seen from the practice of foolish people who use their threads made from twisted flax cords, it is a great mistake; for the binding slips with them outside of the proper quality.
Et fila subtilia iterum non conueniunt: quoniam tu non consequeris per stricturam cum eis illud quod uis.	 And fine threads are not suitable again because you will not achieve through them what you want due to narrowing.
Et non oportet, ut sit inter astellam et astellam minus quam digitus.	 And it should not be less than a finger's width between the stitches.
Quod si laeditur infirmus per extremitates astellarum post stricturam in locis sanis: tunc pone sub eis ex stuppa leni, aut lana carminata, donec nihil laedatur ex illo.	 If the patient is injured by the tips of the stitches after constriction in healthy places, then place under them some soft tow or carded wool until he is no longer harmed by it.
Quando autem est fractura cum uulnere, et accidit disruptio in cute, ego ueniam cum rememoratione eius in capitulo secundum singularitatem.	 When there is a fracture with a wound and disruption of the skin occurs, I will excuse myself from mentioning it again by its singularity in the second chapter.
Et scias, quod non omne membrum fractum oportet ut stringatur cum astellis a primo die.	 And know that not every broken bone should be tied with stitches on the first day.
Quod est, quia membrum quando est magnum, non oportet ut ponas superipsum astellas, nisi post quinque dies, aut septem, aut plus, secundum securitatem tuam ab euentu apostematis calidi.	 Which means that if the bone is large, you should not place stitches on it except after five days, or seven, or more, according to your security from the occurrence of a hot swelling.
Et iste est modus emplastrorum, quibus restaurabant antiqui, quae ponuntur super fracturam et dislocationem.	 And this is the method of plasters by which the ancients used to restore, and which are placed on a fracture or dislocation.
¶ Modus Emplastri communis abbreuiati, restaurans fracturam, conueniens pluribus complexionibus, praecipue mulieribus, et pueris: quoniam est ex eo super quod non uincit calor, neque frigus.	 The method of a common shortened plaster for restoring a fracture, suitable for most constitutions, especially women and children, because it is made from something that neither heat nor cold can overcome.
Et est, ut accipias ex puluere molendini, et est medulla farinae quae pendet in parietibus molendini apud motum molae: et conficias ipsum sicut est, praeter quod cribelles ipsum cum albugine oui: et pone confectionem eius non spissam, neque subtilem.	 And it is, that you take from the mill's dust, which is the marrow of flour hanging on the walls of the mill during the movement of the millstone: and make it as it is, except that you sift it with the thin skin of an egg; and put its preparation not thick, nor fine.
Deinde utere eo.	 Then use it.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius, restaurantis fracturam, et dislocationem, et torsionem.	 Another method of plaster for restoring a fracture, and a dislocation, and a twist.
Recipe almess, et laudani, et acaciae, et enulae, et mugath: et suc, omnium ana ʒ X myrrhae, et aloes amborum ana ʒ V et alethil ʒ XX terantur omnia, et cribellentur, et misceantur cum aqua alethil: aut cum albugine oui, si complexio infirmi est calefacta.	 Take almess, and laudanum, and acacia, and enula, and mugwort: and the juice of all, ana ʒ X; of myrrh, ana ʒ V; and of both aloes, ana ʒ V; and alethil, ʒ XX. Let everything be ground and sifted, and mixed with alethil water, or with the thin skin of an egg, if the patient's constitution is hot. ›
Deinde utere hoc emplastro.	 Then use this plaster.
Nam ipsum est bonae compositionis, restaurat ossa fracta uelociter, et confert pluribus hominibus.	 For it is of good composition, it quickly restores broken bones, and it benefits many people.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius, quod etiam confert fracturae et torsioni.	 Another method for making a plaster that is also beneficial for fractures and dislocations:
Recipe mugath, et mess, et alteae albae, omnium ana ʒ X myrrhae, et aloes amborum ana ʒ V acaciae ʒ VI boli armeni ʒ XX terantur omnia contritione multa, et cribellentur, et conficiantur cum aqua, aut albugine oui: et administrentur.	 Take equal parts of mugwort, marshmallow, and white hellebore, each one ounce; also take myrrh and both kinds of aloe, each half an ounce; and Armenian bole, two ounces. Grind all these ingredients very finely, sift them, and make them into a paste with water or the whites of eggs, then administer it.
¶ Modus Emplastri ad iuncturas, et ossa separata ex locis suis: et sedat dolorem accidentem eis, et scissuram ossis, et fracturam.	 A method for making a plaster to reattach separated joints and bones to their proper places, and to soothe the pain that occurs in them, as well as bone fissures and fractures:
Sumatur lana succida, et submergatur in aceto, et oleo decocto: et ponatur super locum.	 Take clean wool, soak it in vinegar and boiled oil, and apply it to the place.
Et in hoc quidem Emplastro non est uirtus restaurationis, sed est bonum in sedatione apostematis calidi: et expellit dolores proprie.	 And indeed this plaster does not have the power of restoration, but it is good for soothing hot inflammation and properly drives away pain. ︎
¶ Modus Emplastri, quod restaurat os fractum.	 A method for making a plaster that restores broken bone:
Sume folia fici surdi, et folia papaueris syluestris: et tere omnia, et fac emplastrum ex utrisque.	 Take the leaves of the common fig and the leaves of wild poppy, grind them all together, and make a plaster from both.
¶ Modus Emplastri abbreuiati, administrati apud restaurationem fracturae ossis: et quando tu uis resolutionem residui apostematis.	 A method for making an abbreviated plaster, to be used in the restoration of a bone fracture and when you wish to resolve any remaining inflammation.
Recipe radicis alteae, et camomillae, et florum uiolarum, et farinae herbi, omnium ana partem unam: terantur omnia, et conficiantur cum uino, si non est membrum calefactum.	 Take equal parts of the root of white hellebore, camomile, violet flowers, and barley flour. Grind all these together and make them into a paste with wine, unless the limb is hot.
Si uero est calefactum, tunc confice illud cum aqua coriandri humidi, aut cum aqua, et utere eo.	 If it is hot, then make it with water of moist coriander or with water and use it.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius fortioris in resolutione, quam istud primum, quando accidit apostema durum apud restaurationem membri.	 Another method for a stronger plaster for resolving inflammation than the first one, to be used when a hard inflammation occurs during the restoration of a limb: ︎
Recipe radicis alteae, et seminis lini, et balaustiae, et melliloti, et samsuci, et floris uiolarum, et camomillae, omnium ana, partem unam, terantur omnia, et conficiantur cum aqua salicis, aut cum aqua dulci, aut cum uino.	 Recipe of althea root, flax seed, balm, mallow, sumac, violet flower, and chamomile, all in equal parts; grind everything and make it with willow water or sweet water or wine.
Totum illud secundum caliditatem membri, et quietem caloris eius.	 All of this according to the warmth of the limb and the calmness of its heat.
Hippocrates uero non dixit in libro suo, quod ponatur super membrum fractum apud restaurationem eius, nisi caerotum factum ex caera, et oleo: non aliud: et narrauit, ut sit medium inter grossitudinem et subtilitatem.	 Hippocrates however did not say in his book that anything should be placed on a fractured limb at the time of its restoration except for plaster made from wax and oil; nothing else; and he related that it is a medium between coarseness and fineness.
Galeno autem uisum est, ut ponantur super membrum fractum apud restaurationem eius res, in quibus est exiccatio caliditatis, sicut myrrha, et aloes et olibanum, et similia eis ex eis quae narrauimus.	 However, Galen believed that substances which have a drying effect on heat, such as myrrh, aloes, and frankincense, along with similar substances from those we mentioned, should be placed on a fractured limb at the time of its restoration.
¶ Modus Emplastri quod confert ad laesionem et dolorem.	 ¶ Method of plaster which is beneficial for injury and pain.
Recipe mugath, et ciceris, et capillorum hominis incisorum, aut pennae auis, et alteae, et salis partes aequales: terantur, et cribellentur, et conficiantur: et fiat ex eo emplastrum.	 Recipe mugwort, chickpeas, human hair cuttings or bird feathers, marshmallow root, and salt in equal parts; grind, sift, and make it into a plaster.
Quantitas autem secundum quam oportet, ut remaneat ligatura, deinde soluatur, est, ut consideres tunc, si non accidit infirmo dolor, neque pruritus, neque mouetur os fractum a loco suo: tunc non resoluas ipsum diebus multis.	 The quantity by which it should remain bound and then be dissolved is to observe at that time if no pain occurs in the patient, nor itching, nor does the broken bone move from its place; then you should not dissolve it for many days.
Quod si accidat ei in loco pruritus uehemens, aut dolor inquietans, aut inflatio: tunc propera, et solue in hora ipsum, et aufer emplastrum ab eo: et accipe pannum lenem, aut spongiam marinam lenem, humidam: et submerge eam in aqua tepida, et ablue cum ea locum, donec quiescat pruritus, et sedetur dolor.	 If it happens that a severe itch or disturbing pain or swelling occurs in that place, then hurry and dissolve it in the same hour; remove the plaster from him; and take a soft cloth or a soft marine sponge moistened with water; submerge it in warm water and wash the place with it until the itching subsides and the pain is relieved.
Deinde dimitte membrum quiescere una hora.	 Then allow the member to rest for one hour.
Deinde pone super ipsum lanam succidam, submersam in aceto et oleo, aut oleo rosato: et liga super ipsum nocte una, donec sis securus ab apostemate calido, et quiescat inflatio membri, et remoueatur dolor eius.	 Then place on it a piece of cloth soaked in vinegar and oil, or rose-scented oil; and bind it on for one night, until you are sure that the hot abscess has been relieved, and the swelling of the member has subsided, and its pain is removed.
Deinde itera ipsum ad stricturam subtilem, et emplastrum paruum: et non stringas ipsum constrictione tua prima, et subtilia cum eo, donec sanetur.	 Then apply to it a fine bandage and a small poultice; but do not bind it too tightly with your first bandage, and make the bandages that follow with it, until it is healed.
Quod si uides, quod apostema, et rubedo, et dolor, et inflatio, et omnia accidentia iam remota sunt penitus, et indiges emplastro et strictura, tunc itera illud sicut fecisti in primis aequaliter.	 But if you see that the abscess, redness, pain, swelling, and all symptoms have been completely removed, and you no longer need a poultice and bandage, then bind it as you did at first, evenly.
Quod si non accidit membro aliquid ex eis quae diximus, tune non soluas ipsum, nisi post tres dies, aut quatuor, aut quinque, aut septem.	 But if nothing happens to the member from those things which I have mentioned, then do not unbind it until after three or four or five or seven days.
Et quando que dimittitur uiginti diebus totum illud, secundum quod apparet tibi ex solutione membri, sicut diximus, donec quando adhaeret fractura, et approximat coagulatio carnis super eam: adde etiam tunc in strictura plus quam strictura tua prima tota: et adde etiam in ingrossatione cibi infirmi, secundum quod praecessit rememoratio eius.	 And when it is unbound after twenty days, according as you see from the release of the member, as we have said, until such time as the fracture adheres and the coagulation of flesh comes together upon it: add also at that time more to your bandage than your first whole bandage; and add also in the thickening of weak food, according as you remember before.
Si autem uides locum fracturae iam exiccari, et extenuari plus quam oportet: tunc scias, quod nutrimentum prohibetur peruenire ad ipsum.	 But if you see the place of the fracture already drying out and becoming thin beyond what is fitting: then know that nourishment is prevented from reaching it.
Embroca ergo ipsum cum aqua tepida apud omnem uicem qua soluis ipsum, et sit illud in omnibus tribus diebus, et alleuia stricturam parumper.	 Soak it therefore with warm water at every time when you unbind it, and let this be for all three days, and relieve the bandage a little.
Per hanc ergo operationem currit ad membrum nutrimentum, et sanatur uelociter.	 By this procedure nourishment comes to the member, and it is healed quickly.
Illud autem quod faciunt stolidi restauratores ex fractura membri uice alia, quando non restauratur in primis, secundum quod oportet, et restauratur secundum tortuositatem, est error ex operatione eorum, et timor magnus: et si esset rectum, dixissent illud antiqui in libris suis, et operati fuissent cum eo.	 But what foolish repairers do to a member when it is not first properly repaired after a fracture, and they repair it according to crookedness, that is an error from their procedure, and a great fear: and if it were right, the ancients would have said this in their books, and would have done so with it.
Et ego non uidi alicubi eorum uestigium in illo omnino, et rectius est, ut non fiat illud.	 And I did not see their trace anywhere in that at all, and it is better if it is not done.
¶ De factura accidente in capite.	 On the making of an injury to the head.
Caput III.	 Chapter III.
Species fracturae sunt diuersae, et figurae eius multae: et caussae eius sunt distinctae.	 There are various kinds of fractures and many shapes; their causes are also distinct.
Nam ex fractura est quae fit a percussione cum ense: et percussio aufert os totum usquequo peruenit ad siphac, quod est sub osse, sicut facit axia in ligno: et propter illud nominatur haec species fracturae Axialis.	 For there is a fracture caused by a blow with a sword: and the blow removes the bone entirely to where it reaches the marrow, which is under the bone, just as an axe does in wood; and on account of this, this type of fracture is called 'axial'.
Aut ensis incidit quiddam ossis, et incidit faciem eius, et non penetrat incisio usque ad ultimum eius: et nominatur haec species fracturae Kalaan, id est, Leuatio absolute.	 Or the sword cuts into part of a bone and cuts its surface but does not penetrate all the way through; and this type of fracture is called 'kalaan', that is, 'complete incision'.
Et est uulnus duarum fracturarum, aut magnum, aut paruum.	 And there are two types of wounds of fractures: large or small. ¶
Et ex fractura est, quae est contritio, aut attritio: et caussa eius est percussio cum lapide, aut casus super lapidem, aut eis similia.	 And among the fractures is 'crushing' or 'grinding', and its cause is a blow with a stone or falling onto a stone or similar things.
Et haec fractura est etiam aut penetrans, quae iam appropinquat panniculo, quod est sub osse: aut est in facie ossis: et est uulnus harum duarum fracturarum etiam aut paruum, aut magnum.	 And this fracture is also either penetrating and approaching the marrow which is under the bone, or it is on the surface of a bone; and there are two types of wounds of these fractures: small or large.
Et ex fractura est, quae est occulta in osse in subtilitate capilli: et est fissura parua, et propter illud nominatur haec species fracturae Capillaris.	 And among the fractures is one which is hidden within a bone, like a hair's breadth, and it is a small crack; and on account of this it is called 'capillary'. ¶ ‌
Et ex eis est fractura, quae fit a casu, aut percussione lapidis, et eis similium, quae faciunt ingredi laminam ossis ad interiora, et fit loco concauitas: sicut accidit caldariis aeris, quando occurrit eis percussio, et ingreditur pars eorum ad interiora.	 And among them is the fracture which occurs from a fall or blow with a stone and similar things, which cause a layer of bone to split towards the inside, creating a depression, as happens in bronze cauldrons when they are struck, and part of them splits towards the inside.
Et plurimum quidem fit illud in capitibus humidorum ossium, sicut sunt capita puerorum.	 And this occurs most frequently in the heads of moist bones, such as those of children.
Et fiunt omnibus istis speciebus fracturae satagiae separatae, et ego ueniam cum rememoratione illius totius in loco suo.	 And for all these types of fractures, splints are separated, and I will come with a reminder of the whole in its place.
Et cognoscimus omnes has species fracturae per detectionem super eam, et inquisitionem earum cum tentis, et ablationem carnium corruptarum, quae sunt super eas.	 And we know all these types of fractures by examination upon them, and investigation with probes, and removal of corrupted flesh that is upon them.
Species uero Capillaris cognoscitur per hoc, quod detegitur super os, et abstergitur, et linitur super ipsum cum encaustro: fractura enim apparet nigra.	 But the species of the capillary is recognized by this, that it is exposed above the skin, and cleaned, and covered with wax: for the fracture appears black.
In curatione autem fracturae, considera in primis accidentia infirmi: tunc si uides ex accidentibus quod significet significatione manifesta super timorem, sicut uomitus cholerae, et extensio, et amissio intellectus, et abscisio uocis, et syncopis, et febris acuta, et egressus oculorum, et rubedo eorum, et similia eis ex accidentibus in pluribus dispositionibus, proculdubio non sanatur: et si uides accidentia non terrentia te, et speras salutem: tunc incipe curationem eius.	 In the treatment of fractures, consider first the patient's symptoms: then if you see from the symptoms something that indicates a clear danger, such as vomiting of bile, distention, loss of intellect, hoarseness, fainting, acute fever, protrusion of the eyes, their redness, and similar symptoms in various conditions, it is certainly not cured: and if you see non-threatening symptoms and hope for recovery, then begin its treatment.
Quod est, si uenit ad te uulneratus in primis cum uulneratur: et est illud in diebus hyemis, tunc oportet, ut studeas in ablatione ossis ante diem quartumdecimum secundum omnem dispositionem.	 That is, if a wounded person comes to you at the time of wounding: and it happens in the winter days, then you must strive for the removal of bone before the fourteenth day according to every condition.
Et si est in diebus aestatis, tunc oportet, ut properes remouere os ante diem septimum, antequam corrumpatur quod est sub osse ex panniculo, et accidant illa accidentia quae narrauimus.	 And if it is in the summer days, then you must hasten to remove the bone before the seventh day, before that which is under the bone from the membrane corrupts, and those symptoms we have mentioned occur.
Quod si fractura ossis iam peruenit ad panniculum tangentem cerebrum, et est cum minutiis, et attractione: tunc oportet, ut incidas partem comminutam, et attritam, secundum quod narro tibi.	 But if the fracture of bone has already reached the membrane touching the brain, and it is with fragments, and drawing inward: then you must cut away the broken and drawn part, as I tell you.
Et est, ut radas caput uulnerati: et detege super os secundum quemcunque modum possibile est tibi: et secundum figuram uulneris, et quod leue est super infirmum.	 And it is that you shave the head of the wounded person: and expose the bone in whatever way possible for you: according to the shape of the wound, and what is easiest on the patient.
Quod si accidat tibi apud detectionem ossis fluxus sanguinis, aut apostema calidum: tunc oppone ei cum eo quod oportet.	 If during the extraction of a bone there is bleeding or a hot abscess, then apply that which is necessary.
Et est, ut impleas locum cum pannis infusis in uino, et oleo rosato: et facias quiescere uulnus, donec sedetur apostema, et sis securus a fluxu sanguinis.	 And it is that you should fill the place with cloths soaked in wine and rose oil, and make the wound rest until the abscess settles, and be secure from bleeding.
Deinde incipe in curatione ossis, et ablatione eius.	 Then begin with the treatment of the bone and its removal.
Et illud fit secundum unum duorum modorum.	 And this is done according to one of two methods.
Modus quidem unus est, ut incidas os cum Incisorio strictae aciei: et haec est forma eius.	 One method is to cut the bone with a trephine of sharp edge, and this is its form.
Dende administra Incisorium aliud post Incisorum latius eo parumper: et haec est forma eius.	 Then administer another trephine after the first, wider than it by a little; and this is its form.
Deinde administra etiam Incisorium aliud latius etiam quam secundum.	 Then administer also another trephine, even wider than the second one.
Et modus secundus est, ut sit apud te numerus Incisoriorum diuersorum: quorum quaedam sint latiora quibusdam, et quaedam eorum breuiora quibusdam: et sint in ultimo acuitatis extremitatum suarum, et sint ex ferro indo, aut fuled: et utere facilitate in percussione super Incisorium, ut non concutiat caput, et laedat ipsum.	 And the second method is that you should have with you a number of different trephines, some of which are wider than others and some shorter; and they should be sharp at the end of their extremities, and made of Indian iron or steel; and use facility in striking over the trephine, so that it does not shake the head and injure it.  />
Si autem os est forte, durum: tunc oportet, ut perfores in circumitu eius, antequam tu administres Incisoria, cum Terebris quae nominantur Terebra non profundantia: et non nominantur ita, nisi quoniam ipsa non pertranseunt terminum ossis carnei ad illud, quod est post ipsum: propterea, quod Terebro est extremitas rotunda super illud, quod est sub capite eius acuto, similis margini, et circulus paruus prohibet submergi, et pertransire spissitudinem ossis.	 But if the bone happens to be hard and strong, then it is necessary that you should bore around it before you administer the trephines with boring instruments called non-penetrating borers; and they are not so named except because they themselves do not penetrate the end of the bony substance to what is behind it; for this reason, since the end of the borer is rounded over that which is under its sharp point, like a border and small circle, it prevents sinking in and penetrating the thickness of the bone.  /> />
Et conuenit tibi, ut accipias ex istis Terebris numerum multum, quorum unumquodque conueniat quantitati spissitudinis ossis, donec praesens sit tibi omni craneo Terebrum: cuius extremitatis acutae quantitas in longitudine et breuitate sit, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis illius cranei.	 And it is fitting for you to take from these borers a great many, each of which fits the thickness of the bone, until you have with you a borer for every skull; and the length and shortness of the sharp end of its tip should be according to the thickness of that particular skull.
Et haec est forma trium specierum Terebrorum, uel Trepanorum.	 And this is the form of three types of Terebrae, or Trepanes.
Qualitas autem perforandi in circumitu ossis fracti, est: ut ponas Terebrum super os, et reuoluas ipsum digitis tuis, donec scias, os iam penetratum esse.	 The quality of penetrating around the broken bone is this: you place the Terebra on the bone and roll it with your fingers until you know that the bone has already been penetrated.
Deinde permuta Terebrum ad locum alium, et pone quod est inter omne foramen quantitatem grossitudinis radii, aut circiter illud.	 Then change the Terebra to another place and put between every hole a quantity of thickness of the radius or about that amount.
Deinde incide cum Incisoriis quod est inter omne foramen ex osse: et fac illud subtilius quam potes super illud ex fine leuitatis, sicut diximus, donec eradices os, aut manu tua, aut cum aliquo alio ex quibusdam instrumentis, quae parasti ad illud: sicut tenaliae, et forpices subtiles.	 Then cut with the Incisors what is between every hole from the bone and make that thinner than you can over that to the point of fineness, as we said, until you remove the bone either by hand or with some other of those instruments which you have prepared for it, such as tweezers and fine forceps.
Et oportet, ut caueas omni cautela, ne tangat Terebrum, aut Incisorium aliquid ex siphac.	 And it is necessary that you take care with all caution that the Terebra or Incisors touch nothing of the brain.
Cum ergo circumieris os perforando, et separatum fuerit a siphac, si fuerit continuum cum eo, et extraxeris ipsum, oportet ut radas, et aeques extremitatem eius quod remanet in osse cum instrumento alio simili Incisorio.	 Therefore when you go around the bone by penetrating and have separated it from the brain if it was continuous with it, and after you have extracted it, it is necessary that you scrape and even out the end of what remains in the bone with another similar instrument like the Incisors.
Verumtamen oportet, ut sit tenuis et subtilis magis aliis Incisoriis.	 However, it ought to be thin and fine more than other Incisors.
Quod si remanet aliquid ex ossibus paruis, et satagiae: tunc accipe ea cum facilitate, cum eo quod est apud te ex instrumentis.	 If something remains from the small bones and splinters then take those easily with that which you have among your instruments.
Deinde cura uulnus post illud cum liciniis, et unguentis quae diximus.	 Then cure the wound afterwards with compresses and ointments as we said.
Et modus alius operationis est facilis, prorsus longinquus a timore: quem dixit Galenus, et laudauit ipsum laude magna: et iste est sermo eius.	 And another method of operating is very easy and far from fear, which Galen said and praised it greatly, and this is his statement.
Necese est tibi in primis, ut incipias detegere partem ossis ex loco, in quo fractura est uehementior, et manifestior: donec quando detexeris illam partem, et posueris sub eo extremitatem huius Incisorii lenticularis, cuius haec est forma.	 It is necessary for you first to begin to uncover the part of the bone from the place where the fracture is more violent and manifest until when you have uncovered that part and placed under it the end of this lenticular Incisors, which has this form.
Et pars lenticularis, lenis non incidit aliquid: et pars acuta eius in duabus lateribus eius uadens in longitudinem, sicut uides: ut sit pars lenticularis innixa ad siphac, facie eius incidente acuta in osse.	 And the lens-shaped part, the gentle one, does not cut anything: and its sharp part goes into two sides of it, along its length, as you see: so that the lens-shaped part rests against the siphac, with its sharp end cutting into the bone.
Deinde percute super Incisorium a parte una cum malleo paruo, donec incidas totum os cum facilitate, sicut reuoluitur: et tu sis securus ex panniculo, quod non accidat in eo accidens, quod timeas prorsus.	 Then strike over the Incisor with a small hammer from one side until you cut through the entire bone easily, as it is turned: and you will be confident from the cloth that no accident will happen to it which you fear completely.
Et si medicans non esset stultior hominum, et magis ignarus eius, nec esset dormiens, tunc si remaneret aliquid annexum ossi ex panniculo in quibusdam locis, incideret ipsum ab eo cum extremitate incisorii lenticularis ipsius, et liberaret ipsum ab eo cum facilitate.	 And if the physician is not more foolish than other men and is less ignorant of it, and does not sleep, then if anything from the cloth remains attached to the bone in certain places, he would cut it off with the end of the lens-shaped incisor itself, and free it from there easily.
Liberatur enim ab eo sine nocumento, et absque timore.	 It is freed from that without harm and without fear.
Et si fractura ossis non penetret usque ad panniculum, et illud quod abscinditur ab osse est facies eius, et remanent in ipso asperitas et satagiae subtiles: tunc oportet, ut radas illam asperitatem, et eradices illas satagias cum rasoriis subtilibus ex quibus praeparasti numerum diuersarum quantitatum, ut sit tibi possibile administrare ex eis in omni loco conuenientiora eorum, et rectiora ipsorum, secundum illud ad quod perducit te operatio, et ipsum os fractum, et figura eius.	 And if the bone fracture does not reach the cloth, and what is cut off from the bone is its surface, and roughness and fine splinters remain in it, then it is necessary to scrape away that roughness and remove those splinters with fine rasps which you have prepared in various sizes, so that you may administer the most suitable and straightest ones according to the nature of the operation, the fractured bone itself, and its shape.
Et oportet, ut administres in rasione tua, qua in primis radis os, latius illorum rasoriorum.	 And it is necessary for you to administer with wider ones first than those rasps.
Deinde utere post ipsum subtiliore eo.	 Then use a finer one after that.
Et non cesses facere illud secundum continuitatem, donec peruenias ad administrandum tenuius, et subtilius eorum omnium.	 And do not cease to do this continuously until you reach the point of using the finest and most delicate one of all.
In unaquaque autem fissurarum reliquarum paruarum capillarium, et fractura subtili, oportet ut administres curam, secundum illud quod perducit ad rectificationem eius.	 But in each of the remaining small cracks and subtle fractures, it is necessary to take care according to what leads to its correction.
Et est res quae non occultatur super omnem, cui in hac arte est quodlibet studium, et stetit super illud quod scripsimus, et ostendimus in fracturis magnis.	 And it is a thing that is not hidden from anyone who has any interest in this art, and we have written about it and demonstrated in cases of great fractures.
Si autem panniculus detectus retinetur, quando tu eradicas os: tunc oportet, ut accipias pannum lini, secundum quantitatem uulneris, et submerge ipsum in oleo rosa, et pone ipsum super orificium uulneris.	 But if the skin flap is retained when you extract the bone: then it is necessary to take a piece of linen cloth according to the size of the wound and soak it in rose oil, and place it over the opening of the wound.
Deinde accipe pannum alium duplicatum, aut triplicatum, et submerge ipsum in uino et oleo rosa, et pone ipsum super pannum primum: et fac illud quam facilius potes super illud, ut non grauetur siphac.	 Then take another piece of cloth, either double or triple-folded, and soak it in wine and rose oil, and place it over the first cloth. And make sure to do this as lightly as possible so that it does not burden the patient.
Deinde administra supra ipsum ligamentum latum: et non stringas ipsum, nisi per quantitatem quae teneat uulnus tantum: et dimitte ipsum cum hac cura die uno, aut diebus duobus, donec sis securus ab apostemate calido.	 Then apply a broad bandage over it and do not tighten it unless it holds the wound firmly; and leave it for one day or two days until you are certain that there is no hot swelling.
Deinde solue ipsum, et administra post illud medicinas cum quibus est superflua siccitas: sicut radices lilii, et farina herbi, et puluis thuris, et aristolochia, et similia eis: et est, ut facias ex istis medicinis puluerem, qui puluerizetur super uulnus sicut sunt siccae.	 Then loosen it and apply after that medicines with which there is a dry excess, such as the root of lily, powdered herb, frankincense dust, aristolochia, and similar things; and it should be made into a powder from these medicines to be sprinkled over the wound like dry things. 》
Et uniuersaliter administra in illo omnem medicinam de proprietate cuius est ut abstergat, et non mordicet.	 And generally apply every medicine that has the property of cleansing and not causing irritation.
Et caue secundum tuam uirtutem, ut uulnus in curatione tua sit limpidum: neque sit in ea sordes unguenti, neque sordicies.	 And be careful according to your skill that the wound in your treatment is clean; and there is no dirt from ointment or other impurities in it.
Neque dimittas uirus aggregari in eo omnino: quoniam quando uirus aggregatur super panniculum cerebri, corrumpit eum, et putrefacit ipsum, et accidit super infirmum post illud malicia magna: et iam accidit in siphac capitis, cum mundificatur ab eo os, praecipue quando negligitur cura eius, nigredo in superficie eius.	 Do not allow any pus to gather on it at all; for when pus gathers on the membrane of the brain, it corrupts and putrefies it, and a great evil befalls the patient afterwards: and this happens especially in skull wounds, when the bone is cleared from them, particularly when its care is neglected, with blackening on its surface.
Considera ergo tunc, si accidunt infirmo accidentia quae diximus, scias, quia est pernitiosum proculdubio.	 Therefore, if such afflictions befall the patient, know that it is undoubtedly fatal.
Et si nigredo non accidit, nisi a medicina quae ponitur super ipsum, et est in uirtute illius medicinae, ut faciat illam nigredinem: tunc oportet, ut accipias ex melle partem unam, ex oleo rosato partes tres, et linias cum eis pannum.	 And if the blackness does not occur except from the medicine that is placed upon it, and it is in the power of that medicine to produce that blackness; then you should take one part of honey and three parts of rose oil, and anoint a cloth with them.
Deinde pone ipsum super siphac: postea cura ipsum cum speciebus curationis quae conueniunt, donec sanetur.	 Then place it upon the pillow; afterwards treat it with the appropriate remedies until it heals.
¶ De restauratione Nasi quando frangitur.	 ¶ On the Restoration of the Nose When It Is Broken.
Caput IIII.	 Chapter Four.
Scias, quod non franguntur ex Naso nisi duae partes eius superiores simul, aut una earum: propterea, quod ipse sunt duo ossa: quoniam inferius eius est cartilaginosum, non frangitur, et non accidit ei nisi attritio, et tortuositas, et simitas.	 Know that only the two upper parts of the nose are broken simultaneously or one of them, because they are two bones; for the lower part is cartilage and cannot be broken, and nothing happens to it except for abrasion, twisting, and flattening.
Si frangitur una duarum partium eius, tunc oportet, ut intromittas digitum paruum in foramen Nasi, et aeques illam fracturam digito tuo indice, et pollice deforis, donec redeat Nasus super figuram suam naturalem: et fiat illud arte, cum facilitate.	 If one of the two parts is broken, then you should insert a small finger into the nostril and equalize that fracture with your index finger and thumb from outside until the nose returns to its natural shape; and this should be done skillfully and easily.  />
Et caue, ne accidat per operationem tuam illam super infirmum dolor.	 And take care that no pain occurs to the patient due to your action.
Quod si fractura est in superiore parte Nasi, et non perueniat ad illam digitus: tunc oportet, ut aequetur extremitate radii, in quo sit grossitudo parua.	 But if the fracture is in the upper part of the nose and your finger cannot reach it; then it should be equalized with the tip of a small stick.
Si uero fractura est in duabus partibus, tunc fac simile illius: et propera cum restauratione eius in die primo fracturae, si est possibile.	 But if the fracture is in both parts, then do likewise; and hasten with its restoration on the first day of the fracture, if possible.
Et si non, tunc post diem septimum, aut decimum apud quietem apostematis calidi.	 And if not, then after the seventh or tenth day during the quiet stage of a hot swelling.
Deinde intromitte in extremitate Nasi licinium ex panno lini, si fractura est in parte una: aut intromite duo licinia si fractura est in duabus partibus: et sit in licinio grossitudo tantae quantitatis, quae impleat foramen Nasi.	 Then insert a linen wick into the tip of the nose if the fracture is in one part; or insert two wicks if the fracture is in both parts; and let the thickness of the wick be such that it fills the nostril.  /> 
Et dixerunt quidam antiquorum restauratorum, ut infundantur licinia in butyro, et permutentur omni die.	 And some of the ancient surgeons said that ointments should be poured into butter and changed every day.
Illud uero non uidetur mihi, imo oportet, ut infundatur licinium in albugine oui, confecto cum puluere molendini.	 However, this does not seem right to me; rather, the ointment should be poured into a bladder of an egg and mixed with ground pepper.
Deinde dimitte licinium, donec firmetur os, et induretur cartilago.	 Then leave the ointment until the bone hardens and the cartilage thickens.
Et quandoque intromittitur in Nasum loco licinii penna anseris, postquam inuoluitur super ipsam pannus lenis: et fit, quod ipsa tenet fracturam Nasi uehementius, et ut non prohibeatur infirmus ab inspiratione.	 And sometimes a goose feather is inserted into the nose instead of ointment, after wrapping the nose in a soft cloth: and this happens so that it holds the broken nose more firmly, and so that the sick person is not prevented from breathing.
Et non est haec res necessaria.	 And this is not necessary.
Si uis, fac illud: et si uis, fac licinia.	 If you want, do that; and if you want, make ointments.
Quod si accidat Naso iterum dum operaris apostema calidum, emplastra nasum cum caeroto, aut cum coto infuso in oleo rosato, aut modico ex dyaquilon.	 But if a hot abscess occurs on the nose while you are working on it, make a plaster for the nose with caerot or cotyledon boiled in rose oil or a little of diacodion.
Si autem non accidit apostema calidum, tunc oportet, ut emplastres ipsum cum farina sisami, et puluere thuris confecti cum albugine oui.	 But if a hot abscess does not occur, then you should make plasters for it with sesame flour and frankincense powder mixed with an egg bladder.
Deinde pone super ipsum stuppam lenem, et non liges Nasum cum aliquo omnino.	 Then place soft wool on top of it, and do not bind the nose at all.
Si uero franguntur ossa Nasi fractura parua, aut comminuuntur, tunc oportet, ut scindas super ea, et extrahas ipsa cum instrumentis quae conueniunt eis.	 But if the broken bones of a small nose fracture are shattered, then you should cut through them and remove them with appropriate instruments.
Deinde sue scissuram, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat, et consolidat ex emplastris conuenientibus ad illud, uel unguentis.	 Then, whether it is a cut or a wound, take care of it with what causes the flesh to grow and strengthens from suitable plasters or ointments for that.
Quod si accidat inter Nasum uulnus, tunc oportet, ut cures ipsum cum liciniis: et administres cannulam de plumbo, donec sanetur.	 But if a wound occurs between the nostrils, then you should take care of it with ointments and administer a lead tube until it heals. ➤
¶ De restauratione Mandibulae inferioris, quando disrumpitur.	 § On the restoration of the lower jaw when it is broken.
Caput V.	 Chapter 5
Quando disrumpitur Mandibula inferior, et fractura eius non est cum uulnere: conspice tunc si est fractura eius deforis tantum, et non frangitur in duo, et curuatur ad interiora: tunc cognitio eius est facilis.	 When the lower jaw is broken and its fracture is not with a wound, then see if it is only broken on the outside and is not split into two parts and curves toward the inside; then its diagnosis is easy.
Oportet ergo, si est fractura eius in parte dextra, ut intromittas digitum indicem sinistrae in os infirmi: similiter si fractura est in mandibula sinistra, tunc intromitte indicem manus dextrae: et impelle cum eo gibbositatem fracturae deintus cum facilitate ad exteriora cum manu tua altera ab interiori parte ossis decenter, et cum eo aequa ipsam.	 Therefore, if the fracture is on the right side, insert with your left hand the index finger into the patient's mouth; similarly, if the fracture is on the left mandible, then insert the index finger of your right hand: and with it push the prominence of the fracture inward with ease from the inside with your other hand from the interior part of the bone neatly, and make it equal.
Quod si fractura mandibulae iam separata est in duo, tunc oportet, ut administres extersionem a duabus partibus, secundum rectitudinem: donec possibilis sit aequatio eius.	 But if the jaw fracture is already separated into two parts, then you should administer traction from both parts, according to the straight line, until it is possible to make them equal.
Si autem iam accidit in dentibus commotio, aut disruptio: tunc stringe illos de quibus speras quod remaneant cum filo auri, aut argenti, aut seta.	 But if the shock or disruption has already occurred to the teeth, then bind them with gold wire or silver wire, or silk thread from which you hope they will remain.
Deinde pone super mandibulam fractam caerotum.	 Then place a splint on the broken jaw.
Deinde pone super ipsum pannum duplicatum, et pone super pannum astellam magnam decenter factam: aut frustum cutis soleae aequale, in longitudinem mandibulae.	 Then place on it two layers of cloth, and on the cloth a large neatly made bandage; or an equal piece of sole skin in the length of the jaw.
Deinde liga ipsum desuper, secundum quod praeparatur tibi ligatura eius, et conuenit ipsius applicatio, donec non destruitur: et praecipe infirmo, uti tranquillitate et quiete: et pone cibum eius sorbitiones lenes.	 Then bind it from above according to how its bandage is prepared and its application is suitable until it does not break; and advise the patient to rest and be quiet; and give him soft food.
Si autem estimas, quod iam alteratur aliquid figurae aliquo modorum: tunc propera, et solue ipsum in die tertio.	 But if you think that something has changed in the shape in any way, then hurry and remove it on the third day.
Deinde rectifica quod alteratum est ex eo, et emplastra ipsum ex puluere molendini, cum albugine oui, aut cum farina sisami, postquam tu abstuleris caerotum: et pone super emplastrum lanam lenem.	 Then correct what has changed from it, and apply a plaster of mill dust with egg white or sesame flour, after you have removed the splint; and place soft wool on top of the plaster.
Dum ergo permanet annexum illud emplastrum super ipsum, et non alteratur ossis dispositio, dimitte ipsum, ne soluas, donec sanetur: aut stringe fracturam.	 While that bandage remains on it and the bone's position does not change, leave it alone, lest you loosen it, until it heals; or bind up the fracture.
Multotiens enim stringitur haec fractura in tribus septimanis.	 For this fracture is often bound for three weeks.
Quod si interim accidat apostema calidum, tunc administra illud quod diximus multotiens in sedatione eius, donec remoueatur illud apostema.	 But if a hot abscess occurs meanwhile, then administer what we have often said for its reduction, until that abscess is removed.
Et si fractura est cum uulnere, considera.	 And if the fracture is with a wound, consider [this].
Namsi iam separatur ex osse frustum, aut a satagie: tunc subtilia te in hoc, ut auferas illa frusta satagiae cum eo quod conuenit tibi in ablatione eorum ex instrumentis.	 For if already a fragment is separated from the bone, either by itself or through carelessness; then be skillful in this, so that you remove those fragments of splinters along with what suits you among the instruments for their removal.
Si uero orificium uulneris est strictum, tunc amplifica ipsum cum phlebotomo secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	 But if the wound's opening is narrow, then enlarge it with a fleam according to your need.
Deinde quando abstuleris illa satagie, et non remanserit ex eis aliquid, sue tunc orificium uulneris, si est amplum: et si non, pone super ipsum ex emplastris quae conueniunt ad illud, et incarnant illud, donec sanetur.	 Then when you have removed those splinters and nothing remains of them, whether the wound's opening is then wide or not—if it is not, place on it one of the bandages that suit it, and allow it to heal until it heals.
¶ De restauratione Furculae, quando frangitur.	 ¶ On restoring the collarbone when it breaks.
Caput VI.	 Chapter VI.
Plurimum quidem frangitur Furcula ab anteriore parte ex parte humeri, et fractura eius fit secundum unum trium modorum.	 Indeed, the collarbone most often breaks from its anterior part towards the shoulder, and its fracture occurs in one of three ways.
Aut enim frangitur et separatur in duo, praeter quod accidant in ea satagiae: et est facilius ad restaurationem eius.	 For it either breaks and separates into two parts, apart from the fact that splinters may occur in it; and this is easier to restore.
Aut ita, quod accidunt in osse satagiae: et est difficilius ad restaurationem.	 Or [it happens] such that splinters occur in the bone, and this is more difficult to restore.  /> Or [it breaks] with a fragment of bone remaining attached to it; and this is most difficult to restore.
Aut ita, quod est fractura cum uulnere.	 Or so that [the break] occurs with a wound.
Et operatio in ea quando fractura est absque uulnere, est, ut facias praesentes esse duos ministros, ut teneat unus eorum adiutorium quod sequitur Furculam fractam, et alter extendat collum uersus partem.	 And the procedure in it when the break is without a wound is to have two assistants present: so that one of them holds support for the broken collarbone, and the other extends the neck towards the affected side.  /> Then you place the fingers of your right hand under the broken end [of the collarbone], while with your left hand you push the healthy end upwards.  /> And you continue doing this until the broken ends join together perfectly.  /> Then you bind them tightly with a bandage, and leave it for fifteen days or so, not allowing anyone to touch it.
Deinde aequa fracturam digitis tuis, donec fiat forma eius, secundum quod oportet: et non sit in ea eminentia, neque concauitas.	 Then make the fracture even with your fingers until it takes on its proper form: and there should be no projection or depression.
Quod si indiges extensione plus, tunc oportet, ut ponas sub titillico infirmi spheram ex panno, aut lana: et sit magnitudo eius secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae: et extende, et eleua Furculam, et coarta spheram manu tua, donec aeques fracturam, secundum quod oportet.	 If you need more extension, then it is necessary to place under the patient's scrotum a pad of cloth or wool: and its size should be according to your needs: and extend and raise the Furcula, and compress the pad with your hand, until you make the fracture even, as required.
Quod si non potes trahere extremitatem Furculae ad exteriora: propterea, quia peruenit ad profundum: tunc oportet, ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam: et ponas sub humero eius puluinar medium in magnitudine, et premat minister humerum eius ad inferiora, donec eleuetur os Furculae quod est in profundo ad sursum: atque tunc rectifica fracturam, et aequa eam digitis tuis.	 If you cannot pull the end of the Furcula outward because it has gone too deep, then it is necessary that the patient be turned over onto his back: and place under his shoulder a medium-sized pad, and have your assistant press down on the shoulder until the bone of the Furcula which is deep comes up: and then correct the fracture and make it even with your fingers.
Si autem sentis sathaiatum ex Furcula, et mouetur: tunc oportet, ut findas super illud, et extrahas ipsum alsathaiatum cum facilitate.	 But if you feel a splinter from the Furcula that moves, then it is necessary to scrape over it and remove the splinter easily.
Si autem est retentum in osse, tunc ingenia in incisione eius cum uno Incisoriorum quae praeparasti ad illud, postquam tu posueris sub Furcula instrumentum quod seruat sifach: et est instrumentum ex ligno, aut ex ferro.	 If however it is retained in the bone, then use an awl in its incision with one of the instruments that you have prepared for that purpose, after you have placed under the Furcula an instrument that preserves Sifach: and this instrument is made of wood or iron.
Et haec est forma eius.	 And this is its shape.
Assimilatur cochleari cui non est concauitas.	 It resembles a spoon without a bowl.
Et sit latitudo eius secundum illud quo indiges eo ex magnitudine ossis, et paruitate eius.	 And its width should be according to your need for it, in proportion to the size and thickness of the bone.
Longitudo uero eius etiam secundum quod possibile est tibi ad operationem.	 Its length also according to what is possible for you in working with it.
Et habeat duas extremitates, sicut uides: et extremitas una sit ampla, et altera stricta.	 And it should have two ends, as you see: and one end should be wide and the other narrow.
Si autem disruptio uulneris quod scidisti quando extraxisti sathaiatum ossis, est ampla, et securaris ab apostemate calido: tunc aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura.	 If however the gap of the wound that you cut when you removed the bone splinter is wide and you are safe from inflammation, then bring together the two lips of the wound with a stitch.
Et si disruptio est parua, aut times apostema calidum: tunc imple uulnus cum pannis, et puluillis secundum quantitatem scissurae uulneris.	 And if the wound is small or you suspect a warm abscess, then fill the wound with cloths and fine wool according to the size of the wound.
Quod si accidat apostema calidum, tunc infunde pannum in oleo rosato, et aceto, et uino, et pone super ipsum.	 If a warm abscess occurs, then soak a cloth in rose oil, vinegar, and wine, and place it on the wound.
Strictura uero ossis quando est absque uulnere, et absque sectione, est, ut ponas super os emplastrum factum ex farina molendini cum albugine oui.	 But a stricture of the bone without a wound or incision should be treated by placing on it an ointment made from flour and egg white.
Et pone stuppam lenem super ipsum.	 And place soft tow on top of it.
Deinde pone spheram sub titillico eius, si indiges illa.	 Then place a weight under its heel if necessary.  />
Deinde accipe himematem, id est, rotam quam tenent Saraceni, quae sit longa ualde: et sit latitudo eius palmi unius, aut circiter illud.	 Then take a bandage, that is, a roll as the Saracens use, which should be very long; its width should be one palm or about that.
Deinde pone puluillum duplicatum super stuppam et emplastrum.	 Then place a doubled piece of wool on top of the tow and ointment.
Deinde accipe astellam ex tabula subtili, cuius latitudo sit trium digitorum, et in longitudine similiter.	 Then take a splint from a thin board, whose width should be three fingers, and similarly in length.
Deinde inuolue eam in panno.	 Then wrap it in cloth.
Deinde inuolue pannum illum cum astella in loco alhimemati qui cadit super fracturam et locum.	 Then wrap the cloth with the splint in the place of the bandage that falls over the break and the place.
Deinde pone alhimemati super fracturam sicut reuoluiur, et inuolue eam super collum eius, et sub titillico eius sano, et sub titillico eius infirmo: et reduc eam super omnem partem, et quomodo uides quod strictura tenet fracturam strictura decenti: et est illud, quod non occultatur super te, et totum, ut non remoueatur astella desuper os fractum.	 Then place the bandage over the break as it was rolled, and wrap it around its neck and under its sound heel and under its damaged heel; and bring it back over every part, so that the stricture holds the break well: and this should not be hidden from you, nor removed, lest the splint slip off the broken bone.  />
Et propter hoc oportet, ut aspicias infirmum in omni die.	 And therefore it is necessary that you examine the patient every day.
Quotiens ergo mollificatur ligamentum, et uides astellam iam remoueri: tunc rectifica illud, et stringe ligamentum.	 Whenever the bandage softens and you see that the splint has already slipped off, then straighten it and tighten the bandage.
Deinde pone somnum infirmi super dorsum eius, et pone sub titillico eius apud somnum eius puluinar paruum in nocte, ut cum eo eleuetur adiutorium eius a latere ipsius.	 Then place the patient's back on his back, and place under his heel, by his bedside, a small pillow at night, so that with it his support is raised from his side.
Eleuatur ergo fractura furculae per eleuationem humeri.	 The fracture of the clavicle is healed by raising the arm.
Aut liga brachium eius ad collum ipsius: et non soluas ligamentum, si non accidat in loco accidens ex pruritu, aut ab apostemate, usque ad duodecim dies.	 Or tie the arm of that person to their own neck; and do not untie the bandage if it is not happening in the place of the injury due to itching or from a swelling, until twelve days have passed.
Deinde renoua emplastrum, si uideris faciem eius ad illud.	 Then renew the plaster if you see the face turning towards it.
Et adde in strictura, et dimitte ipsum, donec restauretur et coaguletur.	 And add tightness, and leave it until it is restored and solidified.
Et fractura quidem furculae stringitur et confortatur secundum plurimum in uigintiocto diebus: et quandoque fit in quibusdam hominibus in minore illo.	 And indeed the fracture of the clavicle is strengthened and reinforced most in twenty-eight days, and sometimes it happens more quickly in certain individuals.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Spatulae.	 ¶ On the healing of a scapula fracture.
Caput VII.	 Chapter Seven.
Raro frangitur Spatula, et in loco lato eius: et non franguntur ex ea nisi margines eius.	 The scapula is rarely broken, and only in its broad part; and from it nothing breaks except its edges.
Quando ergo frangitur ex eo locus, et frangitur in medio eius, et non cognoscitur illud nisi per tactum: tunc secundum quod est figura fracturae conare praeparationem eius.	 When it is broken in that place, and it breaks in the middle of it, and this is not known except by touch; then according to how the fracture appears prepare it.  />
Et reduc eam super figuram naturalem omni modo ingenii, quod est tibi possibile.	 And bring it back to its natural form in every way possible for you.
Deinde pone super locum puluerem molendini cum albugine oui, et stuppam lenem, et pone desuper puluillum ex panno duplato.	 Then place on the site powder of flour with the white of an egg and soft flax, and put a little bit of doubled cloth over it.
Deinde pone super ipsum astellam latam ex tabula subtili secundum quantitatem Spatulae totius, aut ampliorem ea parum.	 Then place on it a broad splint made of thin board according to the size of the entire scapula, or slightly larger than that.
Si uero sub astella est concauitas in aliquo locorum Spatulae, tunc aequa illam concauitatem cum stuppa leni, donec descendat astella secundum aequalitatem.	 If however there is a hollow beneath the splint in any place of the scapula, then fill that hollow with soft flax until the splint descends to an even level.  />  />  •
